column2: KANSAS CITY (AL) Placed Steve Busby, pitcher, on 21-day disabled list, Sent Roger Nelson and Jerry Cram, pitchers, to Omaha farm club.

GOOD AND BAD Today's cheering news for movie buffs is the start of the Downtown Film Club's summer season as a homebound diversion for workers in lower Manhattan, now at a more accessible location Pace University, one block east of City Hall. The picture is "Arsenic and Old Lace" (1944). Screenings are at 5:30 and 8 P.M. Admission is $1.50 at the door, with reservations at 285-3715.

GENEVA, April 3 The Western industrialized nations and the third world are to make another attempt this year to agree on an international fund to stabilize the earnings of developing countries for their exports of ray materials despite their failure in a four-week-long first try that ended early today.

He was Ernest Hemingway, Edward R. Murrow and William L. Shirer. The very mention of his job recalled the liberation of Paris, the Spanish Civil War and the bombing raids and foxholes of World War II. His work suggested red plush bars in the grand hotels of Europe, ringing dispatches with evocative datelines and; of course, trench coats, He and occasionally, she had the ultimate elite job in journalism the Foreign Correspondent.

The problems of the Mitchell-Lama housing in New York State pose some of the thorniest questions facing public officials today. The program was devised in 1955 as a way to provide private housing for families who earned too much for public housing but too little for the normal market. Its apartment houses have been funded by the state and city with $4 billion borrowed from the public.

Kansas, a rock group with an album in the top 10 on the best-seller charts, has its saving graces. There is a certain Middle Western energy to the band's playing, the sort of energy with which local bands in Missouri or Ohio regularly put headlining groups to shame, Kansas's arrangements are tight and complex, with mixed meters, contrapuntal passages for keyboards and electric violin, and sudden shifts in dynamics.

BOSTON, April 3 (AP) "Steve a Cauthen Day" was big and profitable for Suffolk Downs, but not for Cauthen, who failed to win a race in six tries. The crowd that gathered to see the 16-year-old jockey with 186 victories bet $562,956, the highest handle at Suffolk in six years. The attendance of 15,797 was the largest since 1973.

Bleacherites of the old Ebbets Field would have felt at home yesterday in the Queens schoolyard where four tavern-sponsored teams opened the season of what some irreverent softball fanatics call the "gin-mill league."

PARIS, April 3 Jacques Chirac, the former French Prime Minister, predicted today that if the left won parliamentary power in the next elections, as is widely expected, it would be the end of France's Fifth Republic.
TEL AVIV, April 3 (AP) Former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan announced his support today for the governing Labor Party in the May 17 elections, ending speculation that he would join the opposition.
SARASOTA, Fla., April 3 The National Cancer Institute is planning the first test on humans of a drug that may be able to prevent certain types of cancer.
William Lee McKim, a former stockbroker with Blair Company and an art collector, died Saturday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived and was vice president of the Society of the Four Arts.
WASHINGTON, April 3 President Anwar el-Sadat arrived today for his first meeting with President Carter, in which he is expected to set forth Arab conditions for peace in the Middle East.
John Sharpe, who has appeared locally with the Bel Canto and Amato Opera Companies, made his New York recital debut Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.
MOSCOW, April 3 (AP) Lev Kopelev said today that he had been expelled from the Soviet Writers Union, apparently as a reprimand for his support of dissidents.

Idiot savants, seemingly retarded people capable of performing mental feats far beyond normal human capacity, ap- pear to have brains capable of such extreme concentration on narrow subjects that their minds are simply unavailable for normal activities, an authority on the subject said at a scientific conference yesterday.
EL TUR, Israel-Occupied Sinai, Not far from the jutting weathered an abandoned mosque on a beach here, a skeletal rig erected in the blue green waters of the Gulf of Suez plumbs the depths for oil.

WASHINGTON, April 3 Top officials of the Carter Administration are scheduled to meet Tuesday to begin shaping a new United States immigration policy that could have significant consequences, not only for the six million to eight million illegal aliens now in this country but also for employers and native-born workers.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) A priceless collection of manuscripts of music by Mozart, Beethoven Bach and others that has been missing since World War II has been found in Poland. The collection was traced by a British zoologist who spent five years searching for a herring's correct name, The Sunday Times reported.

WASHINGTON, April 3 Joe W. Grotegut, a longtime Florida newsman who became a Washington public relations executive, died of a heart attack Friday near his weekend home in Orange, Va. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 3 "The transition to a solar era can be begun today," writes Denis Hayes in an optimistic appraisal of the future of sunshine and related energy forms published this weekend by the Worldwatch Institute, a foundation-funded environmental watch-dog group.
TRENTON, April 3 All declared governorship candidates are scheduled to receive questionnaires tomorrow from Common Cause, the public-affairs lobby, asking their opinion on nine issues.

"Samson et Dalila," the last opera to enter the Metropolitan's repertory this season, had its first performance Saturday night. Although the production dates back over a dozen years, it is still a handsome affair. Robert O'Hearn's Bible-story sets remain lavishly colorful and Nathaniel Merrill's straightforward direction takes the opera's rather monolithic tableau nature at face value without imposing any fancy interpretations even the temple caves in at the end with alarming realism.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 Presion Henn of Pompano Beach, Fla., won the Swift Hurricane power-boat race today, beating the second-placed finisher, Sandy Satullo of Fairview Park, Ohio, by 14 seconds.

CHICAGO, April 3 Applause resounded throughout the Chicago International Amphitheater tonight as an audience of 2,000 cheered Ch. Rinskittle Bartered Bride, a stunning white standard poodle, who was selected as the best of 3,811 dogs at the International Kennel Club of Chicago AllBreed show.

DARLINGTON, S.C., April 3 (AP) Darrell Waltrip captured his first Grand National auto race in a wild finish today as the $156,185 Rebel 500 ended in controversy with the yellow caution flag out the final six laps.

Mordecai Shehori, an Israeli pianist who now lives in New York, made his New York debut in 1974 and have another recital in Carnegie Recital Hall late last season. Saturday afternoon he appeared as part of a young-artists series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and made a pleasing impression.

BOSTON, April 3 (UPI) Jo Jo White scored 6 points in a fourth-quarter spurt that enabled the Boston Celtics to defeatthe Philadelphia 76ers today for the first time this season, 96-90, at Boston Garden.

Years of "sweetheart" relationships between the Democratic and Republican Parties in Queens are ending at least this year with the prospective G.O.P. candidacy of Maurice H. Nadjari for District Attorney and Republican plans to oppose the re-election of Borough President Donald R. Manes, who is also the Democratic County leader.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The United States does not have a coherent policy on immunization, and this jeopardizes efforts to protect Americans, especially children, against serious diseases, six consultant panels have reported to the Federal Government.

This seems to be the year for dedicating this column to the Anglophiles of New York. Having settled on one or two sources for the English sausages known as bangers and having offered at least one recipe for that old British favorite, bubble and squeak, we have received numerous requests for sources for English crumpets.

The decision by CBS-TV last week to move its programming and businessaffairs departments to the West Coast is likely to mark the beginning of a migration to Southern California of certain other operating units of all three networks.

URFA, Turkey The new green wheat is pushing up through the dry soil of this province in southeastern Turkey, just as it did when Abraham lived in it during his family's migration to Canaan. But now, the soil and the wheat belong to the peasants. Land reform is coming to Turkey.

MOUNT VERNON, Ind., April 3 (AP) The 7,000 residents of this southern Indiana community were urged yesterday to stop drinking their water after it was discovered that chemical pollutants had seeped into the city's water system from the Ohio River.

DACCA, Bangladesh, April 3 (Reuters) More than 600 deaths from a tornado that struck Bangladesh Friday have been confirmed, authorities said today. Hardest-hit was the Madaripur district 80 miles southwest of here, where relief officials said 596 people had died, 200 of them when a motor launch capsized if the Meghna River.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., April 3 Six South Korean children, branded "untouchable" in their native country, were guests of honor at a small reunion party here.

"Back in the 1920's," Phil Beiber writes, "Walter Reade was the wealthy owner of a chain of movie theaters, a high-bracket horse bettor and an expert on how and when to gamble. He had connections with knowledgeable trainers, and he loved to put over fast deals. For insurance, he always insisted that anybody bringing a proposition to him put up his own money. Then Walter would bet an equal amount for him.

WASHINGTON Informed press speculation has made people aware that President Carter's energy program is likely to involve big taxes, higher prices, stiffer regulation. But those are details. They do not really convey the profound nature of what Mr. Carter may attempt.
Herdis Parker Hanson, who was supervisor of music at the Midtown Ethical Culture School for more than 40 years, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 79 years old.

KOUNTZE, Tex., March 27 There is a place not far from here where the ecology of the Southwest meets and mingles with that of the Southeast, where cactus and yucca plants native to the arid sands of New Mexico and western Texas flourish practically side by side with ferns and orchids more at home in the Florida Everglades.

The new Lincoln Medical Center in the South Bronx, after a turbulent first year, has won recognition by the National Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals and been commended for "efforts toward providing patient care of quality."

NEWARK, April 3 When the Tommy Flanagan Trio, with Larry Ridley on bass and Freddie Waits on drums, performs Wednesday at the Paul Robeson campus center here, an overflow crowd is assured. For one thing, the talent is first rate; for another, the show is free.

ALBANY, April 3 New York City is evaluating the 86,625 acres of reservoirs, lakes and other watershed properties it owns in five counties to the north of the city, with a view toward seliing any land it does not need.

LUSAKA, Zambia, April 3 During the middle leg of his African trip, President Fidel Castro of Cuba tried to mediate between Ethiopia and Somalia two neighbors that are historical enemies but now both ideologically aligned with the Soviet.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 3 (AP) Danny Edwards calmly, confidently, cut out a round of par-72 today, while his would-be challengers fell victim to their own mistakes, and posted a frontrunning, four-stroke victory in the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

One of the most exciting events for inexperienced players ever staged in the New York metropolitan area was played Friday night at the Y.W.C.A., 515 North Street, White Plains. The Westchester Contract Bridge Association attracted 134 experienced players, some with international reputations, and paired them with 134 inexperienced players, many of whom had played little or no duplicate bridge.

WASHINGTON "Barbaric!" an infuriated Leonid Brezhnev shouted at the President of the United States and his three advisers. He thumped the table, complaining bitterly and at length about American actions on a less-than-strategic matter that threatened detente. "Just like the Nazis," he charged, and railed on uninterrupted for fifteen minutes.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., April 4 Several prisoners at New York State's only women's prison have sued in Federal Court charging that they have been humiliated, degraded and embarrassed by the presence of male guards in their housing units.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) President Carter's son, Chip, is one of about a dozen former employees of the Georgia State Energy Office under scrutiny by Federal investigators in connection with a possible fuel-for-favors scandal, two columnists said today.

DETROIT, April 4 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation workers are increasingly retiring in their mid-50's, instead of waiting to reach the mandatory retirement age of 68, according to company figures.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., March 29 F. David Mathews, the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has returned to Alabama determined to promote a social philosophy that seems to be no better received by students and faculty members at the University of Alabama here than it was by bureaucrats in Washington.
CHICAGO, April 4 (UPI) Edward J. Barrett, a power in Illinois and Chicago Democratic politics until he was convicted of bribery, mail fraud and tax evasion, died today. He was 77 years old.

TOKYO, April 4 (AP) Shirley Graham DuBois, widow of the black American civil rights pioneer W.E.B. DuBois, has died in Peking of cancer, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported today. She was 69 years old.

HOUSTON, April 4 "Candace Mossler was so infamous, I just wanted something exciting that was hers to show my grandchildren when I'm a dull, old grandmother," Ann Matthews, a Beaumont, Tex., resident explained.

"It was all very impersonal," Fred Thomas said yesterday, recalling his retirement last Oct. 4 from the New York City Police Department. "They take your gun and your shield. Then you walk out the door and you're lost."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 Palestinian guerrillas opened a major counterattack today in southern Lebanon against Lebanese right-wing Christian militia forces that receive supply and artillery support from Israel.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The Supreme Court ruled today, 7 to 1, that if the jury in a Federal criminal trial does not agree on a verdict and the trial judge then acquits the defendant the Government may not appeal the acquittal.

WASHINGTON, April 4 Tip O'Neill pads around his big office in the Capitol, absently puffing a cigar, whispering on the phone, chatting with aides, telling yarns, stuffing notes into his pockets and welcoming visiting Congressmen.
Cornell moved into the top spot yesterday in the weekly national lacrosse coaches' poll for the first time this year. In the two previous ballots the Big Red was second, behind Maryland.

A sweeping proposal by Mayor Beame to scrap the New York City Board of Education and replace it with a citywide Schools Commissioner, serving at the pleasure of the Mayor, is due to be made public in a month, at which time Mr. Beame plans to conduct public hearings on the merits of the plan, city officials said yesterday.
News that the General Foods Corporation planned test marketing for a beverage, Mellow Roast, made from roasted coffee beans and wheat unsettled the coffee trade yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 4 (UPI) The General Foods Crporation, the nation's largest coffee roaster, announced today it was introducing a new coffee-flavor beverage made from a blend of coffee beans and natural grains that is substantially less expensive than conventional coffee.

One of the most curious episodes of the recent Spring Nationals in Pasadena, Calif., was that Kathie Wei of New York, in all probability, forfeited a national title by being too successful. Her Vanderbilt Cup team had such a great run, beating a string of strong teams including the second-seeded Brachman group to reach the final, that she was deprived by the scheduling of a chance to play in the Women's Knockout Team Championship.
DOVER, Del., April 4 (AP) A team of experts began today the task of identifying 326 victims of the world's worst air disaster.

Dear Leonid: I hear you were surprised when Henry didn't show up at your place the other day, but that was no reason to treat Cy like a total stranger. The fact is, Henry has moved out of the neighborhood and taken on three or four new jobs and is making a mint, and Cy has moved into his place.

MAN'S NATURE At 8 o'clock tonight, in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History, the public is invited to attend a filmlecture tribute to John Burroughs, the internationally known naturalist. The John Burroughs Memorial Association was founded in 1921, shortly after his death.
VADUZ, Liechtenstein, April 4 (UPI) This principality of 23,700 people and 62 square miles said today that it was doing all right economically despite troubles elsewhere in the world.

"The American Short Story," which begins tonight at 8 on public television, represents a long-overdue recognition of the obvious. The short story has been the special creation and pride of American literature, but the form has been virtually ignored by television, the great devourer always in need of fresh ideas.

ATLANTA, April 4 Voters in the Atlanta's Fifth Congressional District are expected to divide sharply along racial lines tomorrow when they select a successor to former Representative Andrew Young, who was, one of only three Southern blacks in Congress when he resigned to become chief United States representative to the United Nations.

Thirty persons were indicted yesterday in what was said to be a $50 million-ayear heroin operation that led from Queens to Asia and back. Among those indicted was a man accused of running the operation from his prison cell.

The Mobil Oil Corporation is exploring with the Newhouse newspaper interests the possibility of purchasing the plant of The Long Island Press and reviving the Queens-based newspaper that closed its doors on March 25.
A Staten Island heating-oil distributor was arrested yesterday and charged with receiving more than $700,000 worth of fuel oil stolen over a five-year period from Exxon storage tanks in New Jersey.
BELLMORE, L.L., April 4 (AP) Navy Lieut. William Klenert was buried in the Long Island National Cemetery in Pinelawn, L.I., 10 years after his death.

NEW HOPE, Ga., April 4 At least 72 people were killed in this tiny rural community this afternoon when a Southern Airways DC-9, its two jet engines knocked out, apparently damaged by hail, crashed onto a roadway.
LAKELAND, Fla. Within the next two months, the harvesting of the 1976-77 citrus crop will be completed throughout the state, and growers will close the books on a very trying year.

With the matter of New York landing rights for the controversial Concorde still awaiting a decision by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the French manufacturer of the joint French-British supersonic jet last night began an ad campaign asking, "Give it a fair hearing."
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) Buyers of new homes require $5,000 more on average for a down payment now than they did only four years ago, according to the nation's central bank.

WASHINGTON, April 4-Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, said today that the Central Intelligence Agency had informed him it was no longer secretly underwriting the publication of English-language books as part of its clandestine propaganda effort.

Priscilla Smith, who is currently appearing as Varya in "The Cherry Orchard" at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center, will play both Clytemnestra and Cassandra in "Agamemnon" when the classic by Aeschylus opens at the Beaumont on April 29. John Cazale, whose film credits include "The Godfather" and "Dog Day Afternoon," will play opposite Miss Smith in the role of Agamemnon and Aegisthus.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 4 If a powerful batting demonstration can sway management into agreeing to sky-high salary demands, lanky Dave Kingman presented some mighty arguments in his behalf at Fort Lauderdale Stadium tonight.

This 171-year-old house is called the Matthew C. Perry House, or simply "Quarters A," by Navy personnel. It has been home to the commanding officer of the Navy Yard post since 1806, when the mansion, framed in hand hewn oak, was built for the then considerable price of $20,900. Commodore Perry lived in the house in 1841-43.

Taking a leaf from critics and guidebooks, New York City Health Department has decided to start giving stars to restaurants that pass its inspections, in addition to publicizing those that flunk them.

PARIS, April 4 In an interview published in Le Monde today, President Sadat said that some "minor rectifications" could be negotiated on Israel's West Bank border but that there could not be even a centimeter of change on the Sinai and Golan Heights frontiers.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 4 The Venezuelan Government's latest economic statistics show that despite its oil wealth the nation had a budget deficit of $332.8 million in 1976 and an overall balance-of-payments deficit of $286 million.

NEW HOPE, Ga., April 4 At least 66 people were Killed in this tiny rural community this afternoon when a Southern Airways DC-9, its two jet engines knocked out, apparently damaged by hail, crashed onto a roadway.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The White House and the State Department made a concerted effort today to deny reports that American miscalculations had induced the Russians to reject proposals for limiting strategic weapons.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 4 Palestinian guerrillas opened a major counterattack today in southern Lebanon against Lebanese right-wing Christian militia forces that receive supply and artillery support from Israel.
NDJAMENA, Chad, April 4 (AP) Four insurgents were executed by a firing squad today for their part in an unsuccessful assassination attempt against President Felix Malloum, official sources said.
DETROIT, April 4 (AP) Mark (the Bird) Fidrych, injured mainstay of the Detroit Tigers' pitching staff, held a new conference today to announce he was lonely and tired of hospital life.

NUTLEY, N.J., April 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the public outcry over the Food and Drug Administration's announced intention to ban saccharin, the widely used artificial sweetener, could jeopardize laws prohibiting the use of food additives known to cause cancer in laboratory animals.

SAN FRANCISCO The continuing drought, which has blanketed the Northwestern section of the United States, has raised the specter of widespread power losses as the reservoirs on which this region depends for much of its electricity become depleted.
WASHINGTON, April 4 About 150,000 retired miltary personnel are working for the Federal Government, receiving both salaries and pensions in a practice that has come to be known as "double-dipping."

On the 70th day of their attempt to go around the world in 80 days, two Norwegians parked their diesel-engined car on West 41st Street yesterday and listened to a noise level they had not heard, they said, since the clamorous traffic of Mideast and Asian cities.

J. Terry Bender, a former special-collections librarian and associate professor of library services at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., died Sunday in Franklin General Hospital, Valley Stream, after a short illness. He lived at 565 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, and was 51 years old.

PARIS, April 2 The ready-to-wear collections are shown here in a carnival atmosphere resembling a state fair, with musical accompaniment ranging From Meyerbeer to Guy Lombardo and such accoutrements as smoke bombs on stage. The first hazard is getting in the door, and store presidents are often left forlornly waving their tickets while fashion groupies enter unchallenged.

The Ladies' Fort, 2 Bond Street, is sponsoring a loft jazz festival this month, with a different group performing each evening at 8. According to flyers, the festival is devoted to "artists deserving wider recognition," and Monty Waters, who directed a 10-piece band at Ladies' Fort on Sunday, certainly falls into this category.

WASHINGTON, April 4 In his arms proposals to the Soviet Union, President Carter has implicitly accepted the longstanding contention of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that heavy Soviet missiles with multiple warheads could pose a threat to the...

One way or another, John J. Santucci, the District Attorney of Queens County, is about to become famous, either by being the upset victim of Maurice H. Nadjari's first attempt at formal politics, or by winning in November and becoming that long-awaited but never quite arrived Italian-American city Democrat with a pluralistic constituency.

VIENNA, April 4 Talks between representatives of the Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots aimed at seeking a federal solution to their divided island's problems resumed today with scant prospects of an early agreement.

Washington, Aprii 4 The Federal Trade Cammission and the General Development Corporation are negotiating a settlement of allegations that the big real estate company has engaged in deceptive sales practices, according to a prospectus made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

NEW DELHI, April 4 Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai, in his first substantive address to the nation since he took office 11 days ago, asked tonight for the people's support in the "gigantic" tasks of developing India and ending destitution within 10 years.

HACKENSACK, April 4 East Rutherford has agreed to drop its lengthy legal fight for extra compensation from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority in return for $9.755 million from the organization, which operates Giants Stadium and the Meadowlands Race Track.
GUERNICA, Spain For four decades the big lie has hung over this Basque town, whose very name has become a symbol of the horror of total war in this century.
TRENTON, April 4 The Assembly's Republicans on the State Legislature's Joint Appropriations Committee proposed today a net reduction of $83.6 million from Governor Byrne's $4 billion budget.

MARANDELLAS, Rhodesia "Let's see if we can spot any footprints," said Guy Cartwright, clutching his automatic rifle as he led a visitor through the bush to a vantage point overlooking his farm. The tracks he was looking for were those of guerrillas or "terrs," short for terrorists who are seeking to drive white farmers like Mr. Cartwright from their land.

The first half of "Jesus of Nazareth," Franco Zeffirelli's 6 hour 37 minute television film on the life of Jesus Christ, swamped all competing programs Sunday night, according to the Nielsen overnight ratings for New York and Los Angeles. The telecast, which covered most of the prime-time period on NBC, drew a 46 percent share of audience in New York and 53 percent share in Los Angeles.

Out of what must have been a shocking experience, the suicide of his mother, and the need to explore the reasons for such an act, Spalding Gray, in collaboration with Elizabeth Lecompte, has composed (to use their word) "Rumstick Road," a play that is partly a documentary and partly a series of counterpointed happenings that resemble bits from silent movies.

The New York City Commissioner of Ports and Terminals, Louis F. Mastriani, said yesterday afteh meeting with a prospective lessee of the city pier at 36th Street and the Hudson River that they were close to agreement on a contract. But whether the agreement with the prospect, the United Cargo Corporation, would solve the problem caused by police use of the pier for towed-away cars could not be determined.

The Secret Service announced yesterday that President Carter had ordered it to stop providing protection for the former Vice President, Nelson Rockefeller, and for Susan Ford, but to continue protection for Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, for at least two to four more weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 4 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Some aspects of President Carter's order to the Defense Department to review and upgrade an estimated 432,000, other-than-honorable Vietnam-era discharges can be squared with his earlier promise to close the book on that unhappy period.
PONTIAC, Mich., April 4 (UPI) The number of cases in the nation's worst outbreak of botulism rose to 35 today. One of the victims sued the Mexican restaurant that served the tainted food.
DETROIT, April 4 The General Motors Corporation said today it was raising optional equipment prices by about $25, or 0.4 percent on the average car.

WASHINGTON, Aprit 4 President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt told President Carter today that the Palestinian question was "the core and crux" of the ArabIsraeli dispute and that "no progress whatsoever can be achieved so long as this problem remains unsolved."

William E. Simon, former President Ford's Treasury Secretary, let the other shoe drop yesterday. Mr. Simon, age 49, the subject of much Wall Street speculation since he left Washington and Government service, will become "senior consultant on economic and financial matters" to the investment banking firm, Blyth Eastman Dillon Company, Inc.

President Carter's proposal to withdraw American ground forces from South Korea and his enigmatic description of the Air Force's future role there have sparked an intense re-examination of the strategic position in northeast Asia.

The Medicaid cutbacks promulgated by the New York State Department of Health were endorsed yesterday by the Federal Government after the regional office of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare eliminated some of the cuts sought by the state.
The New York Racing Association announced yesterday that another of its harbingers of spring would have to be held on Aqueduct's winter track.

WHITE PLAINS, April 4 Driven to the cashier's office by the threat of water shutoffs, about one-third of the 400 Mount Vernon residents who owed the city roughly $50,000 in delinquent water bills visited City Hall today to settle their accounts, according to David A. Ford Sr. the Mount Vernon Water Commissioner.

TEL AVIV April 4 An official here acknowledged today that Israeli gunners on the Lebanese frontier briefly joined the battle this morning as Palestinian guerrillas and Christian militia units fought with artillery and mortars in the Taibe area, about two miles from the border.

AUSTIN, Tex, April 4 On a sweltering summer day nearly 11 years ago, a band of Mexican-American farm workers set out on foot from the lush Rio Grande Valley to carry their hopes for an organized labor union to John B. Connally, then the Governor of Texas. Mr. Connally advised them in advance that he would not be at the Governor's mansion when they called.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters) The National Railroad Passenger Corporation announced today increases of 66 to 76 percent in its unlimited travel rail pass tickets in the summer peak travel months.

WASHINGTON, April 4 President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt told President Carter today that the Palestinian question was "the core and crux" of the ArabIsraeli dispute and that "no progress whatsoever can be achieved so long as this problem remains unsolved."

Always and inevitably, the independent auditor gets off on the wrong foot concerning credibility. At first blush, the practice as old as the public-accounting profession of having the company being audited pay the auditor's fee seems to fly in the face of common sense. "He who pays the piper calls the tune," as the saying goes.

Clarity and liberty tend to go together, like nuts and bolts. People who write and speak in the public arena have a certain obligation, therefore, to turn the wrench every once in a while in an act of preventive maintenance.
TRENTON, April 4 Governor Byrne released today a New Jersey energy conservation plan that he said would save consumers $278 million a year in fuel costs by 1981.

NUTLEY, N.J., April 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the public outcry over the Food and Drug Administration's announced intention to ban saccharin, the widely used artificial sweetener, could jeopardize laws prohibiting the use of food additives known to cause cancer in laboratory animals.

Four young musicians will offer "an incredible simulation" of the Beatles in a show called "Beatlemania" which will open May 19 at the Winter Garden Theater. Performing more than 50 songs written by John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, the four young actors will be the key figures in "a combination of multimedia and simultaneous live music performance" that "will re-create the frenzy . . . that surrounded the tumultuous 60's."

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 4 (Reuters) South Africa's chief deputy commissioner of police today denied allegations by Amnesty International that police interrogating detainees in South-West Africa used torture.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) President Carter appointed Esther Peterson a consumer adviser for the Giant Food supermarket chain, as his consumer advocate today.

Harvey S. Meyers, a stockbroker of Milburn, N.J., was indicted in Manrattan on charges of Federal income-tax evasion for 1971 and 1972. According to Thomas E. Engel, the Federal prosecutor in the case. Mr. Meyers was charged with failure to report $112,000 in income for they two years. The 37-year-old defendant was described as an independent floor broker with his own seat on the New York Stock Exchange.

Dr. Mervyn V. Armstrong, a retired clinical professor of obstetrics and gyne- cology at Long Island College of Medi- cine, now the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, died Saturday in his home at 176 Riverside Avenue, Amityville, L.I. He was 85 years old.

WILLAPA BAY, Wash., April 4 (UPI) Hundreds of oil-soaked birds washed ashore over the weekend on ocean beaches north of the Columbia River and south of Grays Harbor, and officials were unable to find the source of the oil.

CAMPIANO, Italy, April 4 (AP) Six persons, including an American motorcyclist, Randy Cleek, and his American mechanic, Kurt W. Keifer, were killed in a head-on collision between two autos last night near this northern Italian town, the police said today.
SAN FRANCISCO At the conclusion of a recent appearance by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. before the California Federation of Labor, John Henning, the federation's executive, spoke bluntly.

BALTIMORE, April 4 A major figure in the political kickback scandal that led to the resignation of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was sentenced to three months in jail and was fined $5,000 here today.

Six witnesses testified yesterday behind closed doors in Arlington, Tex., at a hearing concerning last week's slugging of Manager Frank Lucchesi by Lenny Randle, a second baseman for the Texas Rangers.

Army will begin its 20th and last baseball season under Coach Eric Tipton today when the Cadets play City College at West Point. Conditions should be about normal for Army baseball barely above freezing with a...
BELLMORE, L.I., April 4 (AP) Navy Lieut, William Klenert was buried in the Long Island National Cemetery in Pinelawn, L.I., 10 years after his death.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 4 Bombs exploded in two restaurants here today within a minute of each other, injuring 33 people, including some children.
A man outside, who would identify himself only as a city employee, was dumbfounded as what he called "the richies" walked into Macy's the other night.
Stock prices fell sharply along a broad front yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling 11.80 points to close at 915.56 in its largest drop in three months.

Even as a magnificently-equipped fly fisherman is stalking a trout with gossamer leader and artificial fly in some Eastern stream, a South American Indian is probably preparing a fishstunning potion with which he will gather his evening meal.

The best selling book in the United States at the moment is not "Roots"; it is "Your Income Tax." Small wonder. There was a time when taxpayers were supposed to sharpen their pencils on April 14 and make out their taxes; now the process is so complex that half of our 85 million returns are compiled with professional help.

HONG KONG, April 4 On the eve of the first anniversary of the large demonstrations last year that led to the ouster of former Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping, diplomatic sources in Peking reported today that, although the city was quiet, there were signs of possible preparations for a major political announcement.

For the third consecutive year, more boys than girls have won admission to Hunter College High School, which was all-female from its 1869 founding until 1974. The school, for gifted children, is at Park Avenue and 94th Street.

Of all the significant contemporary British playwrights, John Arden has had perhaps the most difficult time finding an American platform. Only a few of his many plays (such as "Serjeant Musgrave's Dance" and "Live Like Pigs") have received New York productions.
Charles H. Coster, a former United States vice consul in Florence, fed there on Sunday. He was 79 years old.

J. Terry Bender, a former special-collections librarian and associate professor of library services at Hofstra University, Hempstead, L.I., died Sunday in Franklin General Hospital Valley Stream, after a short illness. He lived at 565 Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, and was 51 years old.
HAVANA, April 4 With a little wonder and a lot of smiles, the South Dakota basketball team and its entourage arrived in this springtime capital today for a good will visit to Cuba.
CORK, Ireland The Ford Motor Company is said to be planning substantial manufacturing expansion here. Henry Ford built his first overseas factory in Cork 60 years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters) Any country could make nuclear explosives easily within two years by using increasingly available plutonium supplies and forming a small group of knowledgeable scientists, a Congressional report said today.

Pathologists in Little Rock, Ark., have refused to analyze the results of a sexchromosome test taken last Friday night by Dr. Renee Richards, the controversial 42-year-old transsexual tennis player said last night.

Investors in the Digital Equipment Corporation, maker of minicomputers, were shaken last week when the International Business Machines Corporation, the industry colossus, cut prices on a computer memory system competitive with an important Digital product.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters) Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he believed the Federal Bureau of Investigation had told some witnesses not to tell the Warren Commission the full truth about President Kennedy's assassination.
JERUSALEM, April 4 Normally frenetic Israel is operating this week on two speeds, slow and stop.

KINSHASA, Zaire, April 4 (AP) The Government of Zaire broke off relations with Cuba today, charging that it had uncovered evidence that Cuba was involved in the invasion of Shaba Province by rebels based in Angola.

This 171-year-old house is called the Matthew C. Perry House, or simply "Quarters A," by Navy personnel. It has been home to the commanding officer of the Navy Yard post since 1806, when the mansion, framed in hand hewn oak, way built for the then considerable price of $20,900. Commodore Perry lived in the house in 1841-43.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The Defense Department announced today the recall from retirement of Gen. Andrew J. Good- paster to take over as superintendent of the United States Military Academy. The appointment comes at a time when the institution's reputation has been clouded by cheating scandals and internal friction.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 4 Ralph G. Caso, the embattled Nassau County Executive, withdrew his name today from consideration for the Conservative Party nomination for re-election.

WASHINGTON, April 4 Representative Donald M. Fraser, asserting that he was astonished by the "brazenness" of South Korean intrusions into American life, said today an investigation had been started "to identify the sources of discord, corruption and distortion of national interests" in United States relations with South Korea.

The E.W. Scripps Company of Cincinnati, a privately held company, announced yesterday that it had proposed a merger with the Media Investment Company for cash amounting to $52 a share for the 583,268 outstanding Media common stock.

ROCK HILL, S.C., April 4 (AP) The Catawba Indians, who say they own some 144,000 acres of land in York and Lancaster counties under a 1763 treaty, say they are going to ask Congress to settle their claim.

Twenty-four of the 26 National Basketball Association referees, meeting in Chicago yesterday, voted unanimously to strike the playoffs, which are scheduled to begin next Tuesday, because of the failure to negotiate a new contract.
The struggle for control of the Babcock Wilcox Company turned into open warfare yesterday.
CHICAGO, April. 4 (UPI) Edward J. Barrett, a power in Illinois and Chicago Democratic politics until he was convicted of bribery, mail fraud and tax evasion, died today. He was 77 years old.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 4 A Philadelphia-based tobacco and vending machine concern with reputed ties to an alleged crime figure, Angelo Bruno, can operate here as long as it conducts "a legitimate business," Richard J. Williams, the Atlantic County Prosecutor, said today.

The credit markets drifted lower in price in unusually light trading yesterday, with most of the excitement in the corporate financing sector. There R.J. Reynolds Industries debentures were priced to yield 8 percent; Wells Fargo

CAIRO, April 4 (UPI) A bus with nearly 100 persons on board swerved to avoid a child and plunged into an irrigation canal yesterday. Nineteen passengers drowned, the police said, adding that 15 had been injured.

Radio City Music Hall, which in the last five years has been presenting stage acts with increasing frequency, has announced a Radio City Music Hall Pop Arts Festival, a twice-a-year, seven-week program of varied entertainment that will include jazz, pop semi classical concerts, rock and ice shows, and children's programs.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Joseph A.Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, plans "a major new push" to immunize as many as possible of the 20 million youngsters who are not protected against one or more of the common preventable childhood diseases, public health sources said today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 In his arms proposals to the Soviet Union, President Carter has implicitly accepted the longstanding contention of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that heavy Soviet missiles with multiple warheads-could pose a threat to the...

WHITE PLAINS, April 4 Westchester County Executive Alfred DelBello, responding to Republican charges that he had mishandled negotiations on a multimillion-dollar waste-disposal system, today disclosed details of the negotiations, and countercharged that the Republicans, aware of those details, were trying to embarrass him politically.
Pablo Yoruba Guzman, whose selection as program director at WBAI-FM contributed to a controversy that shut down the radio station for almost two months resigned yesterday, the station announced.

HARTFORD, April 4 Prison guards in Connecticut went on strike today despite a court restraining order. The walkout, which built up gradually from yesterday afternoon into a full-blown strike this morning, was the first by prison guards in the state's history.

Eugene Zador, who combined a prolific career as a composer of film scores with ambitious creations in the field of opera, concertos and musical compositions for leading musical groups in this country, died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The General Accounting Office reported to Congress today that New York City's fiscal and economic base was continuing to deteriorate and that prospects for halting the trend "are not bright." It cited burdensome taxes and declining employment.

WASHINGTON, April 4 The Defense Department announced today the recall from retirement of Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster to take over as superintendent of the United States Military Academy. The appointment comes at a time when the institution's reputation has been clouded by cheating scandals and internal friction.

Stravinsky's wistful and brutal "Rite of Spring" has become a rite de passage for choreographers attracted to its rhythmic intricacies. Maurice B jart created his version almost 20 years ago, and it remains one of his most effective ballets. Sunday afternoon at the Uris Theater, his Ballet of the 20th Century concluded its season with a performance featuring Angle Albrecht and Daniel Lommel as the chosen ones.

Robert Munoz, the executive director of a drug-addiction rehabilitation program in the Bronx, went on temporary leave without pay yesterday pending completion of investigations into the controversial program.
Out-of-state mail-order houses must collect sales taxes on goods sold in states where they have "substantial presence," the Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 4 President Nikolai V. Podgorny returned to Moscow today after a two-week tour of Africa that has underscored the likelihood of sharpened competition between the Soviet Union and the United States on the continent.

NORWALK, Conn., April 4 A fire of undetermined origin punctuated by numerous gasoline-tank explosions last night destroyed 115 sailboats and power craft in dry dock at three large marinas on Norwalk's waterfront. The damage was estimated at more than $1 million.
The "personnel" notice clacked across the National Football League's TWX machine like a classified ad:

LOS ANGELES, April 4 It had to happen, sooner or later. The string ran out for Brian Gottfried after 37 victories in 40 matches as he was beaten by Stan Smith in a 2-hour-5-minute slugfest that had the partisan crowd at Pauley Pavilion in an uproar. Smith won, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3, and took the title of the $150,000 Southwest Pacific open and the $27,000 first prize.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Senate Budget Committee adopted today a proposal that sharply cuts back the number of public service jobs President Carter wanted to be available in 1979 under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

Set to burst from their now traditional playoff hideaway on Long Island's North Shore, the New York Islanders will begin their third consecutive playoff quest for the Stanley Cup tonight in Nassau Coliseum. The Chicago Black Hawks, the club with the worst regular-season record of any playoff team will be the Islanders' opponent in the two-of-three games series.
Tornadoes skipped across three states yesterday as heavy spring rains triggered massive flooding in three others, leaving at least 26 persons dead, two missing and thousands homeless.

Although Tommy Flanagan, who has been Ella Fitzgerald's piano accompanist for the last nine years, was the official guest soloist with the National Jazz Ensemble at the New School on Saturday, the true guest of the evening in fact, the dominant force of the evening was the late Duke Ellington.
WASHINGTON, April 4 About 150,000 retired miltary personnel are working for the Federal Government, receiving both salaries and pensions in a practice that has come to be known as "double-dipping."

Dr. Mervyn V. Armstrong, a retired clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Long Island College of Medicine, now the Downstate Medical Center, of the State University of New York, died. Saturday in his home at 176 Riverside Avenue, Amityville, L.I. He was 85 years old.

Thirty persons were indicted yesterday in what was said to be a $50 million-ayear heroin operation that led from Queens to Asia and back. Among those indicted was a man accused of running the operation from his prison cell.

In the near corner, wearing paranoia and exclamation points, is Robert Ludlum of "The Scarlatti Inheritance" and "The Rhinemann Exchange." In the far corner, wearing greed and Hurricane Ella, is John D. MacDonald with his 49th book.

Jill Glankoff, the wife of Mort Glankoff, the founder and chairman of Cue Magazine, died yesterday at Morningside House in the Bronx after a lingering illness. She was 68 years old and lived at 219 East 31st Street.

TOKYO, April 4 (AP) Shirley Graham DuBois, widow of the black American civil rights pioneer W.E.B. DuBois, has died in Peking of cancer, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported today. She was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) A Federal Communications Commission administrative law judge today ordered that the license of the University of Pennsylvania's campus FM radio station not be renewed because of lack of supervision by university officials.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. President Anwar el-Sadat's current visit to Washington dramatizes United States interdependence with moderate Arab governments and the need for this country to pursue, no matter the obstacles, the strategy of Middle East peace enunciated last month by President Carter.

The Xerox Corporation announced that it was reducing prices in the United States for its 3100 copier by $2,000 to $5,500. Prices also were reduced by $2,200 each on the Xerox 3107 reduction copier, making its cost now $8,300, and on the Xerox 3100 LDC large document copier making its new price $6,700. Still another copier, the Xerox 660 table-top model, was reduced from $2,500 to $2,195.
WASHINGTON, April 4 Organized labor's fabled lobbying juggernaut is proving to be a rather weak and wheezy machine in the early weeks of the Carter Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters) Any country could make nuclear explosives easily within two years by using increasingly available plutonium supplies and forming a small group of knowledgeable scientists, a Congressional report said today.

Charles H. Coster, a former United States vice consul in Florence, died there on Sunday. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The Carter Administration is raising Government price support loan rates for 1977crop livestock feed grains and will pay farmers to set up a United States wheat reserve of some 300 million bushels from last year's harvest, Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland announced today.
LONDON, April 4 (AP) The dollar declined against Europe's major currencies today while the price of gold rose ahead of the International Monetary Fund's gold auction, scheduled for Wednesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Never bet on anything in the theater especially if it is theatrical reputations. These flourish and fade like wild flowers, Who would have guessed say as little as 20 years ago what No l Coward's reputation would be today. He was regarded as thin, witty, bitter and slightly acidulated, a reputation that, one would have thought, might have disappeared in a puff of elegant smoke from his own cigarette holder.

ALBANY, April 4 Governor Carey, who opposes capital punishment "as a matter of conscience," declined today to say whether he would veto legislation to reinstate the death penalty in New York State if it is enacted.

Jill Glankoff, the wife of Mort Glankoff, the founder and chairman of Cue Magazine, died yesterday at Morningside House in the Bronx after a lingering illness. She was 68 years old and lived at 219 East 31st Street.

ATLANTA, April 4 The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. joined with the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce today in support of the city's Mayor, Maynard Jackson, in his efforts to thwart a bitter week-long strike by the city's sanitation workers.

Rain-swollen rivers inundated towns in the hilly Appalachians yesterday, cutting communications and forcing thousands to evacuate or wait for rescue. At least 29 persons had been killed by rain and wind storms in the region.

Shortly after 1 A.M. yesterday, Evelyn Lieberman was awakened at her home in Forest Hills, Queens, by the ring of the telephone. It was the police. They told her that her stolen car had been recovered.

CINCINNATI, April 5 (AP) The University of Cincinnati board of directors voted unanimously today to continue participation in intercollegiate football, but ruled that a new funding arrangement must be developed to support rising costs of the athletic program.

With the "tuition gap" between public and private colleges widening each year, a growing number of high school seniors and their parents are asking whether it is worth several thousand dollars a year extra to attend an elite private institution.

Foreign indebtedness of governments, big companies and other international borrowers increased by a record $61.9 billion last year, according to the latest World Bank figures. United States banks and capital markets provided a substantial share of the loans.

BERRIEN SPRINGS, MICH. JUST off a two-lane highway at the end of a flat stretch of road distinguished by a Jack Frost food stand, a row of prefab houses, a vegetable stand and a gas station, two stone pillars mark the entrance to the farm owned by "the world's most popular human being."

Alan Hochberg, former Democratic member of the New York State Assembly who was convicted last December of attempting to bribe a potential opponent into not running for his Bronx seat, was disbarred yesterday when the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court granted a petition brought by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

A New York City Council committee moved yesterday to lift a 115- year-old ban on women "hawking" at such places as baseball parks, football stadiums and Madison Square Garden "Get your ice cold beer" or "Get your hot dogs here." The ban is largely ignored and is unenforceable anyhow, since the New York State Civil Rights Law prohibits such discrimination.

WASHINGTON, April 5 Senator Henry M. Jackson today applauded the United States' proposals to the Soviet Union to limit long-range missiles and bombers. At the same time he criticized President Carter for his public approach in negotiating with the Russians.

A simmering conflict between the New York State Department of Health and a federally financed hospital review organization in Manhattan boiled over yesterday when each side accused the other of attempting to undermine and demean their respective efforts to contain publicfinanced hospital costs.

WASHINGTON, April 5 In a harshly worded attack, Lane Kirkland, secretarytreasurer of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, accused President Carter today of reneging on campaign promises and of building a business-oriented Administration.

"I CAN honestly say I have never had a bad bottle of rioja." So wrote Hugh Johnson in his book "Wine." Strong words from a man who has drunk most of the world's wines and who had admitted to finding the normal number of clinkers among them.

Swedish experts continue to dominate the Philip Morris Cup, which is the bridge equivalent of a European Grand Prix circuit. Nearly all the bridge-playing countries in Europe have one tournament scheduled as part of the series, and players with the best record in a complete season earn substantial cash awards.
Ruth Towne, a former headmistress of the Brooklyn Ethical Culture School, died last Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 74 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.
HONOLULU, April 5 Like the dustblown prairies of the Western Plains, this land of trade winds and swaying palms is suffering from a drought.

IN THE LAST TWO seasons at the Impossible Ragtime Theater, George Ferencz has taken two of Eugene O'Neill's lesser plays, "The Hairy Ape" and "Dynamo," and recharged them with theatrical electricity. Each, particularly the first, became high-intensity experiences. The director's method was to take a literal line in the play man as animal, dynamo as earth mother and use it as the basis for an interpretation.

Copper futures prices dropped the daily permissible limit of 3 cents a pound yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange, leaving several hundred unsatisfied sell orders at the close. The unexpected selling was exacerbated when the price fell to levels that activiated standing orders to sell to prevent losses.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 5 Pending legislation to create a powerful state agency to rule on the siting of nuclear power plants and other energy facilities drew sharp criticism at a public hearing today.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. reported yesterday profit increases of 16.6 percent in its second fiscal quarter and 19.1 percent in the half year ended Feb. 28, reflecting higher revenues primarily from feature films. Frank E. Rosenfelt, president, said all three operating divisions continued profitable, citing "Network a co-production with United Artists, as M-G-M's highest grossing picture in recent years.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 The neighborhood is quiet now and the bookstore that last week bore the Nazi swastika is boarded up, but anger and pain remain in the voices of many of the survivors of German concentration camps who live nearby.

The first step by H.P. Hood Inc., the 131-year-old Boston dairy, away from being production-oriented and regional toward being marketing-oriented and national is Frogurt Frozen Yogurt and advertising for it breaks this month in six widely spread markets.

Joseph M. Adelizzi, a rough-hewn, gravel-voiced graduate of Yale University who was a major force in unifying a fragmented trucking industry beset by strikes and chaotic rate structures, died last Friday at his home in Montville, Conn. He was 81 years old.

NEW HOPE, Ga., April 5 A Southern Airways official said today that heavy hail apparently caused engine failure aboard the DC-9 twin jet that crash-landed yesterday in this little village, killing 68 persons and injuring 25 others.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 5 The New York Yankees added another expensive star to their glittering cast today when they sent three players and a bundle of money to the Chicago White Sox for Bucky Dent, the unsigned but long-sought shortstop.

Greater emphasis on public service and projects with a "clear visible impact on the city, such as cleanliness in streets and parks," will be sought in New York City's Summer Youth Employment Program this year, Donald Hamer, acting associate commissioner of employment, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The Treasury described today as "greatly exaggerated" fears that the big expansion in overseas lending by American banks posed a serious threat to world economic order.
New York State has completed negotiations for its annual spring borrowing, $3.6 billion this year, at an average interest rate of 4.51 percent, a significant improvement over last year's 7 percent.

HARTFORD, Wednesday, April 6 (AP) Striking Connecticut prison guards, ignoring a judge's back-to-work order and pleas by their leaders, voted last night against ending their two-day-old illegal strike.

Most stocks edged lower in dispirited trading yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average managed to move up slightly.

WASHINGTON, April 5 In a political compromise, the Carter Administration proposed today a food stamp bill that would eliminate the cash purchase price for the food coupons a concession long sought by liberals but reduce benefits for a substantial number of recipients.
MADISON, Wis., Wednesday, April 6 Mayor Paul R. Soglin overcame a secondplace finish in the February primary and won easy re-election to a third two-year term yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Labor Secretary Ray Marshall said today he would recommend higher tariffs and quotas on foreign shoe imports if the Carter Administration is unable to negotiate voluntary reductions in those imports from foreign countries.
LIVINGSTON, April 5 After more than seven years of waiting, the St. Barnabas Medical Center here will open its 12-bed burn-treatment unit tomorrow, hospital officials announced today.

The boy, Bachir Hila, comes from Semara in Western Sahara, one of thousands of Saharan refugees who have fled from the Moroccan and Mauritanian occupation forces.

TOKYO, April 5 (AP) The dollar dropped below 273 yen at the close of Japanese foreign exchange trading today, down 1.15 yen from yesterday and the United States currency's lowest level in three and a half years.

GENEVA, April 2 Roman Dzindzikashvili of Israel and Jan Timman of the Netherlands held the lead after six rounds of the Geneva International Tournament here in the Hotel la Mediterranee. Each has scored 3 -2 .

SOMETHING FOR Joey," on CBS tonight from 9 to 11, is "based on actual events in the lives of the people portrayed." The unashamed selling of products be they books, records or nightclub appearances, television specials or even pet causes and charities? Or is it the self-congratulatory air surrounding them where seldom is heard a discouraging word?

Cable television, which has not yet reached all of Brooklyn, will use terrestrial microwaves and a stratospheric satellite to broadcast live Madison Square Garden's entire sports schedule to virtually all of the continental United States.

After a four-year period of new ownership and management, the Bing Bing properties in Manhattan have changed hands again. The buyers are unidentified investors who apparently include members of the Bing family.

ATLANTA, April 5 Wyche F. Fowler Jr., president of the Atlanta City Council, soundly defeated John R. Lewis, the candidate of Atlanta's black leadership, in a runoff election today, to succeed Andrew Young as the Congressman from the 5th Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, April 5 Congress struggled today to clear away the obstacles it had built to enactment of President Carter's $4 billion public works jobs bill before both houses adjourn for Easter the Representatives tomorrow and the Senators on Thursday.

The Easter ham is second only to the Thanksgiving turkey as a traditional American holiday main course. Its glistening glaze of golden-brown sugar and the spicy and exotic scent of the clove studs offset the saline richness of the meat. Sliced with just a sliver of its own fat for flavor, and served with bunches of cress, bright green asparagus and parsleyed new potatoes, it becomes a proper celebration of the return of spring.

JOYCE RASMUSSEN Balint presented herself in two capacities Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall as a violinist and mandolinist. On the former instrument she performed a Bach Invention (accompanied by Sandor Balint on the guitar), Brahms's Sonata, Op. 78, and a Suite for Violin and Piano by William Grant Still (with Louise Colusso Feinauer at the keyboard).

TORONTO, April 5 (AP) Twentythree Canadian hockey players, most of them lacking international experience, leave tonight for Europe and an eight-game exhibition warmup for the world hockey championship. It will be Canada's first appearance in the championship in seven years.
Robert L. Taylor, registrar emeritus of City College, who during his 30 years as registrar enrolled an estimated 500,000 students, died yesterday at home at 430 West 24th Street. He was 67 years old.

NEWARK, April 4 Joseph A. Bonaccorsi, a prosperous Vineland physician, is spending 1977 in a cell in Trenton State Prison. Henry J. WASHINGTON, April 5 The United States has no evidence that Cuba is participating in any way in the invasion of Zaire by Katanga exiles based in Angola, officials said today.

SALISBURY, N.C., April 5 Ted Turner, who operates the Atlanta Braves under a restraining order, was the breakfast speaker today at the 18th awards meeting of the National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association, whose members gather here annually to salute those chosen by their peers as the outstanding sportswriter or sportscaster in each state.
CHILMARK, Mass., April 5 Insurrection is sweeping the islands of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

The Knicks celebrated the honoring of Coach Red Holzman and Bill Bradley last night by outscoring the Boston Celtics, 121-113, at Madison Square Garden. It was their fourth straight victory, their longest streak of the National Basketball Association season.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 5 (AP) Many of the favored players were eliminated today in the rain-delayed and windswept first round of the 75th North and South women's amateur golf tournament. The casualties included the defending champion, Carol Semple, Carolyn Hill, last year's medalist, and two former champions, Nancy Roth Syms and Alice Dye.

PEKING, April 5 (Agence France-Presse) For the first time since 1949, the traditional Festival of the Dead, coming one year after the riots in Tien Am Men Square, was celebrated neither in the traditional nor in the revolutionary way.

A bitter labor battle is expected to end today when unionized workers at the American Stock Exchange vote on a move petitioned for by some employees to drop Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union as their bargaining agent.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 5 Mayor Albert H. Wheeler edged his Republican challenger, City Councilman Louis D. Belcher, by one vote in yesterday's election, in an unofficial tabulation, but a recount was assured.

LONDON, April 5 A strike of nearly 4,000 aircraft maintenance engineers that began here last Sunday could completely shut down the state-owned British Airways by next weekend, Kenneth Wilkinson, the airline's engineering director, warned today.

The Farah Manufacturing Company, were management and directors have been turning over of late at a rate more normal to the company's line of men's slacks than to the boardroom, has a new chairman and three new directors.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Consumer credit in the nation expanded by $2.02 billion in February, the second largest monthly gain on record, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

IN THE not-too-distant past the idea has been explored that the common hamburger might have had Russian origins. The Russian name usually given for ground meat patties that are cooked and served with or without sauce is bitok and sometimes bitock or bitoke. Many people have tried to associate the name with a distortion in pronunciation of the words "beef steak."

Terence Cardinal Cooke urged New Yorkers yesterday to take strong community action such as picketing against "the indescribable horrors" of pornography and prostitution. He also urged lawmakers to join the fight if they want to stay in office.

With no anticipated defections but with another player addition, the Yankees begin their first pennant defense in 12 years today. This defense, they hope, will turn out better than the one in 1965 when they finished sixth.
