"Nobody told Kirk Douglas to fill in the dimple on his chin," said Steven Keats, "so why should they tell me to fill in the gap between my two front teeth? I can put caps on them, the same as I can put a hump on my back. That's what an actor does; he changes physically and psychologically from role to role."
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell slightly to 219.1 from 219.2 last week.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Wholesale prices jumped 1.1 percent in March, the sharpest increase since October 1975, the Labor Department said today. The announcement came even as President Carter was exhorting Congress to pass his program of economic stimulus.

An 11-year-old boy who the police say was dealing in heroin on West 115th Street in Harlem was arrested yesterday afternoon with a teen-age accomplice. The police also siezed more than 2 pounds of heroin and $1,400 in cash.

NEW DELHI, April 7 Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai opened a conference of half the world's nonaligned nations here today with the advice that "we must persist in solving our own problems, rather than depend on the charity and benevolence of others."

BALTIMORE, April 7-Jane Elizabeth Kenworthy of Washington, a writer and editor with Health and Education Resources Inc., which prepares teaching materials, died of cancer today at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital. She was 63 years old.

BABY JANE DEXTER, a big woman with a big voice, is giving a scattershot performance at the Ballroom, West Broadway below Houston Street, where she will be appearing for the next three weeks. She tries a little bit of everything, hitting and missing without establishing any consistent pattern or defining a positive personality.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The House ethics committee ruled yesterday, that Representative George Hansen, Republican of Idaho, may not solicit funds for his personal use.

Where the century-old annex to the Central Commercial High School once stood, construction of a combined office building and apartment house is about to begin. Groundbreaking is scheduled within 60 to 90 days, said Steven Goodstein, a principal in the Goodstein Construction Company.

A decision dismissing damage claims against the New York Stock Exchange and a major public accounting concern was affirmed in Manhattan yesterday by a Federal appeals court that said "the securities laws were not enacted to protect sophisticated businessmen from their own errors of judgment"

SARASOTA, Fla.,April 7 A simple, inexpensive new technique for collecting white blood cells from blood donors may help to prevent life-threatening infections in many thousands of patients who are treated with anticancer drugs, a hematologist reported here today.

MOSCOW, April 7 (UPI) Leonid I. Brezhnev met publicly for the first time today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in a display of heightened Soviet concern over the Palestinian role in a Middle East peace settlement.

The mathematics of bridge can be surprisingly mysterious, and players are often deceived in this area, not only at the table but also in retrospect with time to think. Some principles that are obvious in theory may be tricky to apply in practice.
Maurice H. Nadjari, the former special state prosecutor, has been subpoenaed to testify next week before a State Assembly subcommittee that is looking into grand jury and prosecutorial practices.

BEIRUT, April 7 Palestinian and leftist-Moslem forces pressing their offensive against right-wing Christian militiamen in southern Lebanon today captured the Shiite Moslem town of Khiam which had been under Christian control for more than two months.
Broadus Erle, violinist and teacher at the Yale School of Music, died at his home in Guilford, Conn., on Wednesday night. He had been ill for some time from cancer. He was 59 years old.

CHRIS BURDEN is waging a oneman war against Detroit. Disturbed because "you can't buy the most basic economy car for less than $4,000," he went ahead and made one himself a tiny bug of a machine that he calls a "B [for bicycle]Car." Powered by a motorcycle engine, the one-man machine steps up to 50 miles per hour and gets 150 miles to the gallon.

AFTER HE WON the Oscar, Jason Robards said that soon he would be unemployed. Now, however, Mr. Robards has found a job. He will be in Eugene O'Neill's "A Touch of the Poet," which Elliott Martin will produce and Jose Quintero will direct on Broadway next season.

TOKYO, April 7 (AP) The dollar gained slightly against the Japanese yen on the foreign exchange market here today for the second straight day, but still has made up less than one-tenth of the ground it lost on Monday and Tuesday.
PARIS, April 6 A wave of depression about the future has swept this city in the last few weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has brought with her strong commitments to help revitalize the nation's older cities and provide decent shelter for the poor.
NEWARK, April 7 Inmates at the maximum-security Essex County Jail demonstrated noisily today, but prison officials did not mind a bit.
New York City officials said yesterday that they would phase out $115,000 in contracts with a controversial Bronx drug-rehabilitation program.

KARLSRUHE, West Germany, April 7 Assassins riding a motorcycle pulled alongside a limousine carrying West Germany's chief prosecutor today and sprayed it with submachine-gun fire, killing him and his driver and critically wounding another official.

JOHANNESBURG, April 7 A United States-led effort to work out a compromise on the future of South-West Africa, the territory that South Africa has governed since World War I, appeared to have run into resistance from Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa at a meeting in Cape Town today.

CHICAGO, April 7 The "other" team in New York, the formerly amazin' Mets, neither signed nor traded Dave Kingman today but did manage to open the National League season with Tom Seaver pitching them past the Chicago Cubs, 5-3, before a standing-room crowd of 39,937 in old Wrigley Field.

New York's baseball season opened in Yankee Stadium yesterday before a crowd of 43,785 that included according to the Rev. William Kalaidjian God. "We pray this year," Chaplain Kalaidjian said in his invocation, "that from your great heaven we receive the world championship."

ATLANTA, April 7 A panel of historians, members of the Organization of American Historians, called today for a massive but temporary shift of emphasis in historical research to "place the woman at the center of history."
MIAMI, April 7 Three years ago when one of the 500,000 Cuban refugees living here suggested rapprochement with Fidel Castro, the proposal was greeted with a fusillade of bullets. The refugee died.

IMAGINE A WORLD in which there are no animals but men, women and children. Imagine them staring at one another, wondering where all the various species have gone and what they were like. Picture man as driven up against some final biological wall, awaiting his turn for extinction. This is the image, not immediate, but ultimate, with which some highly reputable conservationists are threatening us.
The National Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation said yesterday that it would award 177 scholarships totaling $60,000 this year to sons and daughters of present and former marines.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) President Carter's first major ambassadorial appointments are going to the Governor of Wisconsin, former Senator Mike Mansfield; two educators, three career Foreign Service officers and two Georgians.

BOSTON, April 7 (AP) Frank Duffy charged home on Duane Kuiper's 11thinning chopper, barely beating the throw and giving the Cleveland Indians a 5-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox in their American League opener today.
KINSHASA, Zaire, April 7 (Reuters) Morocco is sending troops and China military equipment to help Zaire repel the invasion of western Shaba Province, a Zaire Government spokesman announced today.

Two Federal agencies, in a move designed to preserve the earth's protective ozone, are drafting regulations that would ban "nonessential" uses of fluorocarbons as spray-can propellants. They will be issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency by April 26 unless unforeseen obstacles arise, according to officials in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 7 A Federal grand jury in New York today indicted John J. Kearney, a former supervisor in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on charges that agents working under his direction had illegally opened mail and tapped telephones in their search for Weather Underground fugitives.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) The Soviet Union owed nearly $10 billion in debts to the United States and other Western nations by the end of 1976 and was paying nearly $500 million in annual interest according to a study released by the Central Intelligence Agency today.

THE CONCERT AT Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night was billed as the, last of the 1976-77 season of the "Eve nings for New Music" presented by the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts of the State University of New York at Buffalo.
A strike by stagehands that closed down five Times Square theaters Wednesday and Thursday was settled last night and management reported that the theaters would be open today.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 7 Eight days before the United States meets South Africa in the American Zone, North Section final of the Davis Cup, Capt. Tony Trabert has changed three members of his four-man team.
Given the propensity of Americans to divorce and remarry, one would think they could live comfortably with the fact of being stepparents.
A Brooklyn police officer was indicted yesterday on charges of attempted murder and assault in the shooting of a boyhood friend last March 13.

GENEVA, April 7 The Soviet Union and its Eastern European partners have had to alter sharply their economic plans because of economic troubles in the West, United Nations' economists said today in a special study.

An art treasure was restored to full public view when the Postal Service decided to remove some phone booths and a bulletin board hiding parts of the Ben Shahn mural in its General Post Office in the Bronx. It was the mural's second rescue from obscurity.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee said today that he would introduce legislation to extend the present rules for the food stamp program for one more year and then to convert the stamps to cash grants that could be used by recipients for any purpose.
Decisions about where or whether to invest in home mortgages can no longer be left to banks alone, Eleanor Holmes Norton, New York City's Commissioner of Human Rights, declared yesterday.

Hitler was probably the weakest leader Germany has known in this century .... he took ineffectual measures against his enemies inside Germany . . . Hitler ordered that there was to be 'no extermination' of the Jews. . . . the killing was partly of an ad hoc nature
TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 7 (Reuters) Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense today denied a report that it had purchased Gabriel surface-to-air missiles from Israel, the Central news agency said.
Julius Watkins, a French horn jazz instrumentalist and music teacher, died Monday at St. Barnabas Hospital, Short Hills, N.J. He was 55 years old and a resident of Montclair. N.J.

Dr. Renee Richards says she has passed a sex-chromosome test. The 42-year-old transsexual tennis player said she agreed to take the test publicly last Friday night and received the results yesterday from a laboratory doctor at A. N. L. Laboratories in Fayetteville, Ark. A reporter for The Arkansas Gazette, Mark Albright, took three slides to the laboratory for a 'blind' test after pathologists in Little Rock declined to evaluate the slides last weekend, she said.
David Frost reasserted last night that he and his company had sole control over the content and editing of his forthcoming television interviews with former President Richard M. Nixon.

Two Federal agencies, in a move designed to preserve the earth's protective ozone, are drafting regulations that would ban "nonessential" uses of fluorocarbons as spray-can propellants. They will be issued by the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency by April 26 unless unforeseen obstacles arise, according to officials in Washington.

John Miles, the English singer, guitarist and songwriter who performed at the Bottom Line on Wednesday evening, has attracted a cult-following in New York with a brand of music one might as well label minimalist poprock.

Thousands of teen-agers, including many who had waited all night in near freezing weather lined up at community employment centers throughout New York City yesterday for the second day of registration for summer jobs. And for the second day many were turned away because of confusion and overcrowding.
WASHINGTON, April 7 Steel union and industry negotiators continued to meet late tonight seeking to work out a three-year wage and benefit settlement.

CANTON, Ohio, April 7 (AP) Jim Montgomery and Bruce Furniss, teammates on the United States' gold-medal winning 800-meter freestyle relay team, cracked American records tonight in the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming meet.

Lois, Holland, Callaway has changed its name to Holland Callaway. "We noticed that George was gone," said James T. Callaway, facetiously referring to his fellow founder, George Lois, who left the agency in late February to be president of Creamer/FSR.

Dr. Donald Kennedy, who was sworn in yesterday as head of the Food and Drug Administration, told employees of the agency, now embroiled in controversy over its recent order banning saccharin, that friends had suggested he was taking on "the captaincy of the Titanic."

WASHINGTON, April 7 Those Washington bigwigs deprived of their limousines may not know it, but their troubles are probably rooted in the hard-scrabble soil of southern Georgia and the price of apples there some years ago.
TOKYO, Friday, April 8 Agreement was expected to be reached here today between Japanese and American negotiators to restrain the export of Japanese color television sets to the United States.

Hundreds of children and many of their parents converted an Easter egg hunt in Flushing Meadow-Corona Park, queens, into a half-hour of pandemonium yesterday in which children wept, parents shouted and a park official tried to call the whole thing off.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company made at least $3 million in undisclosed and illegal payments to induce customers to buy its products, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged in a suit filed today in the Federal District Court here.

Some energy industry officials reacted with relief yesterday at President Carter's decision to continue research on the breeder nuclear reactor and to slow, rather than cancel outright, the industrial breeder demonstration plant on the Clinch River near Oak Ridge, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission has ruled that a Texaco television advertisement was politically biased and has ordered a station tha aired it to present opposing viewpoints to comply with the so-called fairness doctrine.

One of the longstanding members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most wanted persons is Bernardine Rae Dohrn, leader of the Weather Underground, a terrorist group that has said it was responsible for numerous bombings.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) The Federal Reserve Board took action today to enable persons to gain higher interest and other benefits from their own retirement plans at Federally insured commercial banks.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance conferred today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union in an effort to resume discussions on a treaty limiting strategic arms.
METULLA, Israel, April 7 Early this morning, residents of this community in northern Israel that peers over a barbedwire fence into Lebanon awoke to the sound of not-so-distant shelling.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) Soybean futures advanced 15 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today for a threeday total gain of 56 cents for old-crop beans.

LAST Sunday about 23 million American homes watched the first three-hours-plus portion of "Jesus of Nazareth," putting its director, Franco Zeffirelli, in the television blockbuster class. The second half of the sumptuous production will be presented on NBC this Sunday at 8.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals New York City's official dog catcher said yesterday that it had quit picking up strays and that this was part of its plan to go out of the animal-control business altogether on July 1 unless the city came up with a $2.1 million subsidy.

New Yorkers seem to be going to a lot of tea parties these days. Not to drink tea, necessarily. Given a choice, they're more likely to head for the bar than the tea tray. But it's chic to call a gathering a tea party, even if it happens at 6:30 and is held in a department store.
The nation's money supply, narrowly defined, declined $1.2 billion in the week ended March 30, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

The Raymond Johnson Dance Company is appearing in its Manhattan debut this weekend at Pace University's Schimmel Center. And what is it doing there? Dancing. Not demonstrating how to make Grandmother's 7-Up Cake or teaching football players to pirouette. Just dancing.

Mike Marshall of the Atlanta Braves said yesterday he was quitting baseball temporarily because of a months-long dispute with officials of Michigan State University. Marshall charges the university with disturbing his family.

More unmarried American teen-agers are sexually active now than in 1971, but they are relying more hearily on effective contraceptive practices, according to the results of a national survey released yesterday.
More than 200 drivers and maintenance workers struck the Short Line Bus Company early this morning.

Steve Cauthen won the first five races at Aqueduct yesterday and, after recovering from dropping his whip early in the seventh race, became the first jockey to win six races twice in a day at a New York track.

WHEN THE BRITISH departed from Massachusetts 200 years ago, they left behind far more than a bounty of English decorative arts. There was also, for example, a legacy of love for the splendid sterling silver wares that English craftsmen had been producing under kings and queens, and even under Cromwell, since the late Middle Ages.
JERUSALEM, Friday, April 8 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin submitted his resignation early this morning as the ruling Labor Party's candidate for a second term as head of the Israeli Government.

DETROIT, April 7 The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are scheduling shutdowns of four small car assembly plants next week. The closings will idle 14,300 workers. Subcompact and compact cars have lost about 6 percentage points of their market share this year to the intermediate and full-size cars.

The General Foods Corporation, a leading producer of packaged foods and, groceries, announced yesterday the election of Ross Barzelay as president. He succeeds James L. Ferguson, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

UNIONDALE, L.I., April 7 Despite becoming the visitors in their own rink, despite losing J.P. Parise to a knee injury and despite a sensational performance by Tony Esposito in the Chicago net, the Islanders scored a 2-1 victory over the Black Hawks tonight and advanced to the quarterfinal round of the National Hockey League playoffs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 Andrew Young, the outspoken United States delegate, apologized to the British Government today for saying in a broadcast interview that Britain was "a little chicken" on racial questions and had institutionalized racism "more than anyone else in the history of the earth."

WASHINGTON, April 7 President Carter, announcing as expected that the United States would not use plutonium to fuel nuclear reactors that produce electricity, appealed today to other countries to make maximum efforts to combat the spread of nuclear weapons.

NORWALK, Conn., April 7 The Planning and Zoning Commission last night approved a change to permit the giant Manhattan-based Continental Group Inc. to build its headquarters in Rowayton, despite a vote against the move by resin dents of the middle-class residential neighborhood, which thinks of itself as more of a suburb than as part of the city.

AMES, Iowa, April 7 (AP) Ben Peterson, an Olympic gold medalist, led a group of former National Collegiate champions who scored first-round victories today in the National Amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling championships.
Against a backdrop of all the recent adverse publicity about business activity, the corporate rite of spring, the annual meeting, promises to produce numerous probing questions from stockholders.

NEW DELHI, April 7 The new Government announced today that it was set ting up a judicial court of inquiry to in vestigate "all complaints of excesses malpractices and abuse of authority" during Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's 19 month period of rigorous emergency rule."
TRENTON, April 7 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a criminal could not be found guilty of murder if an accomplice in a felony was killed by one of their intended victims.
MOSCOW, April 7 The wife of a Georgian nationalist said today that her husband and two others had been arrested in Tbilisi, capital of the Soviet Union's Georgian republic.

THERE ARE certain works of art that remained lodged in our memories from the first moment that we see them. They leave us with a fond memory, a vivid mental picture, and a sense of a certain moment in time. Because of this, perhaps, we tend to assume that such objects continue to enjoy a public career long after we have first seen them.

OVERLAND, Mo., April 8 Veterans of the Vietnam years who received lessthan-honorable discharges, including deserters, are swamping the Government's Joint Liaison Office here with more than 3,000 telephone calls a day seeking to have discharges upgraded to honorable status.
CHICAGO, April 8 A plodding Democratic mayoral primary has become a political gouging match that would make any old-time Chicago ward heeler feel right at home.
WASHINGTON, April 8 The United States appeared today to give tacit approval to Morocco's decision to send troops to help Zaire repel an invasion by Katangan exiles from Angola.

The pilot of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines jet in the collision in the Canary islands with a Pan American World Airways jet last month apparently never heard the tower's instructions to "stand by for takeoff," sources close to the investigation revealed yesterday.

The Episcopal Diocese of New York signed an agreement yesterday with the Commission for the Elimination of Racism of the New York Council of Churches an agreement that the council believes gives it an opening for an attack on what it calls widespread racial discrimination in the Episcopal Church's leadership and staff.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation warned its stockholders yesterday that a Federal grand jury investigation may reveal more bribery scandals that could hurt its foreign aircraft sales and possibly "severely affect its financial condition."

Herman M. Karson, an architect, died Tuesday in an automobile accident in Elko, Nevada, while on vacation. He was 56 years old and lived at 90 Beekman Street.

Scientists working on artificial sweeteners in laboratories around the country, driven by the vast commercial potential that would be opened up by the Food and Drug Administration's planned ban on saccharin, are accelerating their efforts to find, develop and win approval for alternative sweeteners.

ST. PAUL, April 8 The Minnesota Supreme Court today unanimously affirmed the decision of a lower court and ordered state environmental agencies to issue permits for the Reserve Mining Company to dump ore wastes at a disposals site in northeastern Minnesota that the company prefers.
HAVANA, April 8 Gen. Raul Castro praised today the visit of South Dakota's basketball team as an important step in restoring normal relations between Cuba and the United States.

EL CENTRO, Calif. Most of California is suffering from its worst drought on record, with agricultural losses reckoned at $3 billion, but prospering farmers here in the sun-baked Imperial Valley would be delighted if they never saw another drop of rain.

Like thousands of New Yorkers, Wendy Fuller, Marlene Matarese and Lawrence Goldstein had to share their two-room Greenwich Village apartment with battalions of cockroaches. All kinds of chemical sprays seemed to have little effect, except on the roommates.
BUFFALO, April 8 (AP) Bob McAdoo made a triumphant return to Buffalo tonight, scoring 41 points to lead the New York Knicks to a 104-102 victory over the Braves at the Memorial Auditorium.

Robert A. Ronan, an actor in many productions of the New York Shakespeare Festival, died Wednesday of injuries received when fire destroyed his home at 143 Goldenrod Avenue in Franklin Park, L.I. He was 41 years old.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 7 The progressive Roman Catholic clergy of this industrial metropolis has changed the style of Easter worship here to serve the religious needs of the poor and promote a more "communitarian" church.

JAKARTA, Indonesia Continued repercussions from the failure of the state oil company are threatening large segments of Indonesia's private banking and business community with collapse, with possibly serious effects on American and other foreign banks and financial institutions doing business here.

WASHINGTON, April 8 Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here and in New York expressed anger, bewilderment, hurt and concern today over the first felony indictment issued against an agent in the 53-year history of the bureau.

A 45-year-old Chinese-born poet and professor who came to New York to attend a conference of the Modern Language Association jumped or fell to his death from his room at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel, 106 Central Park South, yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, April 8(AP) Despite the rising cost of new homes, Americans bought them in record proportions in February, the Government reported today.

Elias Sarkis, the new Lebanese President, knows a lot but, when I interviewed him in Beirut in November, he did not like to speak about the past. He knew that if he did not succeed, no one would after him.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, April 8 The oldest ski resort in the United States was sold today for an undisclosed sum when a Wyoming businessman, R. Earle Holding, closed negotiations for Sun Valley with the owner, William Janss.

ATLANTA, April 8 Members of the Organization of American Historians holding their 70th annual meeting here have elected a Marxist historian, Eugene Genovese, as their president-elect for 1979, the organization announced today.

TAIPEI, Taiwan In the two years since the death of his father, Chiang Kai-shek, Prime Minister Chiang Ching-kuo has moved with a combination of toughness and subtlety to achieve even tighter control over this island's 16 million people than his father enjoyed and to preserve Taiwan's record as the most stable country in Asia.

Six men allegedly involved in a major counterfeiting operation that flooded the New York metropolitan area with bogus $20 bills in the last five months were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

A Brooklyn police sergeant yesterday strenuously denied allegations by District Attorney Eugene Gold that there had been "mishandling or a cover-up" in the police investigation of an attempted murder involving a fellow policeman last month.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Although dry areas still persist, the rain and snow that fell over much of the nation last month improved prospects for the 1977 crop in some of the country's most productive grain areas, the Agriculture Department said today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 Two New Yorkers are believed the leading candidates to become chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and Comptroller of the Currency, banking and Government sources said today.

MADISON, Wis., April 8 Gov. Patrick J. Lucey has surprised political leaders of both parties in Wisconsin by announcing that he would resign to accept President Carter's nomination as Ambassador to Mexico.

The musical tribute that was held at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Thursday evening was in honor of Duke Ellington and the program improvisations by three pianists and selections from Ellington's Sacred Concerts was devoted to the Duke's music. Yet it was the irrepressible Eubie Blake, still bubbling with high spirits at 94 years of age, who gave the concert its warmest, most appealing moments.

SINGAPORE, April 8 Singapore's formidable Internal Security Department, under orders from Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, has begun a new campaign to repress dissent that has crippled his thin political opposition and a fledgling human rights movement.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 8 In the end, the historians can write, they reverted to type.
The capricious winter weather, which put the Eastern half of the country in a deep freeze while patching the Western states, has had an erratic effect on oit and gas earnings as well.
A clothing store owner shot two robbers killing one after they critically wounded his 65-year-old mother in a robbery attempt Yesterday.

An arbitrator directed New York City yesterday to pay a cost-of-living allowance totaling $441 to each of its 18,000 police officers. At the same time, he ordered the partial deferral of annuity contributions by the city and other savings that a spokesman estimated would be more than $10 million.
ROME, April 8 Pope Paul VI, in a Good Friday enactment of the Passion and Crucifixion of Jesus, carried a large cross in an outdoor rite near the Colosseum late tonight.

BONN, April 8 Over the strong objections of the Carter Adminstration, West Germany has approved export licenses for the controversial nuclear equipment it has agreed to provide to Brazil, according to a Foreign Ministry spokesman.

HAVANA, April 8 Soon after he took power following the Cuban Revolution in 1959, President Fidel Castro put out the maxim that "Sport is a right of the people." In the intervening years, the state has expended a consistent portion of its meager resources on developing the physical side of what the Government calls "el hombre nuevo" the new man.

PITTSBURGH, April 8 Joseph P. Molony, who retired in 1973 as international vice president of the United Steelworkers of America, died yesterday in Sun City, Ariz., after suffering a stroke. He was 70 years old.

CANTON,Ohio, April 8 (AP) John Naber captured his 15th national Amateur Athletic Union swimming title and 14-year-old Tracy Caulkins picked up her second victory of the week, both in American-record times tonight in the A.A.U. short-course championships in Branin Natatorium.

MAHWAH, N.J., April 8 Negotiators for the Short Line Bus Company and for its striking drivers and mechanics reached a tentative agreement on a new contract tonight, less than 24 hours after a walkout disrupted Easter weekend travel plans for 10,000 commuters.

Helen Edwards Corlett, who was known professionally as Helen Ames during the half century she wrote for the society department of The New York Herald Tribune, died Thursday in her home in Ormond Beach, Fla., after a long illness. She was 74 years old.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 Tom Watson, who has developed a semantic adroitness in dealing with questions about his "choking" in the clutch, and Rod Funseth, a grizzled 17-year veteran who has a way of surfacing now and then in major golf tournaments, shared the lead today after the second round of the 41st Masters tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 8 Carter Administration officials said today that President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt had told them he envisaged full normalization of relations with Israel within about five years after a Geneva agreement had been signed, and that some interim steps toward normal relations could take place even earlier.

CHICAGO, April 8 Manager Joe Frazier joined the New York Mets' war with the unsigned Dave Kingman today, threatened to bench the power- hitting outfielder and said "I think it's time for him to shut up."

NEW HAVEN, April 8 Charles Seymour Jr., a professor of the history of art at Yale University and an authority on Italian Renaissance and sculpture and medieval art and architecture, died yesterday evening at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 65 years old.

JOHANNESBURG, April 8 At sunset, a muezzin's cry filters down the narrow colonnaded road. Women in saris appear on the stoops, watching their men folk gather for disconsolate conversation. Occasionally one of the men steps forward to poke at a pile of smoldering ashes, sending charred scraps flittering in the still evening air.
A 29-year-old Filipino doctor who works at Harlem Hospital was arrested yesterday on a charge of murdering his wife at the hospital on Feb. 9 with a deadly drug.

TRENTON, April 8 The New Jersey State Employees Association contends that 7,000 members receive such low salaries that they get food stamps, and has threatened a strike unless employees, especially the lower-paid ones, are given dramatic pay increases in the new budget that takes effect July 1.

To Ann Ginopolas, the planned opening of a topless bar not far from her home in Flushing, Queens, "is a disease which we must fight." To the establish- ment's owner, Harry G. Vertzinis, the bar "is a business, strictly a business."

Alexander L. Guterma, the controversial financier who was killed Tuesday with five members of his family in the crash of a private plane in the Bronx, conducted his affairs as mysteriously at the time of his death as he did when he controlled a large fortune.

KHIAM, Lebanon, April 10 Palestinian commandos have suspended their weeklong offensive in southern Lebanon pending the outcome of political talks between Syria and right-wing Christian leaders in Beirut.

A middle-aged theatergoer and his teen-aged daughter were heading home the other night when they spotted a man bent over, clutching his stomach, at the bottom of a flight of subway stairs in Times Square. The New York City Board of Education's continuing investigation into improprieties and deficiencies in the school custodial operation has found that 86 custodians held part-time jobs as helpers to other custodians in addition to their full-time jobs.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, April 10 (Reuters) Police sources said today that demonstrators set fire to a Libyan Government office here in apparent retaliation for the seizure of an Egyptian office building in Benghazi.

BRIDGEWATER, April 10 (AP) A reputed underworld lieutenant, freed from prison on a 26-hour court-ordered Easter furough, was shot and killed at a motel here early this morning.

Anna H. Griffiths, professor of classics at Brooklyn College for 25 years, died Friday of an apparent heart attack in Grand Central Terminal. She was 64 years old and lived in the Bossert Hotel in Brooklyn Heights.

MIAMI BEACH, April 10 (AP)-Mike Colbert, an undefeated middleweight, won a split decision today in the semifinals of the United States boxing championships by defeating the son of a man he knocked out two years ago.

John G. Hutchinson, professor of management at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, died Friday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 48 years old and lived a 19 Sycamore Street, Bronxville, N.Y.

ATLANTA, April 10 Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, speaking to a crowd of more than 3,000 opponents of the death penalty yesterday, called on "lovers of life" from all over the United States to reject capital punishment because "death as a problem solver is unacceptable to a humane people."

LOS ANGELES, April 10 A group of investors including Henry Ford 2d says it has obtained financing to acquire the hotly contested Irvine Company for $302.9 million. Among others in the group are Charles Allen Jr., Wall Street banker; A. Alfred Taubman, Detroit developer, and Joan Irvine Smith, heiress.
JERUSALEM, April 10 Shimon Peres, Israel's Defense Minister, was nominated today by the country's governing Labor Party as its candidate for Prime Minister in the general election May 17.

Alexander Drogin, the founder of Barjeff Company Inc. of Bayonne, N.J., a contracting concern, died Friday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived at 91 West 39th Street, Bayonne.

TOKYO, April 11 (Reuters) The Japanese yen rose to its highest level for three years against the dollar on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today and the Bank of Japan bought an estimated $70 million to support the American currency, dealers said.

During the bear market of the early 1970's, a visitor asked managers of a mutuel fund that had lost 25 percent of shareholders' capital in the prior year why they remained fully invested, since stock market prospects clearly continued to be bleak.

For the first time, the four-year-old Financial Accounting Standards Board, the private sector's top authority on accounting rules, yesterday abandoned a project because of a deadlock among its seven members.

A FROST seriously damaged grapes in the Bordeaux region of France 10 days ago. Some properties lost 50 percent or more of the 1977 crop. And every time a natural disaster strikes a major wine region, wine enthusiasts begin to reassess their buying patterns.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) A survey of travel by employees of three Government agencies shows that 15 percent of the trips violated standards for approved Federal travel, the General Accounting Office said today.

Franco Zeffirelli, who directed the six-hour film, "Jesus of Nazareth," which was presented on television by NBC during the Easter holiday, has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to make a modernized movie version of the studio's 1931 hit, "The Champ." It will be Mr. Zeffirelli's first American film under the auspices of M-G-M.

MOST Americans attend opera for the singing, and most American opera productions reflect that bias. At rehearsals, directors confine themselves to explaining rudimentary motivations and to position the singers in a way that makes decent dramaturgy but still gives them a clear view of the conductor.

The city held its first "garage sale" yesterday, auctioning off what the Municipal Service Administration called "choice items of memorabilia," including one fire hydrant, two barber's chairs, four dentist's chairs, 14 traffic signs, 15 traffic signal heads and 31 fire-alarm boxes.

ISTANBUL WHEN Muzaffer Gazioglu wants to go fishing, he steps out on his front porch and tosses a line into the Bosporus. When his wife wants to avoid the traffic, she sometimes goes shopping by boat. When his daughter got engaged and went looking for an apartment, everything seemed too small and cramped.

ROBERT SCHRADE gave his first New York recital since 1963 on Monday night in Tully Hall. The pianist, who made his debut here in 1949, has been out of concert commission because of finger surgery, but Since 1968 he, his wife and five musical children have overseen a thriving annual music festival, Sevenars Concerts, in Worthington, Mass., in the Berkshires.

SHANDAKEN, N.Y. UP HERE, a two-and-a-one-halfhour drive from Manhattan, there is a territory known as the Catskills. To some of the citizens and visitors hereabouts, it is also known as a transplant of the French Pyrenees, which was once home for many of those who have settled here. And American citizens of French background, who visit here by the score, agree that this area reminds them of the French mountain range.
Corporate merger announcements dropped to 490 in the first quarter from 557 a year ago, according to a survey by W. T. Grimm Company, a brokerage firm specializing in mergers.

Tex James, president and publisher of The Daily News, urged the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry yesterday. to get pledges from its 1,700 member companies to stay in New York City for the next five years.
Rend Brion, a retired Compagnie Francaise des Petroles executive of one of the largest oil companies in Western Europe, died in Paris Monday night after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

A legislative battle over Alaska's vast wilderness areas, some of which are rich in minerals and timber as well as scenery and wildlife, is taking shape as a major confrontation between those who want to protect this country's last great tracts of truly wild land and others who want Alaska to profit from the extraction of its natural resources.

Vinaigrette dressing is the only type dealt with here, because it is really the only fitting one for green salads. Save mayonnaise and sour cream dress ings for other vegetable, meat and seafood salads. These delicate greens cannot withstand the assault of heavy dressings on either their flavor or texture.

WASHINGTON, April 12 The National Market Advisory Board, a securities industry-dominated group advising the Securities and Exchange Commission on the national market system, is expected to recommend next week that all off-board trading restrictions be removed by a fixed date.

The world premiere of "Mollie," by Simon Gray, the noted English playwright now represented on Broadway by "Otherwise Engaged," will take place May 26 at the first Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C. Mr. Gray was also the author of "Butley," in which Alan Bates scored a triumph in London and New York several seasons ago.

WASHINGTON, April 12 Although nearly a dozen anti-Castro Cuban exiles have recently been called before a Federal grand jury here, the Government still has no solid evidence linking anyone to the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat, Justice Department sources said today.

NEWARK, April 12 Government officials today differed sharply with members of the medical profession and a spokesman for the chemical industry over what immediate steps should be taken in New Jersey to reduce the incidence of cancer, which experts estimate will strike more than 26,000 persons in the state this year.

The longest day is nothing to the longest night, which is the night one is invited to dinner at the home of friends who are dear but boring, whose other friends, save for present company, are worthwhile but long-winded, and whose idea of company food is beef liver al dente and strawberry shortcake made with aerosol whipped cream.
Joel Harnett said yesterday that he would enter the Democratic primary for Mayor of New York, but would not abide by the results if he lost in the voting in September.
MEXICO CITY, April 12 Mexico's state universities, their budgets inadequate, their classrooms crowded, are becoming the focus of a struggle between political conservatives and leftists.
PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP) The University of Pennsylvania has agreed to buy a divinity school sought by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, according to a university spokesman.
SYRACUSE, N.Y. Warren is a teacher at Syracuse University. He spends some of his time meeting students in a slightly esoteric vocational subject they have expressed interest in by enrollment.

Nearly 1,000 radio-dispatched taxi drivers, angered over airport restrictions on them, blocked roadways at La Guardia Airport for two and a half hours yesterday morning, tying up traffic for miles and inconveniencing thousands of travelers.

WHITE PLAINS, April 12 A Westchester County grand jury today cleared a white Mount Vernon policeman of any wrongdoing in the fatal shooting of a black man, but returned perjury indictments against several persons who said they had been eyewitnesses. One of those indicted was arrested.

The city held its first "garage sale" yesterday, auctioning off what the Municipal Service Administration called "choice items of memorabilia," including one fire hydrant, two barber's chairs, four dentist's chairs, 14 traffic signs, 15 traffic signal heads and 31 fire-alarm boxes.
NEWARK, April 12 The Medical Science Building became today the fifth new structure to open on the $200 million campus of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

ISLAMBAD, Pakistan, April 12 (UPI) Grenades allegedly thrown by antiGovernment demonstrators exploded today in the midst of two security patrols and injured 38 policemen in Lahore, the Government said:

ALBANY, April 12 (AP) Governor Carey wants to give the state government's management and confidential employees the same wage and fringe benefits offered to and rejected by the Civil Service Employees Association.
RUTGERS UNIVERSITY is presenting a series of faculty composer concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall this season, and the two who were featured on Monday night were Larry Ridley and Noel Da Costa.

Two gangs of youngsters, directed by adult criminals and using pre-teen-agers as lookouts, have been pillaging factories in parts of Long Island City, Queens, with such frequency that businessmen there are getting ready to leave the city.
PALO ALTO, Calif., April 12 (UPI) Hermann F. Frankel, an authority on early Greek philosophy and literature, has died in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 88 years old.
KANSAS CITY, April 12 The panic button is as close as the nearest telephone. The telephone George Steinbrenner uses often.

LONDON The fastidious old Connaught Hotel, which has lost two chefs de cuisine to Manhattan Bernard Nourget at La Folie and Daniel Dunas of the Tavern on the Green still has a gifted hand or two in the kitchen.
The old rule for salad dressing still stands. "Four persons are wanted to make a salad. A spendthrift for oil, a miser for vinegar, a counselor for salt and a madman to stir it all up."

PARIS The international implications of India's recent change of government could conceivably be almost endless. Mrs. Gandhi's Congress Party dictatorship was ousted the moment she opened the door to democracy. The subsequent Desai regime has made it plain that foreign policy will take a decisive veer.

SLICES The Big Apple, Midtown, is like this on a Wednesday at lunchtime. Take a break and your pick either a jazz session in a convenient auditorium, or a knowledgeably guided walking tour through one of the world's great railroad terminals. The diversions, both at 12:30 P.M., last about an hour. They cost nothing.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 12 A group of American Congressmen was told by President Park Chung Hee yesterday that there would be no more wining and dining at South Korean Government expense for United States legislators who visit here in the future.
TRENTON, April 12 A nonprofit, church-backed group seeking to set up today it hoped to be in operation at the Clinton Corrections Institute for Women industries in New Jersey prisons said by July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 12 The United States has decided to send $13 million worth of "nonlethal" military equipment to help Zaire resist an invasion by Katangan exiles from Angola, the State Department said today.
Bonnie, an 8-year-old sea lion who had been one of the Central Park Zoo's bestloved attractions, died yesterday afternoon in the pool she had lived in since 1971.

Most tennis fans in the New York area would be saddened to see the United States Open move from its traditional home in Forest Hills to Flushing Meadow Park, but felt that a change was necessary because of the growth of the sport.

The North American Soccer League reported yesterday a 44 percent increase in season ticket sales. Its 11th season opened over the weekend with several division contenders losing their first matches. In another development
Corporations have been quietly building up their in-house, or staff, legal departments, so much so that there is considerable demand for young lawyers with some experience.

The Boston Celtics continued their supremacy over the San Antonio Spurs last night in their opening game of a National Basketball Association two-ofthree-game playoff series. The Celtics, the defending champions, triumphed, 104-94, while four striking N.B.A. referees picketed outside Boston Garden.

IT WOULD BE HARD to imagine a more difficult role for an opera substitute to be handed than the title part in "Lulu." Berg's 12 tone idiom, while often remarkably expressive and evocative in the orchestra, puts all the voices through a wringer, but no singer is squeezed more cruelly than the soprano who is the dramatic focus of this perverse and claustrophobic work.

JERUSALEM, April 12 Foreign Minister Yigal Allon said tonight that Israel could not tolerate attacks by Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon against mainly Christian villages adjacent to Israel's northern border enclaves that the Israelis have been assisting for months.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) President Carter and Vice President Mondale are waging a fight from the White House for the equal rights amendment, which will be voted on tomorrow in the Florida Senate.
When Seattle Slew runs in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct a week from Saturday, his handlers want the undefeated 3-year-old colt to feel right at home.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)-Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland has reversed his decision to keep some big sales by private grain exporters confidential for up to a week, an aide disclosed today.

CAPE TOWN, April 12 After a threemonth lull, another major effort to get a Rhodesian settlement is under way. Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain, who is to meet Prime Minister Ian D. Smith here tomorrow, brings with him yet another new approach to the issue. But his proposals, jointly developed with the Carter Administration, appear to have only the remotest chance of bringing about a peaceful transition to majority rule.

WASHINGTON, April 12 President Carter will propose to Congress next week that American consumers pay for domestic oil at least the same high price set by an international cartel for imported oil, Congressional and Administration sources said today. A rise in the price of domestic natural gas is also to be sought, perhaps through a parity formula that would link gas prices to world oil prices.

A majority on the City Tax Commission has recommended rejection of an application for exemptions on more than $2.6 million worth of property owned by the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, according to sources close to the commission.

The United States Postal Service has wanted to build on the block bounded by 28th and 29th Streets and Ninth and Tenth Avenues for about 15 years. With the passing of time, its plans for the Site have changed and the complexities of construction planning have grown.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 12 (UPI) Vietnam said today that the biggest problem facing Saigon on the second anniversary of the city's takeove by the Communists was how to get city dwellers back to the countryside.

WASHINGTON, April 12 President Carter commuted today the 20-year prison term of G. Gordon Liddy to eight years, thus making the last of the original Watergate burglary defendants still in jail eligible for parole in July.
He seems like just an ordinary guy with an ordinary name, and if you saw him on the street, you would probably never think he was a professional athlete. Much less a National Hockey League star.

Philip K. Wrigley, the chairman of the company that sold billions of sticks of chewing gum a year and the owner of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, died yesterday in an Elkhorn, Wis., hospital. He was 82 years old and was stricken by a gastro-intestinal hemorrhage on Monday night while watching his baseball team on television.

Flora Lewis, European diplomatic correspondent and chief of the Paris bureau of The New York Times, has won an Overseas Press Club award for best daily newspaper or wire service interpretation of foreign affairs and for her ability "to see the continent as a whole, and report its shifting patterns in comprehensible terms to an American audience."

DETROIT, April 12 The General Motors Corporation today made it official: Barring unforeseen developments, the rotary engine has no place in the future plans of the world's biggest auto maker. G.M. announced that it had discontinued research and development work on the rotary, or Wankel, engine, that began seven years ago.
Old-crop soybean and meal futures prices soared by their daily permissible limits yesterday to close at their highest levels since mid-August 1973. Bean oil closed a touch below its upward limit.

THE MAIN TROUBLE with fluorescent lights is that nobody well, virtually nobody can love them. One of the most magical and romantic moments in any 24-hour stretch is when the lamps come on but lamps with ordinary incandescent bulbs.

TRENTON, April 12 (AP) New Jersey's Department of Transportation and the Consolidated Rail Corporation have agreed to settle a contract dispute, ending a threat by Conrail to terminate rail commuter service, a state transportation official said today.

It was Victims' Day in Times Square yesterday, the day when neighborhood residents who suffer from th so-called "victimless crimes" of prostitution and pornography got a chance to tell their stories and vent their anger.

The Internal Revenue Service has proposed that the Rockwell International Corporation pay an additional $8.6 million in Federal income taxes for fiscal 1969. Rockwell is contesting the I.R.S. proposal in the United States Tax Court.

Thanks to food technologists, it's no longer true that to make an omelet you have to break eggs. Excepting only poached or fried eggs, it is now possible for restaurant cooks to serve eggs in any form without having any on the premises in a natural, fragile and perishable state.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third largest aluminum producer, reported yesterday an 88.2 percent rise in first-quarter net earnings on a 25.2 percent sales gains.

Three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor agreed yesterday that the worst of the fiscal crisis was still ahead fo New York City.

McAFEE, N.J., April 12 The top spot in the American Bridge Association's master-point standings changed hands here this afternoon when Bob Price of Chicago led his team to victory in their semifinal of the knockout team championship.
United States Open tennis officials have decided not to recognize the sexchromosone test that Dr. Renee Richards said she passed last week in Little Rock, Ark.
NASHVILLE, April 12 (AP) The Tennessee legislature overrode Gov. Ray Blanton's veto last night, thereby enacting a state death penalty law.

MADRID, April 12 At least one of the four military men in the Spanish Cabinet was reported tonight to have announced his decision to resign in protest against the decision last Saturday to legalize the Communist Party.

Marian S. Heiskell, director of special activities of The New York Times Company, was awarded the Woman of the Year award of the New York chapter of the Achievement Rewards for College Scientists Foundation Inc., at a benefit luncheon yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.
NEW DELHI, April 12 Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi formally accepted the blame today for her party's defeat in last month's parliamentary elections.

Ara Zerounian was working as a substitute, teaching mathematics to seventh-graders in Detroit, on the day recently when he learned that he had been chosen 1977's music teacher of the year by the American String Teachers Association.

But even though things have changed, when it comes to pillows, it really isn't too difficult to keep your head on straight.

MARBELLA, Spain After a half century of banishment, gambling has been legalized in Spain. When the roulette wheels start turning and the dice begin to tumble, one of the main beneficiaries could be the fabled Costa del Sol, which is just recovering from a five-year tourist slump.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April l2 Friends of Milovan Djilas, Yugoslavia's leading dissident, said today that the Government of President Tito was apparently preparing a new campaign against the critic.

WASHINGTON, April 11-For the first time in modern political history, a President has undertaken a personal campaign to eliminate the historic state-oriented electoral vote system that officially put him in the White House and substitute a national plurality of the popular vote.

QUEBEC, April 12 Quebec, a frequent bidder for funds in New York and other financial markets in recent years, will be seen much less this year under the $11.5 billion budget unveiled tonight by the new government, which seeks to make this largely French-speaking province independent.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) A consumer group has asked the Government to investigate more than two dozen alleged defects in cars imported from Britain. The organization said the defects warrant recalling the cars.

PARIS, April 12 (UPI) Bombs damaged the France-U.S.S.R. Friendship Association and a Soviet bookstore in Paris today, less than 24 hours after Moscow protested earlier attacks on Soviet offices in France.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 12 (Reuters) Ethiopia's military rulers have charged that invading Sudanese troops are locked in battle with defense forces deep inside Ethiopian territory, informed sources reported today.

The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that its members would strike seven major ship lines at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow in a dispute over contract demands and the handling of containerized shipments.

The Detroit Tigers have traded Willie Horton, their 33-year-old former All-Star left fielder, to the Texas Rangers. Details of the deal were held up since Horton, with more than 10 years in the major leagues and five years with the same club, had the power to nullify the agreement. But Horton said yesterday that he wouldn't veto the deal.

ARLINGTON, Va., April 12 Just before Christmas last year, several Korean children living here made little gifts for their school teachers, in the custom of their homeland. BOSTON, April 12 The huge, 503-footlong Soviet refrigerator ship Antanas Snechkus, which was brought here today with her cargo of illegal fish under seizure, is a symbol of the size and technology of the big foreign fleets that have swept the fish from the seas off New England, leading to the imposition of the new 200-mile fishing zone.
The biggest crowd in the history of Milwaukee's County Stadium, 55,120, primed by the Brewers' two victories in Yankee Stadium, wound up cheering an opposing pitcher yesterday.

John Chamberlain McClintock, a specialist in Latin American economic affairs and a principal economic adviser to Nelson A. Rockefeller when he was Assistant Secretary of Sate in the mid-1940's, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 67 years old.

HONG KONG, April 12 The Chinese leadership has circulated a dossier of purported evidence against four purged left ist members of the party's Politburo, including charges that Chiang Ching betrayed fellow Communists to the Nationalists in the 1930's and Chang Chun-chiao had been a Nationalist secret agent.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 New chiefs of security have been appointed here in a shuffle of some of the main posts in the country's civil service as a means of strengthening President Elias Sarkis's hold on the country.

DETROIT, April 12 Defense arguments that two Filipino nurses did not poison patients at the Ann Arbor, Mich., Veterans Hospital two summers ago were bolstered today when Federal Judge Philip Pratt refused to admit into evidence two intravenous bags the Government says had been used for two of the victims.

For the fifth play of the Phoenix Theater's season at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, which opened last night, we had death, Vietnam style. It was "G.R. Point," a new play by David Berry.

A fundamental dispute over government regulation of new technology that may have cancer risks and involving tests of plastic bottles, is leaving one purveyor of soft drinks, Pepsico Inc., sitting pretty, and another, the CocaCola Company, with a problem.

NORTH ARLINGTON, April 12 Amid the growl of garbage trucks in low gear and derisive shouts from demonstrators nearby, Governor Byrne led state, county and local officials today in a groundbreaking ceremony for construction of New Jersey's first, and the nation's largest, refuse baling system 10 miles southwest of Giants Stadium in the Hacken sack Meadowlands.

WASHINGTON, April 12 About this time of year, at the changing of the seasons, you can look west in the evening from the Potomac and see the struggle of nature over the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia: Spring trying to banish a savage winter; spectacular sunsets clear and pink light streaming through the vast gray clouds.

KATE AND ANNA McGarrigle's first formal New York performances Monday and last night at the Bottom Line con firmed their status as the most charming and original songwriters and singers in a folk idiom to emerge in many years. WASHINGTON, April 12-The bustling activity at the new National Air and Space Museum, whose 10 acres of satellites and planes have become the most popular tourist aftraction in town, contrasts sharply with the almost melancholy atmosphere at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration across the street on Independence Avenue.

THIS SEASON a number of prominent directors Arthur Penn, Mike Nichols, Frank Perry and Ulu Grosbard have gone from Hollywood to Broadway. What brought them back to the legitimate theater are new plays.
LONDON, April 12 (AP) Ray Gunter, a former Labor Cabinet minister, was found dead today in his retirement cottage at St. Mary's in the Scilly Isles, the police said. He was 67.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP) A hearing on a plan to integrate city schools next fall has been halted by a judge who said that his research had shown that similar plans in other cities had been ruled unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, April 12 Following a two-year legal battle, the Food and Drug Administration will begin Friday requiring the nation's cosmetics manufacturers to list the ingredients of their beauty and cleansing products.

BUENOS AIRES, April 12 (AP) Troops took over 23 of the capital's major fruit and vegetable distribution centers during the night in what Government officials said was a new step in the fight against inflation, which last year was 347.5 percent. No violence or arrests were reported.

The Rev: Dr. George Augustus Trowbridge, who headed large Episcopal congregations here and in Philadelphia, during almost half a century of clerical service, died monday at his home at 333 East 68th Street. He was 79 years old.

Two subway riders were slightly injured during the evening rush period yesterday when a subway car of the BMT "N" line deralled between the Manhattan Bridge and the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn, transit officials reported.

MANILA, April 12 (UP) President Ferdinand F. Marcos today said Moslem rebel leaders in agreeing to end their four-year rebellion in the southern Philippines, had expressed willingness to participate in a provisional government.

GENEVA, April 9 Bent Larsen of Denmark, squeezing out a victory in his adjourned queen-and-rook ending with Werner Hug of Switzerland, took the lead after 12 rounds of the Geneva International Tournament here in the Hotel la Mediterranee. Larsen's 8 points put him a half-point ahead of Ulf Andersson of Sweden.

Remember the good old days, when cops used to find lost children? Well, if a correspondent from Richmond Hill is correct, any day now a child is likely to find a lost cop. Yes, it seems that the men in blue are beginning to join the cabbies who manage to misplace the city.

LANSING, Mich., April 12 Andrew Young carried the Carter Administration's campaign for a more open government to this state capital today, pledging that at the risk of incurring attack on himself he would continue to speak his mind before foreign policy decisions were made "which can cost the taxpayer money and lose precious American lives."

Spinach, red-veined beet tops and tart sorrel, as well as mild-flavored nasturtium leaves if any grow in your garden, are all legitimate candidates for the mixed salad and add iron and other valuable minerals.

The New York City Transit Authority has not achieved enough savings through increased productivity to pay for wage increases already given to its workers, according to Sidney Schwartz, the special deputy state comptroller.
The deaths last weekend of three disabled war veterans who lived at a foster home in Yonkers were tentatively attributed yesterday to pneumonia, apparently caused by a flu-like virus.

It was Victims' Day in Times Square yesterday, the day when neighborhood residents who suffer from the so-called "victimless crimes" of prostitution and pornography got a chance to tell their stories and vent their anger.
"I got to the point where I can say that I really know this market better than anyone on the face of the earth," said James B. Bradbeer, adding, "mostly because nobody else cares."

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve System, warned last night that failure to adopt new rules for the world financial system would risk making it "especially vulnerable" to another recession.
MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., April 12 (AP) Beverly Klass of Tarzana, Cailf., won the Ladies International satellite golf tournament today by shooting a two-day total of 150 in the 36-hole, $5,000 event.
The International Paper Company said yesterday that first-quarter earnings fell 24 percent from last year's comparable quarter.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) The dollar dropped on all major European money markets today, hitting a three-month low against the West German mark in the first day of trading since the Easter holiday. Gold bullion prices rose by more than $l an ounce over Thursday's close.

JERUSALEM, April 12 Israel's new Labor Party candidate for Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, has been attempting to divest himself of the label "hawkish" one he regards as a misnomer and one that has been troubling officials in foreign capitals interested in Arab-Israeli peace talks.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) The Federal Reserve Board adopted regulations today requiring member banks to notify customers that interest costs may rise under variable-rate mortgages.

After the coldest winter in 41 years, six months of vertiginous ups and downs that even the circumspect National Weather Sevice will concede were "quirky," and a weekend so unseasonable that the Indians-Red Sox baseball game was canceled Saturday because of cold, New Yorkers faced the earliest 90-degree day in weather records yesterday with neither shock, amazement, nor surprise.

Directors of the Richmond Corporation decided yesterday, by a vote of 6 to 5, to merge with the Continental Group Inc. in a new cash and securities deal valued by Wall Street analysts at roughly $27 a share or about $356 million.
Nearly 5,000 opponents to the landing of the Concorde at Kennedy International Airport crowded inside two high schools in Queens and Nassau County in separate rallies last night.

The International Longshoremen's Association said yesterday that its members would strike seven major ship lines at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow in a dispute over contract demands and the handling of containerized shipments.

JOSEPH PAPP is planning a massive $6.5 million renovation of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. Yesterday, Mr. Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, presented his plan to the board of directors of Lincoln Center Inc., which has to approve before the reconstruction can take place.

THE USUAL GRUMBLING was heard but not in the publishing houses of the prize winners ` about the National Book Awards that were announced Monday and will be formally conferred early this evening by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

Aluminum shipments in January fell 1.7 percent from the year-ago level, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday. The trade association placed January shipments of ingot and mill products at 905,644 pounds against 921,392 a year earlier.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 12 (AP) A judge ordered striking teachers and Kansas City's school board back to the bargaining table today in an attempt to end a three-week-old walkout.
ASHKHABAD, U.S.S.R. A bright ribbon of water, milky green in the spring sunshine, slices incongruously through the desert sands, pumping prosperity into the southern reaches of the Kara-Kum.
MADRID, April 13 The Spanish Government is studying with concern the implications for its own program of President Carter's new restrictive nuclear policy.

KANSAS CITY, April 13 Manager Billy Martin devised his third batting order in the season's fifth game tonight, but it was the three players who have remained in fixed spots who produced the Yankees' 5-3 victory over Kansas City.
The architecture and restoration of old houses in New Jersey will be the subject of an all-day "preservation conference" April 23 in Princeton.

WASHINGTON, April 13 An advisory group to the Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to recommend to the commission that it move quickly to eliminate or simplify many of the documents it requires from public corporations.

BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) The Department of Justice has opposed the nocontest pleas of five independent oil companies and their trade association to charges that they considered to rig the prices of gasoline.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Abdul Aziz, a spokesman for 12 Hanafi Moslems when they held 134 people hostage last month, pleaded not guilty today to seven counts of violation of firearm laws.

DETROIT, April 13 The General Motors Corporation, expressing belief that sales of small cars would soon turn upward, announced today that it planned to increase production of the Chevette, Chevrolet's minicar, by more than 50 percent on June 27.
Negotiators for 67 private nursing homes and their employees met all day yesterday without apparent progress in an attempt to reach a settlement and avert a strike threatened for 6 A.M, tomorrow.

TWO TRADITIONAL Chinese marble lions stand at the entry to a section of Bonwit Teller's seventh floor. Behind them are gleaming vases, some over four feet high, carved from black or dark red solid lacquer and brilliantly decorated with flowers and birds, or subtly painted with red or orange dragons.

Mayor Beanie's budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1 wilt include cuts of 5 to 10 percent $40 million to $80 million in the commercial rent tax and tehe general corporation tax, budget officials said yesterday.

THE trouble must have started when I first heard the saying "Woman's Work Is Never Done." Maybe I saw it cross-stitched on a sampler, with sweetheart roses couchant, or carved in a knotty pine "decorative accessory." Anyway it had a ring of ancient truth about it like the one around the collar or the tub.

Otis Simmons, the 58-year-old derelict who won a legal battle last winter to stop doctors at Roosevelt Hospital from amputating his frostbitten, gangrenous feet, was back on the streets of midtown Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The Food and Drug Administration plans to announce tomorrow that it will continue to permit bulk sales of saccharin in tablet or powder form but will stand by its proposal to ban the use of the artificial sweetener in prepared foods and beverages.

Mayor Beame promised yesterday to "beef up" police protection for a Long Island City sector in Queens where plants have been pillaged so frequently by youth gangs that business leaders said they were planning to move from the city.
Clarence M. Woodbury, a free-lance magazine writer, died Tuesday at the Northport, N.Y., Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 78 years old and a resident of Centerport, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, April 13 President Carter has decided to withdraw his request to Congress for a $50 rebate for most American taxpayers, sources in the Administration said tonight.

Bond prices rose yesterday, continuing a trend that got under way late Tuesday when the Treasury disclosed it would pay off in cash some $6.5 billion of short-term securities that come due next week. The
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, entangled in legal disputes over its uranium supply contracts, reported yesterday a first-quarter profit increase of 12.7 percent.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 13 (Reuters) An Air France Concorde with 71 passengers aboard landed here today with one engine not working, an airport spokesman said.
The casts of 25 Broadway shows, many of them wearing stage makeup and costumes, yesterday led their matinee audiences in a march down Broadway to an antipornography rally at 1 Times Square.

WASHINGTON, April 13 In the presence of a reporter for Time magazine last week, Jimmy Carter displayed his irritation with Secretary of State Cy Vance. Speaking about policy toward certain African countries, the President complained to Vice President Mondale: "We're just sitting around," and added ominously, "I've told Cy that before."
Mario M. Cuomo will run for the Democratic mayoral nomination with the behind-the-scenes encouragement of Governor Carey, high state sources reported yesterday.

JERUSALEM, April 13 Pressure is increasing here for the immediate revision of an Israeli law that has barred until the elections May 17 the resignation of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin because he is presiding over a caretaker administration.
A second day of record high temperatures left many New Yorkers wilted in apartments and offices in which airconditioning had yet to be turned on.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Despite highlevel contacts and optimistic-sounding comments since the unsuccessful talks in Moscow last month, the Soviet Union and the United States remain deadlocked in an effort to renew serious negotiations on strategic arms.
WASHINGTON, April 13 Conflicting plans by two Department of Transportation agencies threaten confusion in the modernization of the rail system in the New York City area, according to officials here.

DETROIT, April 13 Speculation mounted here today that Henry Ford 2d would announce his successor as chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company when the company board of direc- tors holds its regular monthly meeting tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) California industries received $3.2 billion in prime defense contract awards in the last three months of 1976, the highest total of any state, a Pentagon report showed today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The State Department said today that the United States was seeking, through intense diplomatic activity, to stabilize the situation along the Israeli-Lebanese border so that southern Lebanon could be brought under the effective authority of the Government of President Elias Sarkis.
Things are not as they should be in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) Baseball games have been canceled for one reason or another for years but yesterday's University of Maryland-Georgetown University scheduled contest here may have set some kind of a first. Coach Jack Jackson of Maryland refused to field his team when he couldn't find a free parking spot on the Hoyas' campus.

Each of Paul Tabou's six wives excels at beadwork and helps the Cameroon carver to execute the stunning coverings for his anthropomorphic thrones.

FORT WORTH, April 13 A call allegedly made by a juror in which she told an employer she was ready to issue a verdict caused a State District Court judge here today to order a mistrial in the murder trial of T. Cullen Davis, a Fort Worth millionaire.

TRENTON, April 13 The New Jersey State Commission of Investigation recommended today a number of stringent regulations for casino gambling in Atlantic City, including a prohibition on credit and restrictions on hours, that it said were necessary to prevent the infiltration of organized crime.

ROCHESTER, April 13 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said tonight that the Carter Administration was prepared to revamp its strategic arms proposals to the Soviet Union but would block any attempt by Moscow "to bully us" to sign an acord to control nuclear weapons.

BAYONNE, April 13 (UPI) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Representative Joseph A. LeFante and Hudson County officials called on the Navy Department to reconsider its proposal to move 500 jobs from the Navy International Logistics Office here.

ALBANY, April 13 Governor Carey said today that there was still room for bargaining to avert a strike called for Monday against the state by its largest public employees union, and he urged the employees not to walk off their jobs while negotiations were continuing.
UNIONDALE, L.I., April 13 (AP) The New York Nets have acquired a center-forward, Darnell Hillman, from the Indiana Pacers to complete a midseason deal for a guard John Williamson.

WASHINGTON One of the 28,000 letters that has arrived at the White House energy office in the last five weeks hears this salutation: "To Whom Energy May Concern." And one conclusion the happy energy staff has drawn from the write-in is that a lot of ordinary Americans are themselves very concerned.

KINSHASA, Zaire, April 13 Moroccan troops are reported taking positions around the southern copper-mining center of Kolwezi in apparent preparation for an offensive against Katangan invaders from Angola.

EIGHTEEN SONGS by five composers and an exended work combining song and speach by yet another composer were giv- en first performances by five singers and a pianist in the "Hear America First" Concert in the chapel of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church on Tuesday night.

Protestors demonstrating against the shutdown of certain subway entrances during off-peak hours yesterday forced an early adjournment of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's monthly meeting by shouting down the members of the authority.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, April 13 (Reuters) Three flight controllers, alleged with five others to have caused the world's worst midair collision, today disputed statements by the main accused man that he was overloaded with work at the time. The collision, between a British Airways Trident and a Yugoslav DC-9 on Sept. 10, caused the deaths'of 176 people. There were no survivors.
