BONN, April 13 West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, speaking at a state funeral in Karlsruhe for the assassinated federal prosecutor, called upon his countrymen today not to overreact to terrorist acts.
A settlement in the long-contested multimillion-dollar estate of J.J. Shubert, a founder of a nationwide theater and real-estate empire, was announced yesterday.

The International Business Machines Corporation's disappointing first-quarter earnings report caught Wall Street by surprise yesterday. And the Street reacted to the bad news in its customary manner-a sharp drop in the price of the shares.

WASHINGTON, April 13 Confirming what has long been apparent, the Census Bureau reported today that nearly all the central cites of the Northeast and Middle West lost population in the first half of this decade.

GUILDERLAND, N.Y., April 13 Bereft of the guidance of Nelson A. Rockefeller for the first time in almost two decades, New York Republicans filled the state's male slot on the National Committee today, then squabbled long but decorously over a female counterpart.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The number of passengers with confirmed reservations who were "bumped" from airline flights last year totaled 146,618, an increase of more than 15,000 over the 1975 figure, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced today.

Scientists at Michigan State University have found a way to increase the growth of many kinds of food plants by 10 to 40 percent by treating the soil or the plant with trace amounts of a highly potent substance isolated from alfalfa hay.

ALBANY, April 13 Governor Carey as expected, announced today the appointment of Muriel F. Siebert, a securities analyst and the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange, as New York State Superintendent of Banks.
HONOLULU, April 13 (UPI) Robert Sidney Bowen, a World War I air ace and former newspaperman and author, died of cancer here Monday. He was 76 years old.

A State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan yesterday convicted Joe Costello of promoting prostitution at a "rap studio" called the Intimate Room, at 701 Seventh Avenue. Mr. Costello, who is 36 years old, was arrested last June in one of several raids on midtown "massage parlors" conducted by the Manhattan District Attorney.
The City Tax Commission in a 4-to-3 vote formally denied tax exemptions yesterday for three pieces of property, valued at $2.6 million, owned by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.

Columbia University has been discussing with Henry Kissinger the possibility of his joining its faculty, probably to occupy a well-endowed chair. Dr. Kissinger is no novice in Academe, having been a professor of government at Harvard for a decade before moving to Washington in 1969. Since then, he has busied himself with other matters around the globe; by ordinary criteria he would be an adornment to any university.

The body of Capt. James B. Cosgrave, a Vietnam War veteran killed April 1 when his B-52 bomber crashed while trying to land in a storm at K.I. Sawyer Air Force Base, Mich., arrived in New York yesterday. He lived at 147-20 Tenth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens. He was 31 years old.
LAS VEGAS, April 13 Sheriff Ralph Lamb of Clark County, considered one of the most powerful men in Nevada, was indicted today on three counts of Federal income tax evasion.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) Ralph Hallenstein, day news editor of The Chicago Tribune, died last night in his home in suburban Wheaton. He was 56 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 13 While thousands of workers staged protest marches and sitdowns around the country, a delegation of labor leaders called on President Carter today to ask that he restrict clothing and textile imports to save American jobs.

J. P. Morgan Company, the first major money-market bank to report firstquarter earnings, posted a 10.4 percent gain in operating earnings to $49.5 million from $44.9 million in the 1976 quarter. EZRA TAFT BENSON, the Secretary of Agriculture under President Eisenhower, has told students at the Mormons' Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, that it would be unethical of them to accept food stamps to help them through lean college years. "You did not come to this university to become a welfare recipient or freeloader," Mr. Benson said. "When you accept food stamps, you accept an unearned handout that other people are paying for."

For over a century the hapless Giselle has been the perpetual victim in the ballet of the same name, but she startingly turned the tables Tuesday evening and won. What she Was never able to achieve at the Paris Opera Ballet, starting in 1841, she managed at the Palace Theater with the choreographic assistance of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo on travestie. It was a triumph of special sensibilities over sense.

The buoyant optimism in some quarters a few years ago that the cure for cancer might be just around some corner has largely vanished. WASHINGTON, April 18 President Carter warned tonight that the United States faced a possible "national catastrophe" unless it responded with the "moral equivalent of war" to dwindling energy supplies by accepting a program based on stringent conservation of fuels, higher energy prices and penalties for waste.

Good evening. Tonight I want to have an unpleasant talk with you about a problem unprecedented in our history. With the exception of preventing war, this is the greatest challenge that our country will face during our lifetimes. The energy crisis has not yet overwhelmed us, but it will if we do not act quickly.

ANDREA DARRIAU'S skill as a mime is little in question when she chooses to show it, but there is some doubt as to whether she has fully formed suitable vehicles for that skill. The company of 105 singers, dancers, musicians and actors all Soviet Jewish emigrants now living in Israel is making its second annual United States tour. There are two local performances, tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall and Saturday at 9 at Carnegie Hall. General admission is $5.50 to $12.50.

IT IS 30 years since the late Jose Limon formed his company a company that was to make international dance history. Now at The Roundabout Theater, the company bereft of its master, but still imbued with his spirit is giving an anniversary season, which opened last night.

ALBANY, April 19 A bill that would require the annual licensing and inspection of so-called "Medicaid mills" passed the New York State Assembly overwhelmingly today. Its sponsor predicted it could save more than $50 million a year by reducing fraud and abuse in the Medicaid program.

WASHINGTON, April 19 House and Senate conferees agreed today on all the details of a $4 billion public works jobs bill except the critical one: how to vote it out and get it passed.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, April 19 (AP) Foreign Minister Mauricio Borgonovo Pohl was kidnaped today by a leftist group that threatened to kill him unless the Government freed 36 political prisoners, sources said.

ANY OFFENBACH operetta is fun, and there was a big turnout Wednesday night at the Fashion Institute Theater, where the Village Light Opera Group's new production of "La Vie Parisienne" is being given. Everybody came expecting a good time, and nobody was disappointed. Nobody ever is when Offenbach receives a bubbling performance. And it did on this occasion.

It is becoming old hat. For the second straight day, the Yankees, with their new "lineup-out-of-ahat" look, scored their most runs in a game this season and defeated the Toronto Blue Jay's, 8-6, yesterday at the Stadium.

YAPHANK, L.I., April 21 Dust was being raised in huge quantities today at Parr Meadows. Motor graders spread sand and clay on the track's surface. Bulldozers shoved soil about the parking lots. A crane chugged down the backstretch, getting ready to install a video patrol tower at the far turn.

Red Norvo, the jazz vibraharpist, led a notable big band in the 1930's with Mildred Bailey, who was his wife at the time, as his singer. Later, in the 50's, he had a notable trio, with Tal Farlow on guitar and Charles Mingus on bass. But now he travels footloose with only his vibraharp and an assortment of mallets in what he says is a different musical world.

It was the simplicity of Wendy Perron's concert that contributed so strongly to its immediate appeal. She offered two pieces Wednesday evening at the Merce Cunningham Studio that used straightforward jumps, slides and turns that had an innocent athletic joy.

Strollers along Fifth Avenue in the past week have noticed the same motif in the windows of banks, book stores and airline offices as in fashion shops. Piles of pasta, mock-ups of the leaning tower of Pisa and bits of red, white and green ribbon sometimes the Italian flag have turned up from 34th to 58th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 21 As Rosalynn Carter stepped off a chartered bus in Chicago, a medical student was waving a picket sign: "Mrs. Carter, we will improve mental health care if we ever get the chance."
THT JOSE LIMON Danceo Company took the unusual step Wednesday night at the Roundabout Theater of giving the company premiere of an international classic.

Donald R. Young, a sociologist and a former director of the Russell Sage Foundation, died last Sunday at the Sacred Heart Hospital in Allentown, Pa. He was 78 years old and lived in Macungie, Pa., where he was born.

AT 6:30 in the morning of the day after the news came by telephone this week informing him that he had won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry, James Merrill went to work as usual at home in Stonington, Conn., writing a poem.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the only black member of the New York State Board of Regents, charged yesterday that other board members were overwhelmingly hostile to integration and responsible for the failure to integrate Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, Queens. The high school's student body is 99 percent black.
ADRIAN, Mich., April 21 (UPI) President Carter exaggerated the sacrifices that Americans will be asked to make in the name of energy conservation, Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 21 (AP) A New Jersey Supreme Court justice today blocked an abortion planned by a teenaged college student whose male friend argued it would violate his right to future fatherhood.

Many economic and energy experts, expressed concern yesterday that President Carter may have been too optimistic in setting his goals for 1985 a 10 percent reduction in gasoline use, together with a cut in the annual growth of energy consumption to 2 percent or less a year from 4.6 percent.

The neighbors complained, so the Federal Government has ordered Billy Carter to clean up the debris around his Plains, Ga., service station to meet health and safety requirements. In Washington, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the Labor Department said yesterday that the President's younger brother had been cited for violations on housekeeping and safety.

Twin gynecologists who died nearly two years ago as a result of drug addiction performed or tried to perform surgery when their hands were shaking and they could barely stand up, a New York Assembly committee was told yesterday.
PARIS, April 21 France and several other major industrial nations have already established energy conservation programs similar to that proposed by President Carter for the United States.

EL PASO, April 21 For Hector Sena, light is the worst enemy. Mr. Sena has remarkable eyes and he shields them, turning his head from the sudden glare of a flashlight, a cigarette lighter or an oncoming automobile. It would take only a second to lose the night vision acquired over several hours, and in Mr. Sena's job as a United States border patrol officer, night vision is almost everything.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 21 (UPI) Pledging his father's total support for the Games, Chip Carter broke the first ground today for the 1980 Winter Olympics in this Adirondack Mountain village. Carter, at the controls of a backhoe, ripped up a large chunk of sod on the site of a speed-skating rink for the Games.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 21 The list of President Park Chung Hee's political opponents seized in a nationwide crackdown continued to grow today amid indications that the Government was seeking evidence to build a court case of a Communist conspiracy.

ALBANY, April 21 New York State and its largest public-employees union were at odds today over what they had agreed to last weekend in contract negotiations that yielded a 14 percent raise over two years for union members and averted a strike Monday morning.
Selling pressure hit the stock market yesterday as numerous big-name issues-including I.B.M., Eastern Kodak and Sears, Roebuck-traded at their lowest prices of 1977.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The following table shows the range of taxes and rebates on the purchase of new automobiles, as proposed last night by President Carter in his energy message to Congress.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 1,269,128 shares in the month ended April 15 to 28,044,247 shares. The short interest for the year-earlier level totaled 34,728,133 shares.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The House ethics committee, prompted by the scandal over gifts from a South Korean businessman, agreed today that Congressmen who accepted such cash or gifts could be punished even if no criminal act was involved.

Just about four years ago Andrea McArdle got her start in show business little did she think, a third of a lifetime ago, that she would soon be a star, the 13-year-old playing the 11year-old title role of the new musical, "Annie."

WASHINGTON, April 21 Terence A. Todman, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, will probably fly to Havana soon to resume negotiations with Cuban officials on fishing regulations and maritime rights, Administration officials said today.

"Maui," a new work by Frank Gillette that uses four channels of video and nine panels of photographs to depict life on the Hawaiian island of Maui, goes on view today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street.

NEW ORLEANS, April 21 (UPI) Craig Stadler, a former United States Amateur champion, birdied four of the first six holes today, then let wind and rain take care of his competitors as he led the field by two-strokes in the rain-shortened first round of the $175,000 New Orleans open.

"I survive, I'm still alive and I protect my life," said Zygmunt Soroka as he accepted a Courageous Citizens Award plaque from the Federation of Greater New York Rifle end Pistol Clubs for "successfully defending himself," in the words of its president, Gerald Preiser.
"It's been difficulty at times it's been dreadful," says Jim Jackson, the track coach at Boys and Girls High in Brook lyn, on his hard struggle to keep on teaching so he can keep on coaching.

Utility companies in the New York metropolitan area said yesterday that home-insulation programs and other energy-saving measures proposed by President Carter were already in effect and that more would be instituted.

Twenty-two agencies, including Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Associations and community and elderly people's centers, ceased operations yesterday because of a union dispute involving 450 employees.

WASHINGTON, April 21 From oilstate senators to representatives from suburban commuter districts, critics in Congress of President Carter's energy program took their themes from their constituencies today, even if occasionally they framed them in terms of broader concepts.

WASHINGTON, April 21 The Supreme Court was reported today to have voted 5 to 3 last Friday to refuse to review the convictions of John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman in the Watergate cover-up case.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif. April 21 (Reuters)-Gummo Mark, an original member of the Marx brothers' comedy team, died here today. He was 84 years old.
ROSS, Calif., April 21 (UPI) A 20-year old follower of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has brought kidnapping charges against her parents.

THE FIRST THING to be said about the Kenneth Noland exhibition at the Guggenheim (Museum through June 19) is that it must be seen. Mr. Noland is one of the artists who have decisively shaped American painting or at least some very important elements of it over the last 20 years. The fate of abstract art in America in the 1960's and 70's can scarcely be understood without some knowledge of his work.
First, no one asked me. After that unimportant fact come the important reasons why I do not choose to run.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 21 Thailand's ruling military junta today executed a senior army general accused of plotting an unsuccessful coup and ordered four other military men imprisoned for life.
DETROIT, April 21 The American Motors Corporation said today it planned to partly shut down some of its small-car assembly production for a week beginning Monday, making 3,850 workers idle.

Mayor Beame joined with Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens yesterday to push for passage of a compromise zoning measure that would limipornography to Manhattan, two tiny areas of Queens, two slightly larger areas on Staten Island and one site in the Bronx.

DETROIT, April 21 Thomas A. Murphy's tone was softer this time, and he ringingly endorsed President Carter's general energy initiative. But one important part of the message delivered today by the chairman of the General Motors Corporation was essentially the same as it had been in recent days: The President's proposed tax on cars that waste fuel is chancy, unnecessary and could backfire.

LOS ANGELES, April 21 (AP) Bryan Foy, one of vaudeville's "Seven Little Foys" and producer of dozens of films, including the first all-talkie movie and the 3-D thriller "House of Wax," died yesterday of heart failure at U.C.L.A. Medical Center at the age of 80.

Sadie Hertz, who is 76 years old and lives in a middle-class Bronx neighborhood, said that if she had bumped into Andre Ronon, 17, a Dwitt Clinton High School student, on the street a few weeks ago, she would have thought it was a purse-snatching.

The cashew nut industry in the United States has a delivery or, more accurately, a lack-of-delivery problem with roots that stretch to India and Tanzania. Even the Soviet Union may be involved in the cashew affair or so say importers and brokers who are bracing for potential losses of up to $7 million.

TEANECK, April 21 A six-week-old policy to restrict extracurricular school activities on the Christian and Jewish Sabbaths was replaced today by a scheduling policy calling for "maximum sensitivity for all students" without reference to the Sabbath.

Brazilian Hotmosphere, a nine-piece band led by the percussionist Dom Um Romao, perforced a refreshing mixture of traditional Brazilian music and jazz at Environ on Wednesday and yesterday. Unlike many contemporary Brazilian-oriented groups, Brazilian Hotmosphere does not waterdown its percussion rhythms with rock. And the band's jazz is equally unencumbered by rock stylings.

TOKYO Two developments have attracted our attention. One is a recent press conference given by President Carter in which he reaffirmed his plan to withdraw troops and nuclear weapons from South Korea. Another is the confirmation of his Government's willingness to approach the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

IT WAS REVEILLE at West Point on July 4 last year, and one of the participants, Lieut. Col. John H. Bradley, director of Bicentennial activities at the United States Military Academy, was preoccupied. He had noticed that a flag was already flying over Fort Putnam, a redoubt high above the Plains.

DAKAR, Senegal, April 21 (UPI) The French airlift of Moroccan troops to help the Zairian Government fight invading rebels has drawn strong support from African nations concerned about foreign interference on the continent.

ALBANY, April 21 Animal shelters throughout the state would no longer be required to turn over dogs, cats and other animals to medical facilities for experimentation, under a bill that passed the State Assembly by a large margin today.
WASHINGTON, April 21 A vote in the Senate today virtually assured business of getting some form of tax break in the economic stimulus package, despite a shift in President Carter's tactics.

In March, for the second consecutive month, six of New York City's department stores had sales gains exceeding the average for the metropolitan area. The new strength of retail business in the city, compared to area results, represents a dramatic change from the years in which suburban-store volume showed rises well above those of stores in the city.

The drop in the birth rate over the past twenty years has brought the number of "adoptable" children almost to the vanishing point. But there are still tens of thousands of children in need of the love and care that adoptive parents can provide. The problem is that they are not "adoptable" by the old standards established by social agencies.

ATLANTA, April 22 At a New York cocktail party not long ago, the trendy hostess the kind who has tennis elbow, brushes her teeth with Dr. Bronner's Almond Soap and casts the I Ching on gray days served her guests a big bowl of raw peanuts as counterpoint to the dry Gibsons and Tequila Sunrises.
WASHINGTON, April 22 President Carter said today that his Administration had observed "some stabilizing" of the military situation in southern Zaire.

More than 200 years after Crispus Attucks died in the Boston Massacre and more than 100 years after the Abolitionist activism of Sojourner Truth, the black population of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans will double today to a total of two.

WASHINGTON, April 22 President Carter said today that he might veto revamped tax legislation, aimed at stimulating the economy, following the Senate's rejection of his request to scrap business tax credits along with the $50 tax rebate that was to be the centerpiece of the program.

CLOSE HARMONY The musicand-mingle series "Concert Party at the Barbizon," has been drawing enthusiastic responses Saturdays in the Recital Room mezzanine of the Barbizon Hotel, 63d Street and Lexington Avenue. These get-together evenings, specially planned for music-loving singles, feature preview tryouts of classical programs by reputable artists prior to regular public concerts, with a social session and complimentary wine during intermission. Performances begin at 8:30 P.M.

Fears of a possible credit-tightening move by the Federal Reserve Board and continued weakness in big-name glamour issues pushed the stock market sharply lower yesterday across a broad front. With only the precious-metal group showing firmness, 1,098 issues on the New York Stock Exchange finished the disheartening session lower.

Declaring that New York City is "beginning the long climb back," Mayor Beame yesterday submitted a $13.9 billion expense budget for the year beginning July 1, with a glittering array of election-year bonuses, including modest tax cuts, personnel increases and construction projects scattered through the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) Andrew Young the United States delegate to the United Nations, explained his unorthodox style to some retired diplomats today, saying that he is a rebellious "child of Korea and Vietnam" and a southern black who could not vote until 1965.

One of the nation's most respected black writers filed a copyright infringement suit against Alex Haley yesterday, charging that unspecified portions of his acclaimed book "Roots" had been largely copied from her novel on black life in Georgia in the Civil War era.

WASHINGTON, April 22 The Carter Administration today revised downward its projection for economic growth this year while revising upward its projection for inflation, saying that cold weather was in part to blame in both cases.

Walter B. Coleman, one of three commissioners of the New York City Board of Water Supply, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital after suffering a stroke. He lived at 55 East End Avenue here, and in Islip, L.I. His age was 64.

The New York City Board of Education, responding to a Federal charge of discriminatory personnel practices, yesterday proposed broad changes to bring more teachers from racial minorities into the school system and to avoid their concentration in community school districts that are heavily composed of minority members.
The 1978 executive expense, revenue and capital budgets of the City of New York present a picture of a leaner and stronger city beginning the long climb back.

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (AP) Millet Barber blasted out of a bunker directly into the hole on the 17th green today, carded a six-under-par 66 and gained a tie for the first-round lead in the $175,000 New Orleans open.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 22 Four thousand Palestinians who were driven out of a refugee camp here during the Lebanese civil war and lodged in a village just south of Beirut have now been ordered to move to the southern part of the country.

MOSCOW, April 22 A ranking party ideologist today renewed Soviet criticism of China and acknowledged that relations between the two countries had not im- proved since the death of Mao Tse-tung last September.

In an effort to avert hospital closings or widespread reductions of workers in the municipal hospitals, Mayor Beame proposed in his new budget yesterday giving an additional $24 million to the New York City Health and Hospital Corporation.

Ann M. Look, a corporate lawyer who retired is 1967 as a vice president and counsel of West Point-Pepperell, a New York City textile company, died yesterday at the age of 74 in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a shot illness. He lived in West Tisbury on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where he was a selectman.

The New York Mets don't pick their lineup out of a hat like the Yankees, but sometimes wish that they did. Take last night, when they lived through the full range of trauma before losing in the ninth inning to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3, in the first prime-time show of the season in Shea Stadium.
Austria, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia were each leading is Davis Cup tennis competition played yesterday in Europe. West Germany and Poland were tied after splitting their singles matches at Warsaw.

BOSTON, April 22 With 53 seconds remaining in tonight's game, Joe Bryant embraced Coach Gene Shue, Julius Erving hugged Lloyd Free, and Jack McMahon, the assistant coach, did a little dance with Darryl Dawkins.
BRUSSELS, April 22 (UPI) The dollar gained slightly on most European markets today, while the British pound eased.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Postal Service has accused the American Medical Association of illegally underpaying its postal bills by more than a million dollars and has asked for the money by Monday.
TRENTON, April 22 Unemployment in the state declined in March for the fifth straight month to 9.6 percent, the New Jersey Department of Labor and Industry said today.

The Amerada Hess Corporation, the second oil company to report first-quarter results, achieved a 60.4 percent rise in net income to $70.9 million, or $1.81 a share, from $44.2 million, or $1.13 a share, shown in the first three months last year. The increase was the largest for any quarter in about 5 years and the profit appeared to be the highest on record.
WASHINGTON, April 22 President Carter said today that a new oil-company reporting system he plans to put into effect would show "that unfair competitive procedures are in effect."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22 The Rhode Island Supreme Court is considering a last-ditch appeal by an unseated state legislator to avoid extradition to Michigan to serve a two-to-four-year sentence for shoplifting 31 record albums.
International and domestic issues dominated yesterday's annual meeting of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, highlighted by a protest by union members against J.P. Stevens Company policies.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) To laughter from reporters, President Carter said today that "there may be overkill in having too much access to the press." But there was no evidence that the prospect disturbed him.
"We've got a spirit and a united effort on this club that's been missing for years." So says Ted Simmons, the veteran catcher of the St. Louis Cardinals.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 22 (AP) Corrado Barazzutti of Italy gained the semifinals of a World Championship Tennis tournament today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Tom Okker of the Netherlands at the last stop of the 1977 World Series of Tennis. Barazzutti out classed Okker and broke away from a 2-2 tie in each set.

When Harry Bridges steps down as leader of the West Coast longshoremen at their union convention in Seattle today, his retirement will take from the active labor scene the last of the militant band that joined with John L. Lewis...

LOS ANGELES, April 22 Federal District Judge Robert Kelleher issued a subpoena today to Victor L. Marchetti, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer who wrote a book disclosing some of the agency's secrets, ordering him to testify at the espionage trial of Christopher J. Boyce.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Administration has concluded that an Argentine airline pilot was at fault in a January incident in which a Boeing 707 jet nearly crashed into a heavily populated area near New York's Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON Scientists at the Bell Telephone Laboratories, Holmdel, N.J., who have for some years been working on a communication system that sends light pulses through hairtinn glass fibers, have invented an instrument to improve the process.

CLEVELAND, April 22 Dock Ellis an important man in the Yankee clubhouse and an increasingly important man in the Yankee pitching rotation has entered into a truce in his contract battle with the front office.

To one real-estate man, the Carter energy program means more abandoned buildings, more businesses moving out of New York City. To a senior transit official it means a possible new era for buses and subways. To two state legislative leaders, it meas a chance to make some political hay.

Declaring that New York City is "beginning the long climb back," Mayor Beame yesterday submitted a $13.9 billion expense budget for the year beginning July 1 with a glittering array of election-year bonuses, including modest tax cuts, personnel increases and construction projects scattered through the five boroughs.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 22 Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto met with his party's parliamentary caucus here today in a show of solidarity as this country experienced one of the most violent days of its political crisis.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 22 (AP) llie Nastase ended the upset string of 18-year-old John McEnroe, and Guillermo Vilas upset top-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis tonight in semifinal matches of the Virginia Beach tennis tournament.
Bronx detectives said yesterday they had no suspect in the murder of 77-yearold Sydel Schwartz, whose body was found Thursday night in her Co-Op City apartment at 100 Casals Place.

Peter Quennell has been a part of the English literary scene for as long as most people can remember: since 1922, that is to say, when at the age of 17 he was included in the last of Edward Marsh's then-famous anthologies of "Georgian Verse." Had he died at 21 or 22 he would scrape into the biographical dictionaries as a shortlived poet of promise.

ALBANY, April 22 A bill to bring New York's death-penalty statute into conformance with the latest United States Supreme Court ruling and to expand its application to those who commit murder by arson or terrorist bombing was introduced in the Assembly today.

Shirley Ririe and Joan Woodbury are two names well known in the dance world for their role in the growth of modern dance in the West. After working together since 1957, they formed the Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company at the University of Utah in 1964. In 1966, Miss Woodbury helped form the Utah Repertory Dance Theater, a collective established by the Rockefeller Foundation.

WASHINGTON, 22 The Department of Transportation has proposed to the white House the name of Richard S. Page as the next head of the Urban Transit Administration, according to Carter Administration sources.
LONDON, April 22 (AP) The Bank of England today cut its minimum lending rate to 8 percent from 9 percent, the lowest level since July 1973.
WASHINGTON, April 22 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to uphold a court-ordered desegregation plan in the public schools of Dayton, Ohio, that has extensive busing.

WASHINGTON, April 22 President Carter said today that he could not guarantee that all money collected by the Federal Government through the taxes proposed in his energy plan would be returned to the American people through rebates and refunds.
WASHINGTON, April 22 President Carter will send to Congress on Monday a program that is designed to control health costs by placing a ceiling on increases in hospital charges.

RABAT, Morocco, April 20 King Hassan II and his aides say that Morocco has sent troops to Zaire to oppose the Katangan invasion because, in their view, a challenge to an African country's territorial integrity carries with it the threat of a continent-wide war.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 22 It didn't take much for President Carter's proposed energy program to hit home here.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 22 A Conrail helicopter on a routine flight to watch for fires, vandalism or other trouble crashed onto the Bronx River Parkway today, killing the pilot and injuring a policeman-observer.

Pennsylvania's crew, winner of the San Diego invitation regatta last month, makes its eastern debut today in the Childs Cup regatta over the Orchard Beach lagoon course in the Bronx against Princeton and Columbia. The lagoon at Orchard Beach has become Columbia's home course rather than the Harlem River because the safety of the oarsmen could no longer be assured against the dropping of missiles and rocks from bridges over the river.
CAMDEN, N.J., April 22 (UPI) The New Jersey state police have "substantially" concluded that the fire had destroyed the Garden State race track last week was causd by faulty wiring.
KAOHSIUNG, Taiwan Here at the nearly completed plant of the China Steel Corporation, Taiwan's first large integrated steel mill, engineers are putting the rolling mills through their test runs.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 22 A judge in Superior Court here today rebuffed a Vietnamese refugee who had kidnapped her two children in an effort to reclaim they and ruled that the bachelor who was trying to adopt them would provide a more stable home.

KINSHASA, Zaire, April 22 President Idi Amin of Uganda arrived here today to seek "first class information" about the conflict in Shaba Province and before leaving for home announced he was ready to assist "his brother," President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire.

A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan heard arguments yesterday on a motion to quash a subpoena for a witness in a grand jury's investigation of terrorist bombings attributed to a Puerto Rican nationalist group known as the F.A.L.N.

Two New York food chains, well known to supermarket shoppers, may be merging. Food Fair Inc., which operates both the Food Fair and Pantry Pride supermarkets is preparing to acquire the 42-store chain of Hill's Supermarkets, a division of Pueblo International Inc., food trade sources said yesterday.

More than 200 years after Crispus Attucks died in the Boston Massacre and more than 100 years after the Abolitionist activism of Sojourner Truth, the black population of the Hall of Fame for Great Americans will double today to a total of two.

C.Fred Bergsten, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, asserted yesterday that the Carter Administration wanted to promote greater progress in the developing world and to maintain an open trading system. The economy of the United States has become "inextricably intertwined with the world economy," he said in a speech to the Chicago Council of Foreign Relations.

The all new, purportedly balanced and whiter than white city budget was released yesterday in four big chunks and a man known as Schroeder cast a sad eye on it as a series of dingbats (disjointed paragraphs) in search of a lead (topic sentence).
DUBLIN, April 22 Governor Carey of New York today called members of the Irish Republican Army "killers" and "Marxists" and said they should not receive "a nickel" from Irish-Americans.

If Wednesday night was Baryshnikov Night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the American Ballet Theater showed him in two roles, then Thursday was Makarova Night, when Natalia Makarova made her season's debut, dancing in the same two ballets, Petipa's "La Bayadere" and Glen Tetley's "Le Sacre du Printemps," but not, of course, in the same two roles.

WASHINGTON, April 22 Patrick Shovelton, chief British negotiator in talks with the United States over a new airline treaty, hinted today that the dispute over Concorde landing rights in the New York City area could delay an agreement.

PARIS The legalization of Spain's Communist Party for the first time since the civil-war republic collapsed attracted much Spanish comment and some ugly undercover stirrings in the armed forces. However, Prime Minister Suarez, backed by the growing prestige of young King Juan Carlos, seems to have succeeded with this audacious step whose symbolic importance is to clear the road for Spain's admission to the European Community.

New compositions by Michael Dellario, Hubert S. Howe Jr, and Raoul Pleskow were given premieres at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night in a concert presented by the League of Composers International Society for Contemporary Music.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 22 Nat Perrin, a screenwriter, and the Bank of America were named temporary conservators today for comedian Groucho Marx.

JERUSALEM, April 22 Prime Minster Yitzhak Rabin quietly ended his active service as Israel's leader today by taking an extended vacation that will last until a new Prime Minister forms a majority Government after the country's general election on May 17.
TRENTON, April 22 The New Jersey Supreme Court today unanimously struck down as "clearly illegal" any order by a judge that would prohibit the press from reporting proceedings in open court.

Kevin Loughery has reportedly signed another long-term contract as coach of the New York Nets. A news conference for Monday has been called by the National Basketball Association team to formally announce the agreement, believed to be for five years.

WASHINGTON, April 22 President Carter said today that he could not guarantee that all money collected by the Federal Government through the taxes proposed in his energy plan would be returned to the American people through rebates and refunds.

ATLANTA, April 22 At a New York cocktail party not long ago, the trendy hostess the kind who has tennis elbow, brushes her teeth with Dr. Bronner's Almond Soap and casts the I Ching an gray days served her guests a big bowl of raw peanuts as counterpoint to the dry Gibsons and Tequila Sunrises.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 22 The engineer of a New Haven train was critically injured here last night when a stone shattered the windshield of his moving train and struck him in the forehead, fracturing his skull.

A few years ago, when Tom Benson, Tennessee's Commissioner of Economic and Community Development, had to cut his budget severely, the state's $23,000 contribution to the Southern Growth Policies Board looked ripe for the ax.
HACKENSACK, April 22 The State Public Advocate today criticized the existence of a barren, green isolation cell on the top floor of the Bergen County Jail.
VIENNA, April 22 (AP) The United States ice hockey team hit winning form today in the world championship as the powerful Soviet Union and Czechoslovak teams triumphed for the second time.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (Reuters) President Carter said at his news conference today that he would meet President Assad in Geneva after he attended a seven-nation economic summit meeting in London next month.
MONTREAL, April 22 The International Civil Aviation Organization has called for more effective punishment for airlines that violate rate agreements.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI) Two of the major broadcast networks have offered time for Republicans to respond to President Carter's television appearances on energy, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee said today.

A symphony orchestra conductor, ideally, is just such a communicator, a dealer in muscular subtleties whose every twitch ought to send currents charging through the musicians he faces.

Dr. Milton Helpern, retired Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, died yesterday at University Hospital in San Diego after a long illenss. He was 75 years old.

The no-surprises National Hockey League playoffs are down to the four best teams for the semifinals. The Islanders, who amassed 106 points during the regular season, start a four-ofseven game series tonight at Montreal against the Canadiens (132 points), and the Philadelphia Flyers (112 points) face the Boston Bruins (106 points but more victories than New York) starting tomorrow night.

DACCA, Bangladesh, April 22 (AP) Maj. Gen. Ziaur Rahman announced tonight less than 24 hours after he took over as President of Bangladesh that a referendum would be held May 13 to seek a mandate leading toward a democratic government.

Among the points of interest in the new production of Verdi's "Falstaff," unveiled Thursday night by the Juilliard American Opera Center, was the name of Tito Gobbi as the director. Mr. Gobbi has for many years been one of the world's great baritones, and more recently he has been an opera director, but this was his New York debut in that capacity.

After truly convulsive passage, New York City is experiencing a moment of fiscal calm. We are merely in the eye of the hurricane; there is plenty of heavy weather ahead. But the improbable has occurred: the Mayor has submitted a budget for the year beginning July 1 and it is in balance $14 billion in, $14 billion out.

RALEIGH, N.C. April 24 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth, overtook Pat Bradley with a three-under-par 69 today to win by one stroke in the $50,000 American Defender Life tournament, a Ladies Professional Golf Association event.

Temple Emeth in Teaneck, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Dr. Alicia Kogut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wlodzimierz Kogut of Wroclaw, Poland, to Dr. Vladimir Zwass, son of Dr. and Mrs. Adam Zwass of Vienna. Rabbi Louis J. Sigel performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, April 24 President Carter is expected this week to approve a number of proposals for imposing tighter controls on the export of American arms as part of a general Administration effort to restrain the worldwide sale of arms.

TEL AVIV, April 24 (AP) A bomb believed planted by Arab terrorists ripped through the rear section of a bus today and injured 28 passengers, the police said.

A powerful batting attack, with their team average over the 300 marks, has enabled the Los Angeles Dodgers to put together the best record of the young baseball season. Yesterday, the Dodgers pounded out 16 hits in crushing the Braves, 16-6, at Atlanta for their 11th triumph in 14 games.

Jeff Rubens of Scarsdale, N.Y.; Monroe Ingberman and Paul Heitner of Hartsdale, N.Y.; John Lowenthal of Montvale, N.J., and Larry Rosler of Murray Hill, N.J., held an overwhelming lead of 70 international match points going into the second half of a 64-deal match and won by 83 points.

WASHINGTON, April 25 President Carter sent Congress a tough hospital cost-control proposal today amid growing indications that his Administration had serious questions about the type of national health insurance program for all Americans that he promised in his Presidential campaign.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 They call it the New Orleans Jazz Inheritage Festival, but as far as one eater was concerned, the real subject was food 38 stands and about a half-dozen roving carts spread out on the fairgrounds of the city's race track.

ALBANY, April 25 A bill that would mandate jail sentences for persons convicted of using a gun to commit a serious crime, and increase penalties for illegal possession, sale and manufacture of firearms, passed the Assembly today by a vote of 139 to 3.

DENVER, April 25 An unreleased report severely criticizes the lodgings, restaurants and concessionaire employees in Yellowstone, the oldest and most famous national park in the United States, spokesmen for the Department of the Interior in Washington and the concessionaire confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today that an article about President Carter printed in today's New York Times was "totally inaccurate" and "unfair" and said that he had asked more than 20 members of the White House staff whether they had spoken to the reporter who had written it.

Turkey deserves no tribute for its misguided occupation of northern Cyprus since 1974. The question now is whether it can be persuaded to pull back, then evacuate its forces to permit a fair division of the island between Greek and Turkish Cypriots so that peace can be restored without further damage to both allied and American interests in the eastern Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, April 25 President Carter explored with King Hussein of Jordan today possible ways of allowing Palestinian representation at a Middle East peace conference, a stumbling block that has delayed the reconvening of a Geneva meeting.
General Mills Inc. said it approved a letter of intent to sell its subsidiary, General Mills Chemicals Inc. to Henkel KGAA, a German household care-products company for about $75 million.

MADRID, April 25 Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez was reported today to have suggested strongly that he would be a candidate in the parliamentary elections in June a decision that could shape their outcome.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) Defense Secretary Harold Brown's initial support for criminal penalties for persons who disclose intelligence secrets has apparently been modified in the face of opposition by President Carter and vice President Mondale.

Pledging to end what he termed the "short circuiting" of civil rights by the Nixon Administration, Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, yesterday named David S. Tatel, a 35-year-old Washington lawyer, as director of the Office for Civil Rights.
Two productions of Shakespeare's "Macbeth" one with an interracial cast and the other with an all-black company will be on view simultaneously Off Broadway next month.
The Dow Jones industrial average plugged more than 12 points yesterday, l977's steepest drop as the blue-chip barometer hit a 15-month low.

It might seem unlikely that indigent sailors would make a bridge tournament possible, but it happened Sunday in Staten Island. The seamen's involuntary removal to the Carolinas a few years ago allowed their 150-year-old home, Snug Harbor, to become a cultural center, and bridge is the first activity to make use of the facilities on a regular basis.

DETROIT, April 25 The American Motors Corporation reported today that it more than doubled its earnings in its fiscal quarter that ended March 31, from $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, to $2.5 million, or 8 cents a share.
Bantam Books intends to redistribute two books that have been cited in a controversy over Alex Haley's Pulitzer Prize-winning book, "Roots," a spokesman for the publishing house said yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 25 (AP) Edwin G. Moore 2d was "very frightened" that the Central Intelligence Agency had bugged the office of Dr. Brian Crowley, a psychiatrist who was helping prepare the defense in his espionage trial, Dr. Crowley testified today.

American Brands Inc., the nation's fourth-ranking cigarette producer, reported yesterday a 14 percent gain in first-uuarter net income.

NEW DELHI, April 25 (AP) The World Health Organization has declared smallpox eradicated in India.

CAIRO, April 24 Egypt, its land resources nearly exhausted, will double its population of 38.5 million within 30 years if it continues to grow at the same pace, the first full census in 16 Years indicates.
TRENTON, April 25 After more than eight hours of debate on scores of amendments, the State Assembly approved tonight a bill for regulating casino gambling in Atlantic City.

In the 16 major league baseball games played last Sunday, 44 home runs were hit and 194 runs were scored. Even though the 1977 season is less than three weeks old, there is a noticeable increase in hitting, and while the sample is still too small to have statistical validity, the conviction is widespread among players and managers that the baseball is livelier now than it has been in recent years.

WASHINGTON, April 25 The Supreme Court refused without comment today to hear Charles M. Manson's appeal from his conviction for the killings of Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other persons in California in 1969. No Justice recorded a dissent.

WASHINGTON, April 25 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan denounced the Carter Administration today, both on and off the Senate floor, for delaying submission of welfare reform legislation so that it might not take effect until after fiscal year 1979.

The pace of the fall fashion shows quickens this week. The troops assembled yesterday at 8:30 A.M. ("Before dawn," insisted one sleepy combatant) at the Hotel Pierre to applaud Kasper's gentle clothes for Joan Leslie. Then buses gathered up the retail executives from stores all over the country and deposited them at Geoffrey Beene's door on Seventh Avenue.

LUSAKA, Zambia, April 25 (AP) President Kenneth D. Kaunda dismissed two high-ranking army officials and three Government ministers today on charges of abuse of power and participating in a banned political opposition group.

Phillips Petroleum, which is credited with recoginizing early on the potential of the stormy North Sea as an oil and gas reservoir and which drilled the first two successful fields there, is now facing critical assessment regarding its expertise in tapping the fuel source.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Patsy Mink, an Assistant Secretary of State, and two other women today filed suit against the University of Chicago and a drug concern for $77 million, charging that without their knowledge during pregnancy they were given a drug that was later linked to cancer in offspring.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 (UPI) The Manson group members who killed Leno and Rosemary LaBianca told them before the slayings that they were not going to be hurt, a former Manson follower testified today.

Frederick G. Schmidt, who retired in 1955 as a justice in the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, died Friday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He lived at 20 Lafayette Drive, Port Chester, and was 91 years old.

ZENITH, Kan., April 25 With the winter dryness throughout much of the wheat belt broken by recent rains, the chance for another bumper crop has been increased and President Carter is confronted with the economic and political problems of a huge, price-depressing wheat surplus.

John W. Grady, a New York Times accounting department executive, died of cancer Sunday at the St. Elizabeth's division of the St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. He was 49 years old and lived at 25 Cumming Street.

In an effort to consolidate his control over the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, Mayor Beame is expected to ask the semi-independent city agency today to make Donald E. Kummerfeld, the city's Budget Director, its top policy maker, and to accept a former critic of the agency as the replacement for Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr., its ousted president.

SAN DIEGO, April 25 (UPI) Edgar H. Smith Jr., who spent 14 years on Death Row in the slaying of a New Jersey teenager, was sentenced today to life in prison for the kidnapping and attempted murder of a seamstress.

WASHINGTON, April 25 The Dow Chemical Company paid foreign employees $3.7 million in salaries and bonuses in countries other than where they lived but did not disclose them because "no impropriety" was involved, an amended company registration statement disclosed today.

Abram H. Stockman, a labor arbitrator, who served during World War II as assistant general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board and as vice chairman of the appeals committee of the National War Labor Board, died Sunday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.
DETROIT, April 25 A parents' group here has asked a Federal court to prohibit public schools from punishing students who misbehave by denying them hot lunch.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 24 (AP) The Adirondack Park Agency has given final approval for construction of the controversial 70-and-90-meter ski jumps to be built just south of here for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

NEW DELHI, April 25 The opposition Congress Party won a temporary restraining order from the Supreme Court tonight preventing nine state assemblies under its control from being dissolved by the central Government of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai.

Weston Vernon Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley McCloy and a past president of the New York State Bar Association, died Saturday at his home on Basket Neck Lane in Remsenburg, L.I. He was 72 years old.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 25 "Do you know what happens when a person lies?" the judge asked the boy on the witness stand.

BOSTON One would expect Boston to be a great theater town, and in the past Boston has been a great theater town. Yet in recent years it seems to have had more than the usual difficulties in sustaining high-quality, indigenous theater.
WASHINGTON, April 25 It calls itself the February Group. It meets in Washington hotels, irregularly.

EKOFISK CENTER, in the North Sea off Norway, April 25 High winds and rough seas forced the postponement today of efforts to cap an offshore oil well about a mile from here that is spewing hundreds of thousands of gallons of crude oil a day into the North Sea.

WASHINGTON, April 25 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell listened today to complaints by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who said that morale in the bureau had been damaged by the indictment of a former agent. But he said afterward that it was not likely he would reconsider his decision to prosecute the case.
The gain and soybean futures markets was scenes of heavy selling yesterday as a spate of bearish news hit trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 21 Sixteen months after the Communists seized power Buddhist monks still file through this quiet capital in the early morning collecting alms. But many people wonder how much longer the 700-year-old nation- al religion of Laos will be able to flourish.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 25 (UPI) Bobby Walker, the Utah state aeronautics director, took full responsibility today for crashing the state's $132,000 Beechcraft Barron at Duchcene Airport Friday night. He admitted that he had misjudged his landing approach.

Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx charged yesterday that five of the six state-chartered savings institutions based in the Bronx had "redlined" the borough by providing few residential mortgages in the Bronx.
Governor Carey said yesterday he planned to discuss with state attorneys the "legal aspect" of James A. Farley Jr.'s role in the suspended United States Boxing Championships.
Blase New Yorkers saw still another remarkable Steve Cauthen riding performance at Aqueduct Monday.

A 60-year-old New Jersey man described by law enforcement officials as a major wholesaler of child pornography surprised New York City prosecutors yesterday by pleading guilty to a two-count felony indictment that could bring him as much as 14 years in prison.

Since the period of jazz development preceding World War II came to an end more than 30 years ago, the jazz styles of that period have virtually disappeared except for copies in traditional or revivalist groups. For a young jazz musician today to grow and develop on his own as though this growth were occurring in the 30's or early 40's is almost unheard of.

THRESHOLD Any presentation of the Young Concert Artists, which features the New York debuts of performers selected through international auditions, is an event of interest. Tonight's recital by Sung-Ju Lee, a violinist, is the sixth and final program in the group's 16th series.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 25 (UPI) Lenny Randle, the suspended Texas Rangers' infielder, was named today in a Florida warrant charging him with aggravated battery, a felony, for allegedly beating Manager Frank Lucchesi of the Rangers on March 28.

WASHINGTON, April 25 One year after the Senate intelligence committee issued its final report, its recommendations for controlling the intelligence agencies still have not become law, the oversight committee it led to still is not fully organized and important legislative battles remain to be fought.

TRENTON, April 25 After more than eight hours of debate, the State Assembly approved tonight a bill for regulating casinos in Atlantic City that would allow gambling on roulette, baccarat, blackjack, dice, big-six wheels and slot machines from 10 A.M. to 4 A.M. weekdays and 10 A.M. to 6 A.M. on weekends and holidays.

The NBC-TV production of "Sybil" is one of the 24 winners this year of George Foster Peabody Awards for broadcasting excellence, it was announced yesterday by the University of Georgia School of Journalism. "Sybil" was cited as "one of the truly outstanding dramatic programs of the year."

Advocacy advertising, generally by business but sometimes by public interest groups, is booming in the mid1970's. But S. Prakash Sethi, a business school teacher who has extensively researched the matter, doesn't think it's very effective.

Like cheap energy and the doctor's house call, cheap automobile insurance is becoming a thing of the past. For some young drivers, the cost of the insurance may now exceed the cost of a used car. For a single male in the South Bronx, to take an extreme example, insurance for a 1974 Oldsmobile Cutlass will rise this spring from about $1,200 to more than $1,800.

NEW BRUNSWICK, April 25 Joanne Chesimard sat handcuffed in the jury box today as Judge Theodore Appleby of Superior Court sentenced her to 26 to 33 years in state prison on assault and weapons charges.

Sixty fourth graders from downtown Brooklyn swarmed onto the beach yesterday at Rockaway Point, across Rockaway Inlet in "overseas" Queens, poking into tidal shallows and the "litter line" of marine life cast up by the sea onto the sand.

The automobile industry, whose robust sales have been the major factor in the nation's recovery from its worst postwar recession, has of late been joined in the towing effort by a resurgent home building business.

A Newburgh city judge, Albert S. MacDowell, who delayed cases for months, allowed court mail to pile up for as much as 30 days and who once ordered the arrest of an acting judge seeking access to court records, was dismissed from the bench yesterday for failure to discharge his administrative responsibilities.

The nation's chain stores had a 12.6 percent sales gain in March compared to March 1976, according to a compilation by Chain Store Age magazine. For the first three months of the year, sales were ahead 11.1 percent.

"William Blake: The Painter as Poet," an exhibition of the artist's own books as well as illustrations for other works, such as Dante's "Inferno," is on view at the Swirbul Library Gallery at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I. It may be seen, except for Sunday, daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. through May 29. Admission is free.

Nearly five months after a fire swept a Columbia University dormitory, injuring a dozen students, a Fire Department study has recommended and the university has agreed to implement a major renovation of fire-protection and safety systems on campus.
WASHINGTON, April 25 The House of Representatives, supporting the main lines of President Carter's defense policy, authorized today nearly $36 billion for weapons procurement and military research.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 Victor L. Marchetti, a former officer of the Central Intelligence Agency, testified today that proposed C.I.A. satellite system was not a serious project but was concocted mostly as part of a "dog and pony" show to impress Congress.

American Atlantic salmon anglers are rejoicing that Canada's Province of New Brunswick has announced that it does not contemplate "any major changes or cancellations" in the present system of Crown leases of salmon rivers.
CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) The Illinois Attorney General, William J. Scott, said today that the General Motors offer was a "step in the right direction" but did not go far enough.

ALBANY, April 25 Republicans, who control the New York State Senate, reached agreement on two major issues this afternoon, voting in caucus to extend the Emergency Tenant Protection Act for four years and to make permanent the present 8.5 percent ceiling on homemortgage interest rates.

WASHINGTON, April 25 President Carter has selected a career diplomat, Arthur A. Hartman, as the next American ambassador to France, and has decided to retain another veteran Foreign Service officer, Malcolm Toon, as the Ambassador in Moscow.

The architect of Presidest Carter's energy program, James R. Schlesinger, has raised the distinct possibility that substantial revenues from the new energy-related taxes eventually would be diverted to tax and welfare reform programs.

Eren Ozker and William Russell Bogert 2d were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Robert Duane Pelton. The bride is an actress and puppeteer and her husband is an actor.

The General Motors Corporation, bowing to widespread criticism that it swapped engines without informing buyers, agreed yesterday to let buyers of 1977 Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac cars equipped with Chevrolet engines exchange their cars or receive a free mechanical-performance insurance policy.

From Inwood and Wall Street, some of New York's Irish-Americans have begun denouncing one of their own, Hugh Carey, the Governor of New York who went to Ireland over the weekend and spoke his mind about the violence in the North and the American money he feels helps feed it.

The big guns will be traveling from Arizona, Tennessee and Florida, bringing their fast times and equally fast talk. But Coach John Moon does not believe Seton Hall will be intimidated when the Penn Relays begin in earnest Friday and Saturday at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 Hundreds of Syrian troops of the Arab League's peace-keeping force battled Palestinian extremists and Lebanese leftisfts here today for the third day as a result of the murder of two Syrian soldiers last Friday night.

Making a musical play out of Thomas Hardy's "The Return of the Native" is the kind of endeavor that should give a young author pause. Hardy's novel, with its intertwined characters, folkways and abrupt happenings, is not, one would think, easily reduced to a couple of hours on stage.

BALTIMORE, April 25 Baltimore fans, aroused by Reggie Jackson's return, and a steady rain, falling in spite of the umpire's desire to get the game in, combined tonight to create potentially serious problems for the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, April 25 On the surface, the decision of Ethiopia's military Government to close most American facilities represents a substantial loss of influence for the United States and a dramatic advance for the Soviet Union in the Horn of Africa.

Rough weather delayed efforts to cap the blowout in an oil well in the North Sea between Britain and Norway. With a forecast of winds up to 60 miles an hour and 20-foot waves for today and tomorrow, the repair work may not resume until later in the week. At least two days of calm weather are needed to do the work. [Page 1, Columns 1-2.]
FREEHOLD, N.J., April 25 (UPI) Racing will resume Wednesday at Freehold Raceway, where parimutuel clerks have ended a seven-week strike by accepting a new contract.

The International Business Machines Corporation, having just released what analysts found to be disappointing earnings, reassured stockholders today that price cutting in the industry would actually have a beneficial effect.
SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., April 25 John D. Toft, a pioneer in the fish canning industry, died Saturday in the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 90 years old.

Specialties from more than 100 of New York City's restaurants and food shops will be offered to an expected half a million people at an expanded version of last year's successful "A Taste of the Big Apple" event to be held Saturday afternoon, June 4, in Central Park.

MOSCOW, April 25 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has won the European team chess championship for the sixth straight time. Its team was led by the world champion, Anatoly Karpov, who won all five of his games, and included two former world titleholders, Tigran Petrosian and Mikhail Tal.

WASHINGTON, April 25 President Carter explored with King Hussein of Jordan today possible ways of allowing Palestinian representation at a Middle East peace conference, a stumbling block that has delayed the reconvening of a Geneva meeting.

STAMFORD, Conn. The announcement that Henry Kissinger will coach the Detroit Red Wings hockey team next season came as no surprise to those who know of the former Secretary of State's long-time interest in ice.

A statewide Ku Klux Klan organization, fighting an effort by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to compel disclosure of its membership, has enlisted the help of the American and the New York Civil Liberties Unions.
Alberto Ginastera's "Barabbas" will be given its world premiere by the New York City Opera next spring as one of five new productions it is presenting during the 1977-78 season.

LONDON, April 25 (AP) The dollar fell slightly against every major West European currency today. the price of an ounce of gold dropped to $148.375 in both Zurich and London, the two biggest gold markets.
LAUREL, Md. The whooping cranes are not receiving visitors just now, being otherwise occupied in propagating themselves a bit further back from the edge of extinction.
TRENTON, April 25 The State Senate approved today a record $4 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The vote was 24 to 9, with the opposition coming from Republican members.
MARSALA, Sicily, April 25 (UPI) Archeologists believe that they have found the ancient wall of Lilibeo where the Romans fought the Carthaginians in the first Punic War in 241 B.C.

The General Motors Corporation, bowing to widespread criticism that it swapped engines without informing buyers, agreed yesterday to let buyers of 1977 Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac cars equipped with Chevrolet engines exchange their cars or receive a free mechanical-performance insurance policy.

Martin R. Gainsbrugh, who retired in 1972 as senior vice president and chief economist of the Conference Board, died yesterday at the age of 70 in Freeport, the Bahamas, where he had his winter home. He was a former resident of New York City and had a summer home in Plessis, N.Y.

The shootout, this year's innovation by the North American Soccer League to provide thrills and to prevent a tie, is despised by most players and a number of coaches, but advocated by several administrators.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Supreme Court gave some insurance compa nies a financial victory today when it ruled that methods they used to obtain favorable tax treatment did not violate the Internal Revenue Code.
Art directors from the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, took home three of the 26 Gold Awards distributed yesterday by the Art Directors Club.

Bell said today that the Government ought to but would not pay the legal fees of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents indicted for alleged break-ins, wiretaps, mail openings or other illegal activities they carried out in domestic subversive cases.

England's greatest contribution to gastronomy has nothing to do with Brussels sprouts, toad in the hole, bubble and squeak or even rare roast beef and Yorkshire pudding. PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 27 The fans stayed until the bitter end early this morning as the Boston Bruins stole another overtime game from the Philadelphia Flyers, this time scoring after 10 minutes 7 seconds of the second extra period for a 5-4 victory.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill. Some weeks ago, my father survived a heart attack. Now that he is recovering, we are not so much concerned about his physical condition as we are about his financial situation. While he has survived the heart attack, he may not survive the bills.

AS LAST season's bitter cold begins to recede into memory, and long-awaited warm weather strikes stirring chords in winter-weary New Yorkers, one sign of the city's awakening to spring is the sudden proliferation of bicyclists once again freewheeling through the streets and parks.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they would resume formal negotiations for a new strategic arms limitation treaty in Geneva on May 11 in advance of a meeting there later in the month between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.
WASHINGTON, April 26 The Carter Administration is studying the imposition of ceilings on doctors' fees as a second means of controlling sharply rising medical care costs.

CLINTON, Mass., April 26 President Carter put this mill town in the limelight as a showcase of New England democracy when he came here on March 16 for a special staged town meeting. The townspeople drew lots for the honor of crowding into the town hall, the streets were jammed, 300 reporters were in attendance and the event was televised nationally.

The last of four indictments brought by Maurice H. Nadjari against Patrick J. Cunningham was dismissed yesterday by Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the New York State Supreme Court. The judge criticized the case for an insufficiency of evidence and the "shockingly improper and prejudicial manner" in which it was presented to a grand jury.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26 President Carter's warning of a tight world oil supply in the 1980's is in keeping with the analyses that have been made by a number of United Nations experts here.

LOVERS OF KURT WEILL, arise. Get to see the Chelsea Theater Center production of the Weill/ Brecht musical "Happy End," which officially opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night and is scheduled to end there this weekend. The company is confident of tranferring the production to Manhattan but please take no chances. Besiege Brooklyn, in case it is too late.

DETROIT, April 26 (AP) Three Chrysler Corporation assembly plants will be shut and two others will operate on half shifts tomorrow because of a srike at a key components factory, company officials said today.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) Drugs given to pregnant women in an experiment in the early 1950's did not cause cancer in their children, the University of Chicago said today in response to a suit filed by three women who took part in the experiment.

ALBANY, April 26 New York State's Social Services Commissioner charged today that tactics "bordering on the unethical" were being used to discredit his choice of the Bradford National Corporation over Citibank to handle computer services for New York City's Medicaid program.
Bella S. Abzug declared yesterday that she was "running" for the Democratic nomination for Mayor even though she had not formally announced her candidacy and could still change her mind.

In requesting the Central Intelligence Agency to declassify its report on world petroleum resources, President Carter yielded to an understandable impulse with consequences that may do him and the C.I.A. more harm than good.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) The teamsters' largest pension fund, operating since last year under the threat of losing its tax-exempt status, has been requalified under an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service, it was announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, April 26 (UPI) "Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman," television's hit satirical soap opera, is going into "voluntary retirement" as of July 1 but will be seen on reruns, and may of its zany characters will appear in two new miniseries, its producer, Norman Lear, announced today.
