In 1972 and 1973, the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health collected the personnel records of 2,500 workers who had been exposed to carcinogenic substances at dye plants in five states. The substances, benzidine and beta-naphthylamine, have long been known to cause cancer of the bladder. With early warning, the lives of victims of bladder cancer can be prolonged. But most of these 2,500 who had been exposed received no warning.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) The Administration today declared that discrimination based on pregnancy is sex discrimination and urged Congress to pass a bill that would overturn a Supreme Court ruling that lets employers deny disability payments to expectant women.

YONKERS, April 26 State Comptroller Arthur Levitt told an executive session of the Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board today that the city, which appeared to be emerging from its fiscal difficulties, might find its budget out of balance this year and face continued state supervision of its financial affairs.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that they would resume formal negotiations for a new strategic arms limitation treaty in Geneva on May 11 in advance of a meeting there later in the month between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.
WASHINGTON, April 26 The Carter Administration is studying the imposition of ceilings on doctors' fees as a second means of controlling sharply rising medical care costs.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that it is unconstitutional for states to bar illegitimate children from inheriting from their father when the father dies without leaving a will.

MONTREAL, April 26 The Quebec government, after five months in office, is engaged in an increasingly bitter battle on four fronts to persuade this province's predominantly French population to accept independence.

EAST RUTHERFORD, April 26 Representatives of 35 communities and cultural organizations urged members of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts today to establish a major arts and cultural center in their areas.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP) Old crop soybean and meal futures fell to permissible limits on the Chicago Board of Trade today for the second straight session.

The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, removing what M.A.C. officials said had been a "cloud" driving up the corporation's interest rate and hampering its efforts to meet New York City's financing needs.

DETROIT, April 26 The Chrysler Corporation reported today net earnings of $75.4 million, or $l.25 a share, for the first quarter a modest increase of 4.6 percent over the $72.1 million, or $1.20 a share, that the company earned a year earlier.

Reform politicians to the north of him. Puerto Rican politicians to the south of him, Patrick J. Cunningham finally free of the legal problems that had hounded him for more than a year confronts a political landscape strewn with pitfalls.

Two correction guards at the Men's House of Detention in Kew Gardens, Queens, were assaulted last night by a group of inmates, but an alarm signal was set off by one of the guards and a possible escape of the prisoners was prevented.
A question of one little word has plagued the residents of Queens who live in School District 28 and are involved in the community school board elections.

DETROIT, April 26 In a surprise move late this afternoon, the General Motors Corporation filed a motion in a Federal court here today to stop a grand jury investigation into allegations of tax fraud by the company.

Employees and management of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People reached a tentative settlement of a dispute over contract issues late last night, ending a seven-day work stoppage that was the first fullscale walkout in the history of the civil rights organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. faces a test in the California Supreme Court of his authority to continue to circumvent a 40-year-old state law in avoiding the extradition of Dennis Banks, the militant Indian leader, to South Dakota for sentencing in a felony conviction.

NEWCASTLE, England, April 26 (AP) Sir Daniel McGarvey, who started work as a shoeshine boy and became the tough left-wing president of the Boilermakers' Union, died today in Newcastle General Hospital, the union announced. He was 57 years old. The cause of death was not stated.

FROM MY apprenticeship as a chef in Paris more than 40 years ago, one of the things I remember most profoundly is the occasional trip to the old markets at Les Halles with my mentor and guide, the chef of the Restaurant Drouant, at that time one of the most celebrated restaurants in the city.

They have a need to help others, and they gathered yesterday in the Board of Estimate chambers at City Hall high school and college students, grandmothers and those with no special label to be recognized.

ALBANY, April 26 The leadership of both houses of the Legislature announced agreement today on a four-year extension of both the statewide rent stabilization program and of upstate and suburban rent control.
NEEDHAM, Mass., April 26 The first instant motion picture system, far more compact than advance speculation had indicated, was demonstrated here today to stockholders of the Polaroid Corporation.
The Dow Jones industrial average clung precariously to a slim gain yesterday and narrowly avoided hitting another 15month low.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, reported yesterday a sharp recovery in first-quarter earnings, thanks largely to its Peabody Coal subsidiary.

Jack Kauffman, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, has gained quite a reputation for his fearless forecasts of industry advertising revenue. Yesterday in San Francisco, where the membership is meeting, he said that 1977 was going to top 1976 the best growth year yet for newspapers by 10 percent, and reach $11 billion.

WASHINGTON, April 26 A three-sided power struggle involving two Senate committee chairmen and James R. Schlesinger, the Administration's energy chief, has shaped up over what authority Congress will grant Mr. Schlesinger as the nations first Secretary of Energy.
The New York Times Company told its shareholders yesterday that first-quarter earnings had doubled on a 12 percent increase in revenues over the comparable period of 1976.

ALBANY, April 26 The leadership of both houses of the Legislature announced agreement today on a four-year extension of both the statewide rent stabilization program and of upstate and suburban rent control.

Dr. Stanley Berger, a psychoanalyst who had served as president, dean and training analyst at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research here, died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

ALL-RACHMANINOFF programs have been a Philadelphia Orchestra calling card for many years. The composer first per formed his music with the Philadelphians in 1909, continued the association as guest conductor and piano soloist for 30 years, and often proclaimed the group his favorite orchestra.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 26 (AP) Most of the record 69 whooping cranes at the Aransas National Wildlife Refuge on the Texas coast have left for their Canadian breeding grounds, the Parks and Wildlife Department reported today.

It was a story explicitly anti-TV, and television loved it, covered it and, ultimately, exploited it.

IT WILL BE the first trip to Europe for Andrew Wyeth, the distinguished American realist painter, when he leaves Saturday for Paris to be installed as a member of the French Academy of Fine Arts.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 26 (Agence France-Presse) South African security forces have killed 20 guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization and one Angolan soldier in clashes on the border between Angola and South-West Africa since April 2, an official army communique said today.

MARTHA LOOMIS was walking across the Barnard College campus recently when one of her friends spotted her, stopped still and asked, "Martha, is that you?" It was Martha, in a new beige linen suit, brown blouse, blue pumps and a fresh haircut, midway in the spring metamorphosis from college to career woman. She was on her way to a job interview.
Oil companies continued yesterday to report a mixed pattern of earnings for the first quarter, with Texaco Inc. showing a modest 8.4 percent increase.

CAIRO, April 26 Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain left Cairo for Damascus, Syria, today after two days of talks centering on Soviet activities in Africa and a resumption of the Geneva peace conference on the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, April 26 House and Senate conferees broke a long deadlock and accepted President Carter's $4 billion public works jobs program today by agreeing to detach controversial water pollution provisions from the legislation. The bill, a key element of the President's economic stimulus package, is expected to be on his desk for signature on Friday.
GUERNICA, Spain, April 26 (UPI) Basques today commemorated the 40th anniversary of the Nazi bombing of Guernica.

ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa April 26 (Reuters) The South African Government, sensitiv to accusations that it runs a "Devil's Island" for political prisoners, has finally allowed outsiders to see its maximum-security jail. All its inmates are nonwhites.

MUTSHATSHA, Zaire, April 26 (Reuters) A Zairian militay spokesman said today that his country's forces, backed by Moroccans, had pushed swiftly west from here toward the Angolan border, meeting little resistance from rebels who lost control of this key railroad town yesterday.
Johnny McEnroe had a week of tennis that other 18-year-old players dream about.

Anyone with the right credit card can buy sexon credit, the Mayor's Midtown Citizens Committee charged yesterday, and it called on two major banks and the American Express Company to cancel the credit-card accounts of sex merchants.

The Ernest Hemingway Foundation Award "for the best first novel by an American published during the previous year" will be presented this afternoon to Renata Adler, author of "Speedboat." Miss Adler, a former New York Times film critic and New Yorker writer, is now a first-year student at Yale Law School.

Lenny Randle, the controversial infielder who was suspended for 30 days by the Texas Rangers after he had floored Manager Frank Lucchesi, was bought yesterday by the New York Mets a team badly in need of some punch.

OTTAWA, April 26 In a major reform resulting from official charges of laxity in the administration of public funds, the Canadian Government has decided to appoint a permanent overseer of Federal spending programs, with the title of Comptroller General.

The Manhattan District Attorney's office capped a seven-month investigation yesterday by arresting eight alleged pornographers on felony charges and seizing 4,000 copies of pornographic films involving children between 8 and 12 years old.

BALTIMORE, April 26 In the second of their three night foray into Baltimore's hostile wilderness, the Yankees suffered a 6-2 loss to the Orioles tonightand ended their six-game winning streak, but they couldn't be altogether unhappy.

EVERY SO OFTEN someone announces that the fashionable wine from California this season will be the zinfandel or the petite sirah or the merlot. Everyone dutifuly hastens to stock up on whatever is supposed to be the rage.

A change in the delicate balance of the body's sex hormones is the major factor that makes men susceptible to heart attacks, according to a major new theory developed by Dr. Gerald B. Phillips of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The accuracy, completeness and purpose of the major United States study arguing for the safety of nuclear reactors have been challenged by internal Government documents made public today.

Milton Helpern, who was internationally known as a medical detective, wrote the definitive text in his field and taught generations of forensic pathologists, was honored yesterday by 700 relatives, colleagues and students who filled the Park Avenue Synagogue to pay their last respects.

MOSCOW, April 26 When Vladimir Voinovich was summoned for a chat with the K.G.B. security police in May 1975, one agent with intellectual pretensions inquired how the writer went about his creative labors.

SAN DIEGO, April 26 (AP) The first of the Dew quadruplets has been released from Children's Health Center and the others are reported getting stronger. They were born 12 weeks prematurely Feb. 24 to James and Diane Dew of Poway. Elizabeth, weighing five pounds, was taken home yesterday.

GENEVA, April 26 A standby credit of $1.2 billion was offered to the Swiss Credit Bank today, to help as needed fol- lowing the multimillion-dollar loss it faces because of irregular dealings at one of its branches.

HOUSTON, April 26 Instead of the "moral equivalent of war," the nation faces what some regional officials are calling "the economic equivalent of civil war" over President Carter's energy proposals.

VIENNA, April 26 (AP) A dramatic goal with 2 minutes 16 seconds left to play, scored while a broken stick was sliding through the goal crease, gave Finland a 3-2 victory over the United States today in the world ice hockey championship.

HEINRICH VON KLEIST committed suicide in 1811 at the age of 34. Shortly before his death, he wrote "The Prince of Homburg," using a 17th-century story about a Prussian nobleman who disobeys his military orders but nevertheless defeats the invading Swedish forces. The conquering hero is sentenced to death for not following orders. Von Kleist transformed this incident into an exploration of dream and reality, passion and dissembling, cringing cowardice and bravado.

The recent spell of premature summer turned out yesterday to be the chief villain in the slowdown of garbage collection in queens. Borough President Donald R. Manes and Sanitation Commissioner Anthony T. Vaccarello agreed on this after a meeting at the Borough President's office.

MONTREAL, April 26 Learning to their dismay that "close" still counts only in drive-ins, grenade-throwing and horseshoes, the Islanders dropped their second straight playoff game to the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The score was 3-0.

The Manhattan District Attorney's of fice capped a seven-month investigation yesterday by arresting eight alleged pornographers on felony charges and seizing 4,000 copies of pornographic films involving children between 8 and 12 years old.

A police officer who had called for assistance over his portable two-way radio was found lying unconscious with a head injury in Bryant Park early today. His service revolver and two spent shells were lying nearby, the police said.

TEL AVIV, April 26 The Soviet Union has offered to trade with Israel for the first time since Moscow severed all relations 10 years ago. The Soviet offer was immediately interpreted here as a signal that the Russians wanted to restore diplomatic relations.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 A 23-year-old college student testified today that, while working as a code clerk for a Central Intelligence Agency project, he learned of "a deception against the Australians," and that revulsion over this discovery had begun a trail of events that led to his being blackmailed into becoming a Russian spy.

PRINCETON, April 26 Governor Byrne met today at Morven, the Governor's Mansion, wish three of the six New Jersey members of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to try to line up support for a proposed shakeup of the top posts at the bistate agency worked out by Mr. Byrne and Governor Carey.

Mayor Beame took control of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday, installing his principal fiscal aide a the corporation's top policymaker and assuring a major administrative shake-up of the semi-independent city agency that operates the municipal hospitals.

HALLANDALE, FLA. Thousands of former Northerners have discovered that retirement in southern Florida, though often luxuri ous, nonetheless presents some of the same sorts of anxieties that they came here to escape.
OLD WESTBURY, L.I., April 26 Students at the State University campus here voted today to end their nine-day strike, remove their guards from the campus gates and return to classes tomorrow.

Every corporate headquarters job moved out of New York City to a suburb adds a minimum of 248 gallons of gasoline a year to the nation's energy expenditures, according to a study made public yesterday.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 26 (Reuters) The acting president of Pakistan's nine-party opposition alliance met eight jailed leaders of the movement today in a detention center outside the nation's capital. The meeting was arranged by Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in an effort to negotiate a solution to his country's two-month-old political crisis, in which some 250 people have died.

VERGEZE, FRANCE PERRIER, the gaseous mineral water that has been bubbling up from an underground spring near this southern village for at least 2,000 years, is about to lose some of its chic on the American drinking market.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 26 Manny Ycaza the 38-year-old retired jockey, emerged from his debut as a harness-racing driver at rainy Monticello Raceway tonight convinced he has lots to learn before he can create a stir in the standardbred sport.

KODIAK, Alaska, April 26 (AP) Twenty-nine crew members have been rescued from a burning Japanese fishing boat in Cold Bay, 450 miles southwest of Anchorage, a Coast Guard spokesman said. He said that the crew abandoned the blazing 185-foot Fukyoshi Maru No. 85 and was picked up by a Russian cargo vessel yesterday. The Coast Guard in Kodiak sent the cutter Jarvis to pick up the rescued men.

Twenty-one F-15 Eagle fighters, the Air Force's Contestant for air superiority, will be deployed across the Atlantic today in what the Pentagon regards as a major qualitative reinforcement of United States air power in Western Europe.

Extra-base slugging by Bill Robinson and Frank Taveras, coupled with the combined three-hit pitching of John Candelaria and Rich Gossage, carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-0 victory last night over the Philadelphia Phillies in Three Rivers Stadium.

The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter was up 15.2 percent from year-earlier levels. The utility, one of the nation's largest, also declared as unchanged dividend of 50 cents a share payable June 15 to stockholders of record as of last May 11.

JERUSALEM, April 26?Acting Prime Minister Shimon Peres said last night that it was still possible to reconvene Arab-Israeli peace talks this year although the path to a speedy solution of the prolonged conflict between Arabs and Israelis was blocked by formidable barriers.

PARIS, April 26 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who is struggling to prevent a Socialist-Communist victory in parliamentary elections scheduled for next year, today unveiled a new economic program that his Government hopes will take the political sting out the country's growing unemployment problem.

Other players and coaches during the National Basketball Association regular season had made similar remarks about the Philadelphia 76ers' lack of togetherness on defense. Even Coach Gene Shue has been an outspoken critic of the way his team plays defense.

The New York Apples open their new season in World Team Tennis tonight against the Sea-Port Cascades in Felt Forum. With the kind of salesmanship they are enjoying, it's hard to see how they can miss a successful defense of their championship.

He was 82 years old and lived at 464 Riverside Drive.

A 32-year-old policeman was reported in "fair" condition at Bellevue Hospital yesterday after being mugged while on patrol in Bryant Park late Wednesday night.

Choking back sobs, Hortense Barber told a joint legislative panel yesterday that the first time her husband beat her was the day she told him she was pregnant with their first child.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI) Finance ministers of 20 nations agreed today that the International Monetary Fund should be supplied with new money to help member countries with deficits in their payments balance.

John F. Murray Jr., a writer and former advertising copywriter was found dead Thursday in the Kill Van Kull off New Brighton, S.I. He had been reported missing since early January and an autopsy is to be performed today. Mr. Murray was 53 years old and lived in Wainscott, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Two of the rites of spring in Washington are the arrival of tourists to view the cherry blossoms and the sending to Congress of the Presidential health message containing hard facts about rising health.
CHICAGO, April 29 On an active trading day the grain pits at the Chicago Board of Trade have a decibel range somewhere between a disgruntled crowd at a rock concert and the Tower of Babel.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 (UPI) If an unmarried man is a bachelor, what should an unmarried woman be called? A high school class studying the origin of words has coined its own term, "tamatress," based on a Latin term meaning "one who cares for bulls."

Stock prices showed little overall change yesterday as investors worried over the Federal Reserve's apparent move to tighten credit conditions a notch by allowing short-term rates to rise in the money market.

LONDON, April 29(AP) The dollar lost ground against most major currencies for the third straight day today, despite encouraging news from the United States index of economic indicators. The price of gold increased.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 1 Four United Nations diplomats who look. fondly on New York as their adopted home have set themselves the goal of polishing the city's image and, it is hoped, attracting some corporate business its way.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 Lloyd Free was the ultimate playground player today. He was arrogant, confident, brash and at times disrespectful of John Havlicek and the Boston Celtics.
MIAMI, May 1 (UPI) A marine research vessel, the Venture, returned home over the weekend after spending two and a half days under interrogation by the Cuban authorities.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Americans should not rush out and buy fuelefficient cars on the assumption that gas taxes are going up or that there will be rebates, two members of Congress said today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1 The head of the political department of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Farouk Kaddoumi, today set forth the conditions for Palestinian attendance at a reconvened Geneva conference on the Middle East. He also warned that if the conference was held without the Palestinians, "it will become an obstacle to peace."

Henriette Helene Ellner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Ellner of Kew Garden Hills, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel L. Hasley, son of Louis L. Hasley, professor emeritus of English at the University of Notre Dame, and Mrs. Hasley, known as Lucile Hasley, a retired personal essayist and lecturer, of South Bend, Ind. Prof. Hasley taught at the university for 42 years.

Although the Exxon Corporation topped Fortune magazine's list of 500 industrial companies for last year, General Motors Corporation narrowed the oil company's lead and the Ford Motor Company passed Texaco Inc. to move into third place.

No sooner had the Government asked a Federal Court in Chicago last Thursday to force members of the oil-rich Hunt family to liquidate their allegedly excessive holdings of old-crop soybean futures contracts, than commodity traders started asking questions.
HOUSTON A recent Harris poll indicated that public confidence in the press fell from 26 percent in 1975 to 20 percent in 1976. Confidence in television news declined from 35 percent to 28 percent.
Charles O. Locke, a newspaperman who wrote for the stage and later concentrated on Western novels, died yesterday in a nursing home in Burbank, Calif., where he lived. He was 81 years old.
ST. LOUIS, May 1 St. Louis welcomed on Friday a long overdue prodigal son, Al Hirschfeld, theater caricaturist extraordinary, who last visited his native heath just over half a century ago.
A Carter Administration spokesman and the Senate's ranking Republican came to New York City yesterday to affirm support for Jews seeking rights in the Soviet Union, including the freedom to emigrate.
RUTHERFORD, May 1 When a bridge joining two communities in different counties is knocked out by a barge, who pays for its repairs?
MOSCOW, May I (UPI) About two million flag-waving marchers paraded before the Soviet leadership today in a May Day celebration on the sundrenched cobblestones of Red Square.

Jesse and Belle Estroff of Brooklyn say their concern is theft, unimpeded, because there are no neighborhood policemen pounding the beat. Alexander Plummer in Queens says his concern is inadequate parking. Bernard Harris in the Bronx says his is the continuing cutbacks in mass transit. John Lucci on Staten Island complains about the sales tax and shoppers fleeing to New Jersey. And Cy Berger in Manhattan talks about a complete breakdown of all city services.
The Seattle Mariners ended their first visit to New York yesterday with the tiniest of consolations they outhit the Yankees, 13-8, but lost the game, 5-2, at Yankee Stadium.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1 (Reuters) President Suharto appealed to Indonesians tonight to vote in tomorrow's general elections for a new parliament and pledged to uphold democracy and constitutional rule.

New York City has nearly completed the two-year process of converting $6 billion in short-term debt into long-term obligations, and fiscal experts familiar with the projections for the next 10 years believe that the city's annual payments to retire that debt will be well within its means.

WASHINGTON, May 1 Senators John J. McClellan and Edward M. Kennedy and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell will announce tomorrow an agreement on a proposed new Federal criminal code that would modify or eliminate provisions that have been attacked as threats to civil liberties.

Of the seven last-round games in the Geneva International Tournament, only one between Grandmasters Genna Sosonko of the Netherlands and Werner Hug of Switzerland produced a victory. The others resulted in draws that were for the most part perfunctory, taking about a dozen moves.

As the lights in the downtown apartment buildings and brownstones began snapping on in New York City about 6:45 the other morning, John Sawhill, the president of New York University, just finishing his daily two-mile run around Washington Square Park, joined a group of 20 volunteers for their twiceweekly clean-up of the park.

Michel Beroff chose a splendid program for his Sunday afternoon piano recital at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. He opened with four of the exotic short pieces Liszt wrote in his final years "Nuages gris," "La lugubre gondola I," "En reve," and "Trauer-Vorspiel and Marsch."

DREAM TEAM Tonight and tomorrow at 8, New Yorkers have the rare opportunity to see a small but distinguished theater unit from Germany in action, with a German-English production of Franz Kafka's "Dream of the Ape Redpeter." The place is the CSC Theater, the Off Broadway showcase at 136 East 13th Street.
BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP) Guillermo Vilas, Argentina's No. 1 tennis player, beat Dick Stockton today, enabling his country surprisingly to eliminate the United States in Davis Cup play.

In the ornate lobby of what used to be the Riverside Plaza Hotel, under chandeliers and ceilings with hand-crafted designs, several young men were polishing and sweeping the hardwood floors and marble stairway.

John G. Greenburgh, former president of Adolph Lewisohn and Son, a mining and banking concern, died Saturday at his home, 936 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. He was 97 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Charles W. Colson, who was special counsel to President Nixon, said today that reports that he and Mr. Nixon discussed a coverup three days after the Watergate breakin were filled with "gross inaccuracies, gross distortion."
CLEVELAND, May 1 A member of the chorus of New York's Metropolitan Opera Company was killed here last night when her flowing costume was caught in the grille of a backstage elevator.

The Hicksville, L.I., school district is facing a strike by 90 custodians today, but all 10 of the district's schools are expected to be in operation, according to Superintendent Frederick Hill. Jose Molina, a highly individual Spanish dancer who has acquired an enthusiastic following in the United States, capivated a packed house again Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

Barbara Shemel, a lawyer-therapist in a special counseling service for the Children's Hospital in San Francisco, was married yesterday morning to Caleb Cushing, an architect and builder in Berkeley, Calif.

PARIS, May 1(Reuters) International regulations should be drawn up to govern the safety of offshore oil rigs, the 24member Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recommended in a report today.
With the hot breath of competition now only as far away as Atlantic City, the debate over casino gambling for New York State has warmed considerably.
WEST HILLS, L.I., May 1 The Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission is looking for a couple with a passion for lilacs and literature to live on the homestead of a great American poet.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 1 With Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto in con trol of his divided nation at least temporarily, negotiations With the imprisoned leaders of the opposition Pakistan National Alliance remained stalemated today.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 1 Two years after the Communist victory, Cambodia is pictured by refugees arriving here as a desolate country, beset by crop failures and disintegrating irrigation systems.
CHESTER, Pa., May 1 (UPI) A former state investigator says that police abuse is no longer confined to large cities and ghetto areas.

HOUSTON, May 1 (UPI) Gene Littler, one of the few old pros still battling the horde of talented young lions on the tour of the Professional Golfers' Association, won a $40,000 paycheck today with a three-shot victory in the Houston open. The triumph was the 29th in his career on the tour.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 "You can't buy horses like this one," Seattle Slew's trainer was saying at Churchill Downs today. "You can't breed 'em, and, you can't steal 'em. One day you just look up, and there it is."
ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 Major commercial airlines, which have shown little interest in Atlantic City in the past, are competing vigorously to serve the resort now that gambling casinos are due.

Curious what sticks in some people's minds. A friend reminisced recently of a trip she took to France, during which she dined at the Pyramide Restaurant in Vienne, when the owner and great chef, Fernand Point, was still alive. She recalled very well the foie gras en brioche, the gateau of chicken livers, a timbale of crawfish and so on, but what she distinctly remembered was a prune dessert made with bordeaux wine and vanilla.
LOS ANGELES, May 1 As President Carter's first 100 days are reviewed, there is probably no segment of the electorate more pleased with his performance than the environmental community.

WASHINGTON, May 1 President Carter and his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., have found it much more difficult than they once imagined to develop fundamental changes in the nation's welfare system, according to Government officials who have worked with them.

A former high Czechoslovak official who was allowed to come to the West last year says that Czechoslovak intelligence documents refer to Julius Rosenberg executed as a spy with his wife in 1953, as "our agent," Time magazine reports today.

CAIRO, May 1 A team of archeologists from the Brooklyn Museum has begun to explore the temple precinct of Mut, queen of the gods of ancient Egypt. COVINGTON, Ky., May 1 (AP) A postal clerk has filed a union grievance alleging that the United States Postal Service is discriminating against him because he is left-handed.

Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Watson of Westfield, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Joseph Allen.

For the investor from the Northeast who puts his money into tax-exempt state and city bonds, the 1970's have been a trying time of defaults, moratoriums and broken covenants, And the bad news has been prevailing over the good. This important sector of the financial markets has brightened significantly, thanks to two court decisions that have strengthened its philosophical foundation.

Playing in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the Borodin Quartet reappeared here after a four-year absence. They were replaced by Mischa Kopelman and Andrei Abramenov. Dimitri Shebalin continues as violist and Valentin Berlinsky as cellist.

COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, May 1 (Reuters) The police today shot and wounded about 30 people here during clashes bettween rival Sri Lankan political groups on their way to May Day rallies.

The Boston Bruins to the Montreal Canadiens: "We're waiting for you, and we're ready."

TOKYO, May 2 Japan is celebrating go-ru-den oo-ee-ku once again, if that is not too active a verb to describe what the Japanese started doing last Thursday evening and plan to continue until next Friday morning.
Mayor Beame has asked Timothy A. Hanan, a close friend of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, to head his campaign committee for re-election, City Hall sources said yesterday.

AMITYVILLE,, L.I., May 2 Daniel J. Ferris, a leading figure in amateur athletics in the United States and abroad for more than 70 years, died early this morning in a nursing home here after at long illness. He was 87 years old.
TRENTON, May 2 The State Commission of Investigation urged the State Senate today to strengthen further the casino gambling bill that was passed by the Assembly last Monday night.
Mayor Beame's office has sent to Martin P. Lang, the Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, a list of 200 names of politically connected youths seeking unadvertised summer jobs.

ALBANY, May 2 An elaborately heralded effort by the Legislature to fashion a neat package of bills benefiting the elderly on the eve of Senior Citizens Day in the Capitol fizzled this afternoon when the Assembly leadership botched a principal measure that would have liberalized property-tax exemptions for people 65 years of age and over.
For the people who are trying to cut down on deaths owing to high blood pressure, a major problem is that sufferers are not faithful about taking their medication.

The New York City Board of Education was accused yesterday of routinely sending black and Hispanic problem students to special schools for the Socially Maladjusted and Emotionally Handicapped while seeking to help white problem students in their own schools.

A convict who allegedly kidnapped and raped a 19-year-old college student while he was on a two-day furlough from a state study-release program was arrested at gunpoint in a Brooklyn motel room yesterday afternoon. The police said he had forced his terrified victim to accompany him on a 20-hour crime spree in Brooklyn and Queens.
VIENNA, May 2 (UPI) Sweden put an end to Soviet Union domination of the world ice hockey championship today with a 5-1 victory over the previously undefeated team.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The General Accounting Office told Congress today that commercial nuclear facilities in the United States were not able to account for thousands of pounds of highly enriched uranium and plutonium.

UNITED NATIONS, May 2 (Reuters) The Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities have a long way to go before they start making the concessions needed for a solution of the island's problems. Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said today.

Arthur Miller's newest play, "The Archbishop's Ceiling," his first since 1972, had its world premiere in Washington Saturday night and the critics who saw it there have given the work unfavorable reviews.
When the Yankees and the California Angels meet for the first time in the season at Yankee Stadium tonight, the fans might not be able to see the players for the dollar signs.

QUEBEC, May 2 (UPI) The Quebec Nordiques tonight gained the final series of the World Hockey Association's playoffs by defeating the Indianapolis Racers, 8-3. Quebec won its semifinal series by four games to one.

NEWARK, May 2 A vascular surgeon testified today that several cases of gangrene that Dr. Peter T. DeMarco had treated with his patented drug procaine PVP would have healed just as quickly without any treatment at all.

A New York City Council Committee yesterday said it would act immediately to alleviate three common problems of small businesses throughout the city lack of adequate parking, insufficient security and red tape.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) A Green Bay, Wis., company that furnishes nearly half the hamburger for school lunch programs may have been harassing and even threatening harm to Federal meat inspectors, Assistant Agriculture Secretary Carol Foreman said today.
The Boeing Company, the largest producer of commercial jet aircraft in the non-Communist world, reported yesterday a rise of 80.8 percent in first-quarter earnings.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (AP) Sid Collins, the long-time announcer of the Indianapolis 500-mile race, was found dead at his apartment today, the authorities said.

LONDON, May 2 President Carter, speaking to European television viewers today, proclaimed an "undeviating commitment" to human rights everywhere, and said he would maintain it "until the last day I'm in office."

CAIRO, May 2 President Anwar elSadat appears to have made more of a political gesture than a military commitment in announcing last night that Egypt "will take over the operation of the entire Zarian air force," Western diplomats here said today.
Governor Carey is expected to announce today that he has created a cabinet-level Office of Health Systems Management to carry out his program to keep health-care costs from rising.

WASHINGTON, May 2 Transportation authorities in the House called today for a 3-cent-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes for highway improvements and a separately financed mass transit fund that cities could use to buy buses and trains.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Senate approved today, 63 to 15, a $20.4 billion appropriation bill to finance major portions of President Carter's economic stimulus program, Sponsors said the funds would create nearly one million jobs directly or indirectly.
For the first time in two years the Police Department is considering resuming promotions of officers to the ranks of sergeant and captain, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

Only six years after Swiss women won the right to vote, a woman yesterday assumed one of the highest offices in the land. She is Elisabeth Blunschy, a 54-year-old lawyer who is one of 11 women in the 200-member Swiss national council, the lower house of the parliament. Mrs. Blunschy was elected president of the council, which by protocol is considered the top-ranking position in the country.

LONDON, May 2 President Carter, speaking to European television viewers today, proclaimed an "undeviating commitment" to human rights everywhere, and said he would maintain it "until the last day I'm in office."

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Barring sudden weather problems, world grain production should again outstrip consumption, leaving global reserves of wheat, corn and other food-producing grains at record levels by mid-1978, the Agriculture Department said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 A special tribunal of seven appellate court Justices ruled today that Marshall F. McComb, 82 years old, was senile and therefore unable to perform his duties as a Justice of the California Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The United States still lacks an integrated food-export policy and a systematic approach to monitoring and managing supplies despite five years of repeated crises since the big Soviet grain deals of 1972, the General Accounting Office said today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 President Carter declared today that the nation's present welfare system "should be scrapped and a totally new system implemented."
WASHINGTON, May 2 The House Appropriations subcommittee on Public Works voted today to fund 17 of the 18 water projects President Carter wanted to kill.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 0, that it is generally unconstitutional for a community to prohibit the posting of "for sale" and "sold" signs in front of homes in hopes of stemming the flight of white homeowners and thus maintaining a racially integrated community.

JERUSALEM, May 2 A state comptroller's report that is sharply critical of the Israeli military because of documented instances of waste and ineptitude was the subject today of partisan pre-election debate in Parliament.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 Jerry Koosman lost a fine pitching duel to Doug Rau tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored twice in the eighth inning for a 3-1 victory over the New York Mets. A crowd of 28,017 at Dodger Stadium watched Los Angeles end a losing streak at one game and post its 18th victory in 22 games this season, snapping a three-game winning streak the Mets had acquired in San Diego.

ALBANY, May 2 Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the State Court of Appeals warned today that the practice of law has become so profitable that the profession "tends to attract in certain sectors persons motivated by greed."

WASHINGTON, May 2 An expert committee called today for limits on the acquisition, use and fees for revolutionary new X-ray diagnostic equipment that produces clear cross-sectional pictures of the living body.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The Food and Drug Administration has been lax in enforcing some aspects of laws regulating new pharmaceuticals, a special Federal panel that has been investigating the agency for two years concluded in a report made public today.

ALBANY, May 3 Governor Carey, who last month stirred up a rhetorical storm by denouncing members of the Irish Republican Army as "killers" and "Marxists," said today that he had no regrets about his controversial remarks and went on to add "Maoism"' and "Trotskyism" to his list of the I.R.A.'s offenses.

PARIS, May 3 Twenty-one heads of church statues from Notre Dame Cathedral, chopped off during the French Revolution and believed lost, have been recovered here together with 350 fragments from other statuary.
Florence Dunlap, who had a long career as a stage actress, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She lived at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, and was 94 years old.

BENNY GOODMAN brought something old and several things new to Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, in a concert for the benefit of Planned Parenthood, at which he led both a big band and a small group.

PARIS, May 3 The economic summit meeting in London this coming weekend gives European and Japanese leaders a chance to take the measure of President Carter, regarded here as one of the strongest of recent Presidents.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 Hope gives way grudgingly to logic here at this time of year, so it would be premature to guess how many of the seven 3-year-olds in today's 50th running of the Derby Trial would also start in Saturday's 103d Kentucky Derby.

HONOLULU, May 3 (UPI) President Carter, speaking by telephone to a group of newspaper editors, said today that the Soviet Union was "many years away" from developing a weapon that could neutralize United States missiles.

Maria Theresa Gronich-Runes, editor in chief of Current Digest and co-founder with her husband, Dr. Dagobert D. Runes, of the Philosophical Library, died yesterday at Woman's Hospital. She was 71 years old. She lived at 44 West 77th Street and in Grahamsville, N.Y.

SUMMIT, May 3 New Jersey's campaign for Governor turned into a political flea market today as candidates of both parties met some of the 1,800 employees of the Ciba-Geigy Pharmaceutical Company during a work break.

Carolyn Amory went up to the attic of her country house and dug out a long pleated muslin dress; Nanette Kreizel appeared in a white lace Edwardian number; Eleanor Revson, Jill Middleton, Ann Oxenberg and Jan Chipman looked as though they were off to a garden party, in floral chiffons, embroidered shawls and floral entwined hairdos. That's what happens on the first of May in certain parts of New York.

FOLLOWING HER attendance at her first rock concert, Princess Alexandra, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, popped backstage to chat with the star performer, Elton John. The princess, a vivaciously outspoken woman known to her friends as Sandy, had a straightforward question for Mr. John: "Do you take cocaine?"

LOS ANGELES, May 3 Manager Joe Frazier shook up the New York Met lineup tonight, but not as badly as Burt Hooton of the Los Angeles Dodgers shook it up when they came to bat. The 27-year-old right-hander, who used to torment Met teams for the Chicago Cubs, struck out 10 in the first seven innings and completed a 4-1 four-hitter for the 19th Dodger victory in 23 games.

GENEVA, May 3 The director general of the World Health Organization today urged the breaking of what he termed the "chains of dependence on unproved, oversophisticated and overcostly health technology."

ALBANY, May 3 Senate Republicans, using almost visible arm-twisting, mustered a bare majority today to pass a bill eliminating the $500 "threshold" at which an automobile-accident victim may sue for medical payments under the nofault insurance program in effect in New York State for the last four years.
PARIS, May 3 The United States and Vietnam opened formal negotiations here today "looking toward normalizing relations," in the words of the American spokesman.
The car of a union negotiator in a school custodians' strike in Hicksville, L.I., was firebombed last night outside Hicksville High School, according to the Nassau County police.
MANCHESTER, N.H., May 3 Sleeping bags, arranged in small groups and clusters set in neat rows, cover the concrete drill floor of the National Guard Armory here.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 Philip D. Sprouse, a retired diplomat who served in Nationalist China and later in Cambodia, died here Thursday of cancer. He was 70 years old.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., May 3 The leaders of Conservative Judaism agreed today to form a study group that would produce a definitive judgment within two years on the question of ordaining women.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Defense Secretary Harold Brown today ordered the Minuteman III missile production line kept open for two more months.
"MY DOCTOR WANTS me to open a restaurant," Mrs. Agnes Anderson Johnson explained as she sliced hot Creole sausage in her neat and shiny New Orleans kitchen.

HOUSTON, May 3 A high-level New York City promotion team, expressing strong support for Atlantic offshore oil development, impressed a meeting of oil company executives today by what the oilmen described as the city's "new attitude" toward their industry and toward drilling off the East Coast.

PETROS, Tenn., May 3 (UPI) An attorney for James Earl Ray said today that there was a witness who could place Mr. Ray at a service station on the afternoon of April 4, 1968, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis.
Cancer isn't just a disease. It is a stigma few want to discuss, remaining a study in ignorance, irrationality and fear.

Luciano Pavarotti is a tenor with such a large following that when he gives his recital next Feb. 12, under the auspices of Lincoln Center, he will sing in the Metropolitan Opera House. It will be something of a precedent, because in the classical field only Vladimir Horowitz has given a recital in the 11-year-old structure.

Five years ago, when Americans were spending more money in the cities than in the outlying areas, a transfer of a main-store executive to a suburban store was widely viewed as a ticket to Siberia. But times and the proportion of branch-store volume to total sales have changed.

"Trollstenen" (Swedish for trolls' rock), which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is Gunvor Nelson's 125-minute meditation upon ner relationship to the members of her family in Sweden and the land where she grew up.
At breakfast yesterday, eating a double serving of Rice Krispies with sliced bananas, Mike Torrez was discussing his new team.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 3 Attempting to wrest the political initiative from Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the opposition Pakistan National Alliance today called for nationwide demonstrations on Friday, in defiance of martial law that has been imposed in three major cities.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 After almost eight years and four Federal trials, former Mayor Joseph L. Alioto today was awarded a libel judgment of $350,000, plus costs, against Look magazine, which had said that he was "linked" to the Mafia.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 "We got off to such a poor start," said Merrill Lynch Company's Donald T. Regan, declining today to predict second-quarter performance, "but we're generally constructive on the remaining nine months."

Jack Ramsay will be in the Forum in Los Angeles tonight on a scouting mission. The Portland Trail Blazer coach will watch the deciding game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff semifinal between the Lakers and Golden State Warriors with mixed emotions.
About a year ago, Hartford adopted an ordinance forbidding the posting of "for sale" signs in front of homes.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday voiced opposition to a Securities and Exchange Commission proposal that would permit the agency to obtain more data about foreign accounts with United States brokerage firms.
The Tobin Packing Company, a Rochester meatpacker whose listing on the New York Stock Exchange has been imperiled by continuing losses and depressed market value, apparently has a new lease on life.

WASHINGTON, May 3 A SenateHouse conference compromised today on the bill President Carter wants for his economic stimulus, approving tax cuts for business and individuals but rejecting an increase in the 10 percent investment credit that had been originally proposed to increase capital spending.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (Reuters) The United States today responded to renewed criticism from Pakistan by publishing the text of a private cablegram sent to Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

KINSHASA, Zaire, May 3 (UPI) Zairian and Moroccan troops advancing against an invading force of Katangan exiles in Shaba Province have suffered scores of casualties in the most serious battle since the conflict there began, Western military sources said today.
WEST POINT, May 3 The United States Military Academy paused today to honor Henry Ossian Flipper, who persevered here as a virtual outcast to become West Point's first black graduate 100 years ago.
Earlier this year, Charles W. Fowler, Superintendent of Schools in Fairfield, Conn., made an informal study of the amount of time children spent in school.

IN "The Great Republic," a textbook for adults by six of the heaviest sluggers (see names above) in academic historiography, judgments are rendered with authority and facts with certainty. The book, designed as a history of the American people, is not a flag-waving tract but a surprisingly hard-hitting view of why, somehow, the nation worked. There are heroes and charlatans, great and mediocre Presidents and a Civil War that almost destroyed the Republic.

In a move likely to provoke at least some union opposition, Mayor Beame's office announced yesterday that it would seek to remove hundreds of supervisors from collective bargaining and take other steps to strengthen the hand of management in assigning and hiring civil servants.

SOME WEEKS AGO we reported on a tasting in Paris that attempted to open a new assault on the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux. The article mentioned that Alexis Lichine had proposed an updating many years ago and that Baron Philippe de Rothschild had succeeded in having his Chateau Mouton-Rothschild elevated from the first of the second growths to the status of a first growth, along with chateaux Haut-Brion, Marguax, Latour and Lafite.
WASHINGTON, May 3 "You know," a ranking foreign policy official observed, "no one talks about Vietnam any more."

Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday confirmed reports that the company had received a proposal form Cia, Vale do Rio Doce to purchase United States Steel's 49 percent interest in the Carajas iron ore project in Brazil's Amazon region.

The City Council's Committee on Consumer Affairs voted out a bill yesterday that would require locked gates on certain parking lots that are being used for prostitution. The bill now goes to the City Council, where it is expected to be approved.

AMERICAN BALLET Theater's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House is ambitious, bold and so many of those other adjectives that might be thought more germane to a political platform than an artistic prospectus.

WASHINGTON, May 3 President Carter's Cabinet committee on what to do about the 6 to 8 million illegal aliens in the United States has how sent its recommendations to the White House, and these recommendations raise some fundamental questions of public policy.
A 38-year-old woman of Lido Beach, L.I., was found lying in the living room of her home at 271 Harbor Drive by her 14-year-old daughter at 8 o'clock last night.

The Treasury sold $2.75 billion more of its 7 percent notes maturing in 1984 at an average rate of 7.28 percent yesterday as dealers and investors were somewhat more eager than expected to buy the securities, part of the Government's effort...

In a society where a sizable segment of the public is said to prefer reconstituted orange juice even in a powdered state to the freshly squeezed product, it is scarcely surprising that soups out of cans taste to some palates like ambrosia.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3 Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met in Riyadh today with King Khalid and Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia on what Palestinian sources here described as forthcoming Saudi-American talks on the Middle East.
New Yorkers will have a chance to gamble on two state lotteries beginning next Tuesday. A new $1 weekly lottery will be offered on that day with prizes ranging from $20 to $1 million.
Coach John McVay and the Giant braintrust didn't get Tony Dorsett yesterday. They were very happy, though, gaining two almost-certain starters from the National Football League draft.
NEWARK, May 3 (UPI) Former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark, released from prison five days ago, surrendered to authorities today after the Federal Government went to court to put him back in jail.

WASHINGTON, May 3 Vice President Mondale will emphasize at a meeting with Prime Minister John Vorster in Vienna on May 19 the Administration's conviction that South Africa must abandon apartheid, officials said today.
WITH MOTHER'S DAY just ahead and Father's Day right over the horizon, it seems appropriate to turn some light on the current state of children, parents and grandchildren.

WASHINGTON, May 3 The United States Postal Service began preparing a request today for a rate increase to 16 cents for a first-class letter and a cutback to five days of mail deliveries a week, with both actions to take place early next year.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Occidental Petroleum Corporation had set up two secret companies in Europe and funneled profits from them into clandestine Swiss bank accounts and secret cash kitties for illegal campaign contributions.

FOOD PRICES, continuing their ascent, last week reached the second highest total recorded by the Department of Consumer Affairs since that city agency began its weekly 41-item compilation four years ago.

ALBANY, May 3 (AP) Governor Carey said today he wanted to reorganize the State Athletic Commission, but he declined comment on whether he would remove the commission's chairman, James A. Farley Jr. Farley has suspended himself without pay pending investigation of allegations that he had improperly assisted a boxing promotion group.

CURTAINS DOWN in the theater district. The lights on Broadway shine over the heads of crowds carrying programs, and from curbside a teen-ager approaches a young man wearing jeans and a newsboy cap and holds out a square of paper for him to autograph.

First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti yesterday canceled a list of 200 names of politically connected youths seeking unadvertised summer jobs in New York City. The list had been quietly submitted to the Parks Department by another Deputy Mayor.

NEW ORLEANS Unless they have friends who are New Orleanians, visitors to this graceful old city will have to sample native fare in restaurants, and certainly there is a bewildering array. Since time will probably be limited, it is wise to confine one's eating to those specialties that cannot be found elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, May 3 President Carter announced today that his wife,Rosalynn, whom he described as "a political partner of mine," would visit seven Latin American countries during the first two weeks of June.

A reputed Mafia figure, his brother and five other men were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of conducting a major gambling operation that allegedly accepted "at least $10 million annually in illegal policy wagers" in Manhattan.
The reluctance of union pension funds to purchase long-term New York City bonds could endanger Mayor Beame's plan to put a cap on real-estate taxes, city sources said yesterday.

WILLINGBORO, N.J., May 3 Despite a United States Supreme Court decision ruling that an ordinance in this Burlington County township banning "for sale" signs in front of homes was unconstitutional, real estate people here said today that there would be no immediate move to put them on the lawns of the approximately 480 homes listed with brokers.

VIENNA, May 3 (UPI) Bob Miller of New Hampshire College scored two goals within 3 seconds today to lead the vastly improved United States team to a 4-1 victory over West Germany in the first United States playoff game of the world ice hockey championships.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Congress completed action today on the first of President Carter's economic stimulus programs when the House authorized a $4 billion public works jobs program.

PARIS, May 3 France evacuated the dependents of French technicians yesterday from the Mauritanian iron mining center of Zouerate and said today that it would seek through diplomatic means to free the six French nationals reportedly abducted there over the weekend.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 3 (UPI) Col. Charles William Blyth, U.S.M.C., retired, who wrote the official "Marine's Prayer," died of a brain tumor in a Little Rock hospital yesterday. He was 53 years old.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 3,(Reuters) Indonesia's ruling Golkar movement appeared headed for a comfortable victory as results were reported tonight from yesterday's election for a new central parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 3 A deepening division, both political and philosophical, between President Carter and Democratic leaders in Congress emerged today at a second White House meeting on legislative priorities.

SALZBURG, Austria, May 3 Developing countries are buying and installing nuclear power plants that are less safe than those operating in the supplier nations, according to an American expert, Morris Rosen, who is on the staff of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

BEST BOW FORWARD Finalists in the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's competition for cellists are performing today from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The event is free. This is a rare chance for the public to look in on this group's first contest for just cellists, with concert bookings and cash awards in store for the young winners named by a panel of cello experts.

Residents of big cities, including New York, appear to be mentally healthier than their counterparts in small towns and rural areas, a Columbia University psychiatric sociologist has found in an interpretation of several sources of new evidence.

As poll watchers bemoaned parent apathy and stacks of paper ballots went untouched, voter turnout in community school board elections yesterday was reported even lighter than had been expected, with an estimated 5 percent of all eligible voters going to the polls.

FOR A WHILE at the dinner of the Accademia Italiana Della Cucina, held this month at the Ristorante H. Monello Monday evening, things were a bit chancy for Samuel Bowman.

Prices of old-crop soybean futures jumped the expanded daily limit of 45 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean meal and oil futures were also strong, but the grains were again under pressure.

The Halliburton Company, a leader in oil well services and in construction and manufacturer of industrial and electronic products, reported yesterday a 15.4 percent jump in first-quarter net income to a record $68.1 million, or $1.16 a share. Revenues, however, were unchanged at $1.2 billion from the year-earlier period.

The 52d Hastings International Tournament was won this year by the young Russian grandmaster Oleg Romanishin, who turned in a very high score, 11 -2 , to finish a clear 2 points ahead of the second-prize winner, International Master Shimon Kagan of Israel.

SAN DIEGO, May 3 What had been reported here to be a "handshake agreement" ending the American tuna fleet's deadlocked dispute with environmentalists collapsed today, halting a flurry of preparations for the immobilized vessels' immediate return to sea.

LONDON One principal subject for the NATO summit here next week attended by all chiefs of government except the French President should be Greek-Turkish relationships. Valery Giscard d'Estaing returns to France because that country is no longer integrated into the alliance's command. But Jimmy Carter will stay through the second half of London's diplomatic marathon.

CHICAGO, May 3 After months of behind-the-scenes maneuvering, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops moved today toward an initial major response to the hotly debated packet of reform proposals adopted by the Call to Action Conference last October in Detroit.

DETROIT, May 3 The American family car of 1985, the year when the Carter Administration's plan to drive "gasoline guzzlers" off the road would have maximum effect, is not on the drawing board yet. But a general picture of it can be discerned.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 3 (AP) The Outlet Company, a Providence-based broadcasting and retail company, announced today an agreement in principle to acquire the assets of Hughes Hatcher Inc. of Detroit.
In advertising in some 525 newspapers and on radio stations in 68 markets, American Motors today will try to hook its small cars into President Carter's energy proposals.

Community groups in the prosperous residential Douglaston area of Queens lost a crucial round yesterday in their two-year fight to prevent construction of a building that would contain eight tennis courts and also have an adjoining parking area for 36 cars. The tract is 300 by 200 feet and is adjacent to Alley Pond Park.

The broad market outperformed the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday as advances led declines by better than a 2-to-1 ratio on the New York Stock Exchange. Meanwhile, three issues posted 1977 highs for every stock that hit a new low.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 (AP) A continuance has been ordered on hearings regarding the proposed settlement of the lawsuit between the National Football League and the Players Association.

Dr. Peter T. DeMarco was characterized yesterday as both a "dedicated and attentive physician" and an "incompetent" doctor who lacked "good moral character" at the conclusion of nine weeks of state hearings to determine if his New Jersey medical license should be suspended.

GUATEMALA, May 3 Andrew Young asked Latin American countries today to join in forging a new relationship in the hemisphere in which economic development would be linked to social justice. He assured them that the United States wanted to contribute to the relationship and not dominate it.

NEWARK, May 2 (UPI) Two highranking officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in New Jersey have been indicted in Separate schemes to circumvent normal bidding procedures on federally owned property.

Chrysler directors approved a 10-cent increase in the quarterly dividend to be paid in June from the pattern of 15 cents a share started last summer. At the stockholders' meeting preceding the directors' session, an exceptionally high 20 percent supported stockholders' proposals, opposed by management, to tighten formulas for incentive or bonus pay to top executives and related matters.

JERUSALEM, May 3 Two Arabs were killed today in two clashes involving Israeli occupation forces and Arab protesters near the West Bank town of Jenin, a military spokesman said. One was a 15-year-old boy and the other a 55-yearold woman.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Arthur F. Burns warned today that accelerating inflation "casts a cloud" over the nation's ability to sustain economic recovery into next year.

SAN DIEGO, May 3 (AP) A Federal judge has dismissed a $10.6 million damage suit accusing former President Richard M. Nixon and others of violating the civil rights of two self-proclaimed radical activists.

The United States and Vietnam opened talks in Paris, two years after the Communist takeover of Saigon, aimed at normalizing relations. Rosa Maria Vicien of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pedro Vicien of Buenos Aires, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank Hinckley Milburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn of Old Westbury, L.I. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold Guy Fraiman performed the ceremony in his chambers.

While technically canceled for next fall, "Who's Who," the CBS News magazine show devoted to people topics, will be given another chance by CBS-TV to prove that it can compete for prime-time audiences.

Protesting parents and students from Martin Luther King Jr. High School won a slight concession from the New York City School Chancellor yesterday on a plan to phase out the high school on Manhattan's West Side. The chancellor promised that the plan would not begin during the next academic year.

CANBERRA, Australia-When Tom Steele and his wife decided after five years of unsuccessful marriage to finally get a divorce, all he did was fill out a simple Government form attesting that their marriage had "irretrievably" broken down. Within days he got a 10-minute hearing before the local office of Australia's new Family Court. That was it.

DUBLIN-The Belgian Government has purchased 124 armored cars of a revolutionary design. What has astonished rival arms makers is the fact that the car was designed and made in the Republic of Ireland, which has no history of arms production.

Primroses or primulas are among the best loved of spring's flowers. In their native habitats, they grow with gay abandon in fields, high in the mountains or at the edge of most woods in Asia and Europe. The English primrose is ever dear to our hearts.

NEW HAVEN "The Rose Tattoo" is Tennessee Williams's warmest, most ingratiating play, a romantic comedy with the zestiness and bolsterous humor of a folk tale. In revival at the Long Wharf Theater, starring Rita Moreno, "The Rose Tattoo" seems to have ripened into a popular classic. It is filled with sunshine and optimism.

WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 8 Ch. Harwire Hetman of Whinlatter beat more than 5,700 dogs in two shows this weekend, ending with the Trenton Kennel Club's 48th event tonight at Mercer County Park.

LONDON, May 8 (UPI) President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said today that unless the British-French Concorde airliner was permitted to land in New York, France would "draw same conclusions" about the "real will" of the United States to remove barriers to world trade.

WASHINGTON, May 8 Government agents are investigating possible fraud and abuses that may have cost up to $20 million of the funds spent in the past year for emergency aid to livestock producers in drought-stricken states, according to sources familiar with the inquiy.

In the long run, Jerome Williams, who was accused of petit larceny, found blind justice more reliable a friend than the stranger who claimed to have witnessed everything and came to court to proclaim the young defendant's innocence.

TOKYO, May 8 (AP) A crew member swinging a fire ax subdued a would-be hijacker today who had tried to force a Northwest Orient Airlines jumbo jet with 261 persons aboard to Moscow, authorities reported.

LONDON, May 8 Roy Jenkins, the man who personifies Europe's hopes of unity and independence from the United States, was for a time treated as a second-class citizen by the Europeans during the economic conference here.

Muriel Bishop Rush, daughter of Col. Benjamin Rush 3d, U.S.A., retired, of Alexandria, Va., and the Late Louise Cassard Rush, was married yesterday to Douglas Brown Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner F. Gillespie Jr. of Rye, N.Y.

William S. Noel, vice president for industrial relations of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, makers of air-conditioning equipment, water heaters and shipping containers, died Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 11 Rotary Lane in Summit.

Lynn Caren Rubenstein, associate librarian at the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, was married yesterday afternoon to Seth G. Abraham, assistant to the president of the Major League Baseball Promotion Corporation. Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein performed the ceremony in South Orange, N.J., at tha home of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer A. Rubenstein, parents of the bride.
WASHINGTON With great fanfare, President Carter has announced his proposal for "The Ethics in Government Act of 1977," its purpose "to remove any possibility of hidden conflict of interest."

YONKERS, May 8 The City of Yonkers, which was pulled from the brink of default last year with the help of state supervision of its finances, faces a court test this month on whether the strict supervision will continue for another year or will end on June 30.
WHITE PLAINS, May 8 New York State and Connecticut environmental authorities have finished presenting to the public a plan that would guide the disposal of dredged materials in Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, May 8(UPI) Americans for Democratic Action called today for abolition of the corporate income tax. A resolution said that all corporate income, whether paid in dividends or not, should be "allocated to individual shareholders and these shareholders should pay tax on this income at their own personal income tax rates."

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 8 (UPI) The opposition Pakistan National Alliance today rejected Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's offer to hold preliminary talks on its demands for ending the country's political crisis.
VIENNA, May 8 Although, it was swamped by Canada tonight, Czechoslovakia retained its World hockey title here when the Soviet Union, needing only a tie to take the championship, lost to Sweden.

Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag of New York City took the halftime lead in the Cavendish Club invitational tournament held over the weekend, putting together two strong sessions for a score of 1,467. Weichsel and Sontag, last year's winners, were 201 points ahead of Jack Blair of Tulsa, Okla., and Robert Levin of Miami.

WASHINGTON, May 8 The Carter Administration today stepped up pressure for a partial rollback of steel price increases announced last Friday by the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.
Ivan Nunez may be something less than a virtuoso pianist, but at its best his poised, thoughtful playing Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall brought richer rewards than many a flashier recital.

Julius Hemphill, the saxophonist and Composer, performed "Roi Boye and the Gotham Minstrels," an original, one-man "audiodrama" at the Tin Palace on Sunday. He was costumed in a bright silver minstrel's suit and he improvised on saxophones and flute accompanied by a prerecorded tape.

T. Brooke Price, vice president and general counsel for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from 1951 until his retirement in 1955, died Saturday at a Morristown, N.J., hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 33 Ogden Place in Morristown.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP) Herm Gilliam, a reserve guard for the Trail Blazers, pumped in 14 points in the final quarter, including the go-ahead field goal, to spark the Trail Blazers to a 99-97 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers today The victory gave Portland a 2-0 lead in their four-ofseven-game semifinal playoff series.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 Legislation to restore the death penalty, despite its current popularity in American public opinion polls, has not been sweeping to victories in all the state legislatures debating the issue.
Frederick M. Stern, the author of "The Junker Menace," an expose of the roots of Nazism, died Friday at his home, 45 East End Avenue. He was 87 years old.

Dr. Leonard Rubin wrote recently about the spoilage of tomato paste once the tin was opened and only a spoonful or so was dished out. He also noted that in Europe tomato paste was packaged in tubes much like toothpaste, a much more efficient and less bothersome method for using small quantities.

"Testimony of Two Men" arrived draped in that most admirable intention of providing a quality alternative to the embarrassment of mediocrities being churned out by the commercial networks. The six-hour miniseries, produced by M.C.A. Universal and the various stations involved in the project, represents the first effort of "Operation Prime Time."

WASHINGTON, May 8 In an open break with top Carter Administration economic officials, Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall has questioned the intent and value of an elaborate plan that would require Government agencies to estimate the cost to industry from proposed regulations.

Ken Norton, who is scheduled to face Duane Bobick in a 12-round heavyweight bout Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, held a secret workout" yesterday at the Solar Sporting Club.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) A report prepared for Congress says the Soviet Union and its allies have extended their influence through Angolan society from the military to fishing fleets and that Russian aggressiveness there may indicate a "new, more belligerent Soviet approach" to the third world.

LOS ANGELES, May 8 (UPI) Southern California beat Ohio State, 15-7, 9-15, 15-10, 15-12, last night and captured the National Collegiate volleyball championship at Pauley Pavilion. Pepperdine defeated Rutgers, 15-8, 15-6, for third place.

The Defense Department's planning for the M-X mobile missile program includes a development cost of $5.5 billion and the purchase of 200 to 250 missiles at a cost of $100 million each, according to testimony made public by the Senate Armed Services Committee.

Traverse Clements, national secretary of the American Socialist Party from 1939 to 1942 and manager of Norman Thomas's campaign for the Presidency in 1940, died of heart failure Wednesday in Neuchatel, Switzerland, where he had been visiting. He was 77 years old and lived in Bethel, Conn.

HOLLYWOOD, May 8 Chapter Two," Neil Simon's 17th play, will not reach Broadway until Dec. 1, but it has already been purchased by Columbia Pictures in association with Rastar Productions, it was announced by Daniel Melnick, in charge of worldwide production for Columbia.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 8 The Carter Administration's chief representative to New York City said yesterday that Mayor Beame's budget for the next fiscal year was "not balanced in a true accounting or financial sense" and that the city would probably have to show how it would handle its projected future deficits before it could receive an extension of Federal loan assistance after 1978.

WASHINGTON, May 8 A Democratic Congressman charged today that the Navy establishment and the House Armed Services Committee were seeking to "sub vert" a decision by the Carter Administration and Congress to build smaller aircraft carriers and end the construction of expensive, Nimitz-class, nuclear-powered ships.

NEW HAVEN, May 8 With 1 minute 17 seconds to play today and the score tied, the Cosmos were awarded their first penalty kick of the North American Soccer League season. The current boxing scandal centers on the "United States Boxing Championships," a tournament promoted by Don King, the flamboyant ex-convict and exnumbers racketeer who had become the sports biggest promoter. BOONE, N.C., May 8 (UPI) Nora South Eggers, 87 years old, received from her son and grandson a Mother's Day present that rekindled fond memories. They bought her the Methodist Church building where she attended services as a child and put it in her back yard.

The Citizens Committee for Children of New York, a 170-member leadership group, has named as its new executive director Larold K. Schulz, who has been executive director of the United Church of Christ's Office for Church in Society since 1973.

A 14-year-old boy who spoke broken English and what seemed to be an African dialect, and who had confused immigration authorities and brought Ugandan partisans into the picture by claiming to be a refugee from Uganda, confessed yesterday that he really was a runaway from Honduras. The boy had been found wandering the streets of Manhattan on Friday night, and he convinced the police that he had fled Uganda and reached here as a stowaway.

Suddenly, last year, the American frontier was gone. It was, in fact, officially dispatched. Buried in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 was the repeal of the Homestead Act of 1862. THE DRAMA OF kidney transplantation has made it one of the best known achievements of modern surgery. The decision by a Los Angeles Superior Court judge not to jail Patricia Hearst for her part in a 1974 robbery and shooting spree raises the inevitable question: Is there one justice for the poor and another for the rich and powerful?
