One by one, those in the well-dressed crowd drifted into Jean Bach's handsome home in the Washington Mews, each pausing on the way to where the maid took the drink order to first shake hands with Representative Edward I. Koch.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Two New York Republicans, John W. Wydler of Nassau County and Frank Horton of Rochester, will be playing major roles tomorrow in trying to push an important part of the Carter Administration's economic-stimulus program through a divided House of Representatives.

Plans for a major reduction of air pollution from four large incinerators operated by New York City were announced yesterday by Mayor Beame and the Federal Government. The plans are meant to bring the incinerators into compliance with the Clean Air Act.
TENNIS COURTS are not quite as common in metropolitan area backyards as badminton nets and hibacnis, but they're getting there.

CHICAGO, May 11 (Reuters) Treasury Secretary Michael Blumenthal said today that the Carter Administration was considering a broad reduction of taxes as part of the tax reform package promised for later this year.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) The United States Postal Service, saying that the American Medical Association had underpaid for postage, will sue the association for more than $1 million this week, the A.M.A. says.
MIAMI BEACH, May 11 "If everything goes well," said Irene Rubin, greeting visitors last night to an exhibition of paintings by E. Howard Hunt Jr., "we might take it to New York."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 11 For eight days militant Protestants have tried, with little success, to bring Northern Ireland to a halt with a general strike. Today bus drivers throughout the province refused to work, but not because of any sympathy for the Protestant cause.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 11 Bob Bruno is a 43-year-old club professional who has had his day on the golfing tour, competing for those big purses but never quite striking it rich. He spent six years chasing the young Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer at his peak, and the others who were winners in 1961 through 1966.

Do dogs have a sixth sense and, possibly, even a seventh or eighth? Mrs. Sylvia Fisher of Staunton, Va., believes they do. She shared some of her startling experiences related to the field of extrasensory perception in canines ...

Jean Cruguet, the winning jockey aboard Seattle Slew in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, finally received "his due" at Aqueduct. On Monday, he failed to get the salute from the Big A's announcer always accorded a victorious Derby rider.

TRENTON, May 11 Alan Sagner, the State Commissioner of Transportation, expressed hope today that his department's proposed Transportation Improvement Act of 1977 would be voted on by both houses of the Legislature before they recess for the summer.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The highest budgets ever for the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities $98 million and $96 million respectively for the regular grants programs of each agency have been approved by the House Appropriations Subcommittee for Interior and Related Agencies.

POLDARK," the new Masterpiece Theater series on public television, faces the unsettling, and unfair, possibility of being punished by neglect for presuming to fill the electronic shoes of the recently departed and beloved "Upstairs, Downstairs." Doctors, hospitals and medical societies in New York State have consistently evaded a responsibility to protect the public against harm from incompetent and uunethical physicians, two New York State Assembly committees charged yesterday in a strongly worded interim report after four months of examining medical practice.

MADRID, May 11 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, while flying to Spain for a brief visit, today, avoided raising expectations that his talks next week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would bring a breakthrough in negotiations on arms limitation or even result in a framework for progress.
The Federal Signal Corporation, a company whose shares traded at 2 7/8 a little more than two years ago, has evidently gotten attention from two types of purchasers since then.

ALBANY, May 11 The New York State Health Department has been conducting a federally financed study of the effects of abortion involving 48,000 women, without their knowledge, in what two state legislators charged today was a "massive invasion of privacy."

NEXT TIME you're asking yourself questions, you will undoubtedly ask yourself what the following objects have in common: bowie knives and buttonhooks, trivets and toy banks, beer cans and butter molds, Playbills and paperweights, watch fobs and war posters. I'm happy to provide the answer so that all of us can get on to more important questions, such as "How high the moon?" and "Why me?"

WASHINGTON, May 11 A substantial number of representatives, most of them freshmen or second-term members, demanded today that the House ethics committee step up its investigation into the Korean scandal.

John Gilland Brunini, director of the Temple of Religion at the 1938-39 New York World's Fair and from 1945 to 1949 executive director of the Park Association of New York, died last Thursday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Avenue and 72d Street, where he lived. He was 77 years old.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 11 The development of an electronic intermarket execution system linking the nation's securities exchanges and the over-the-counter market is close to achievement, but important obstacles still must be overcome, securities officials said today.

A Federal judge, citing the primacy of Federal rules, held yesterday the ban on Concorde flights to Kennedy International Airport imposed a year ago pending a study of the effect of the supersonic airliner's operations on other cities was illegal.

Estella Goldstone Fox, the widow of David Fox, who was president of Jay Thorpe, the women's specialty store no longer in existence, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 101 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The House voted tonight, 369 to 20, to approve a $14.5 billion housing and community development bill designed to rehabilitate older sections of the country and relieve overcrowding in the new ones.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) Major West European newspapers were high in their editorial praise today for President Carter and his role here in the international meetings of recent days. Two said he evoked the character of John F. Kennedy.

MISSION, Tex., May 6 In the busy operations room, Gil Rodriquez made a last-minute check of his flying routes, the weather and his targets. Seconds later he was out on the flight line, climbing into the cockpit of a converted C-45 twin-engine transport and starting its engines.
LONDON, May 11 (UPI) Canada is optimistic it can avoid a boycott of next summer's Commonwealth Games at Edmonton by black nations, External Affairs Minister Don Jamieson said today.

To honor National Preservation Week, the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, located at 421 East 61st Street, will join in the closing weekend festivities and open its doors to the public on Saturday, May 14, from noon to 4 P.M. (The museum is normally open weekdays but not Saturdays.)

NEWARK, May 11 Residents of affluent north Bergen County communities served by the Rockland Electric Company today urged the Public Utilities Commission to deny a $7.9 million rate increase requested by the utility, or to reduce it to the bare minimum required to provide reliable and low-cost electric service.

Governor Carey and Mayor Beame remained at odds yesterday over whether they should sit down and talk about politics, especially mayoral politics. But both agreed that their political feud was not preventing them from discussing the business of government.

IN 1967, DEBORAH JOWITT, a dancer and choreographer with an interest in the esthetics of the art, began to wrte about dance. Since then, she has been plunging her readers into dance, re-creating each performance with something very like its original spontaneity. The fruit of those years of uninhibited dancewatching has now been culled in "Dance Beat," Miss Jowitt's first collection of reviews and essays.
HOUSTON, May 11 The Houston Rockets reverted to their two-center lineup tonight and that was the difference as they took an early lead and coasted to a 118-94 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

American International Group Inc., a holding company with a wide variety of insurance operations here, in Canada and internationally, reported yesterday firstquarter net income rose 22.7 percent to a record $29 million, or 92 cents a share, from $23.7 million, or 75 cents a share for the initial three months last year.

John B. Oakes, senior editor of The New York Times, was named yesterday as first S.I. Newhouse Visiting Professor at Syracuse University. He will conduct once-a-week seminars on editorial writing and policy, starting this fall, while maintaining his duties at The Times.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) Edward E. Knourek, an Olympic pole vaulter who in 1916 set a record with a vault of 12 feet 16 inches, died yesterday. He was 85 years old. Mr. Knourek, who retired from competition in 1924, died in a nursing home in the suburb of Berwyn.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Attorney General Griffin B. Bell told Congress today that President Carter's plan for Election Day registration should not be used to weaken long-standing civil rights laws that bar discrimination against minority-group voters in the South and elsewhere.

LONDON, May 11 Prime Minister James Callaghan's Labor Government stirred a political tempest today by naming Mr. Callaghan's son-in-law, Peter Jay, a 40-year-old journalist and broadcaster, as the new British Ambassador to Washington.

SAN DIEGO, May 11 (UPI) The United States tuna fleet was going to sea again today but the boats were commanded by captains and mates who voted to go only under protest against Government restrictions.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 11 Herbert Hoover, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson all have, or will have, libraries and museums to commemorate their Presidencies. It is getting to be almost commonplace, as Paul Henry, the Republican Party chairman in the Fifth Congressional District here, said yesterday.

A man in his mid-20's was stabbed fatally on a street corner off Times Square yesterday afternoon in a confrontation with another man and a woman. Transit policemen seized two suspects after a brief chase.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Treasury Department made it a bit easier today for Taiwanese manufacturers to sell shoes in the United States.
LONDON, May 11(AP) The dollar closed stronger against most European currencies on foreign exchange markets today. The price of gold held steady.

New York City and the municipal employee pension systems reached agreement yesterday on how the pension funds would make their next $1 billion in loans to the city, removing the possibility of yet another fiscal crisis next week.

The head of the State Workmen's Compensation Board accused New York City yesterday of "heartless treatment" of its employees though its failure to pay promptly and properly workmen's compensation for injuries suffered at work.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Israel and its supporters have been engaged in a curious campaign here. They have been warning that a new arms sales policy now under consideration by President Carter would, as one story put it, "limit Israel's ability to receive modern weapons" from the United States. Congress, moved by the alarms, seems likely to attach to the foreign aid bill language commending arms supplies to Israel.

Trading activity on the nation's 10 commodity futures exchanges continued to surge last month as the turnover rose 41 percent from the year-earlier level. For 1977's first four months, volume was up 52 percent from a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) Ignoring a warning that some cities might have to dump their sewage "in the streets," the House Merchant Marine Committee voted 22 to 12 today to ban the dumping of sewage into the oceans after Dec. 31, 1981.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, May 11 Saudi Arabia plans to increase its ability to produce oil by nearly 50 percent between now and 1982, in part to help keep world oil prices down and in part to meet increasing demand, Frank Jungers, chairman of the Arabian American Oil Company, which produces virtually all Saudi oil, said today.

Gimbel Brothers Inc., which recently changed the managements of two major store divisions, is expected to announce this morning the discontinuance of its decades-old corporate buying office, and the shift of that function to an independent office, the Mutual Buying Syndicate.

The American Association of University Professors accused the City University yesterday of disregarding the need for "a reasonable period of notice for those faculty members who faced retrenchment" last year and deplored the universit's overall handling of 1,000 dismissals.

Inventories of crude oil for the week ended May 6 reached record highs for the second week in a row, with supplies at 306.7 million barrels, up from the 300.5 million barrels in the previous week, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

Rita A. McGuire, senior professor of social work at Fordham University's School of Social Service, died at the age of 65 yesterday at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn. She had lived at 245 Henry Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 11 President Carter has invited some key senators to meet with him tomorrow morning to discus their concern that the Administration might be jeopardizing Israel's ability to buy or co-produce advanced American arms.

THE JOB OF A turntable is deceptively simple. Just going in circles seems easy enough. But spinning a record imposes rather stringent demands if the result is to resemble the true sound of music. One of these requirements the absence of "rumble" was treated at length last week. Equally important, the turntable must rotate at a constant rate, or else the music wobbles in pitch, a condition onomatopoeically called "wow."

ALBANY, May 11 The Senate Republican leadership, in a major change of tactics, today dropped its demand for a delay on a vote on whether to institute appointment rather than election of Court of Appeals judges. The delay would have insured one more election for Chief Judge, in 1978.

With her superb artistry, for example, Mary Garden was able to raise many of the feebler Massenet works to a level where they seemed worth watching.

The recollection of old rain on older roofs, of different streets and different ways. Tennessee Williams's new play, "Vieux Carre," which opened at the St. James Theater last night, is a journey into the past, an excursion into an interior, that perhaps once existed, or perhaps once did not.

JERUSALEM, May 12 The Jews of Jerusalem today celebrated the 10th anniversary of the day when the walls and barbed wire that had divided this historic city for 19 years were torn down and Jerusalem was physically reunified.

WASHINGTON,May 12 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit today charging that an insurance holding company, three members of a prominent Louisiana family and seven other defendants violated antifraud laws.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 9 The 35 women who sort and box shrimp at TexMex Cold Storage Inc. are quick with their hands. With the help of machines, they can grade and package for freezing about 6,000 pounds of shrimp an hour. Their base pay is $2.30 an hour; their take-home pay; $2.12 an hour.

MORE THAN MOST of his other scores, the Fifth Symphony of Mahler requires of the listener an act of faith, a predisposition to be persuaded and even overpowered. In inferior performances, the work can seem a series of tenuously connected outbursts of joy and pain, flecked with enigmatic allusions to Wagner, Bruckner and Beethoven, and barely, if at all, held together by the flimsy string of distorted or aborted tunes.

His 131 led Ben Crenshaw, the first-round co-leader.

WKCR-FM, the radio station of Columbia University (89.9 on the dial), begins an adventurous experiment in jazz programming at 6 P.M. today. For 90 continuous hours, through Wednesday WKCR will broadcast the complete recorded works of the jazz musicians who make up Chicago's Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians. On Thursday evening at 8 P.M., tihe first of four live concerts by the association's musicians and groups will take place at Columbia's Wollman Auditorium.
Clara Pilates, who taught an exercise system popular with leading film stars, dancers and musicians, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. She was 95 years old.

CHICAGO Charles Lang, the fictional hero of David Mamet's new play, "The Water Engine," is a lowly punch-press operator and amateur tinkerer. In his home workshop he manages to remove the H from H.O and eureka! he invents an engine that uses plain distilled water as fuel. The effects could have been revolutionary were it not for a small matter of Big Business.

WASHINGTON, May 13-The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today new rules that would require automobile manufacturers to pay for fixing cars that were not meeting Federal air pollution standards while they were in use.

WASHINGTON, May 17 They honored a prophet today. With speeches and dignitaries and with birdsong and sunshine and the rustle of a light breeze in the trees the 127-year-old C. O. canal and towpath were dedicated to William O. Douglas, the retired Supreme Court Justice.
MADRID, May 17 Vice President Mondale today told Prime Minister Adolpho Suarez of Spain. "I think our people are as excited as yours by the way democratic processes are taking hold here."
WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus today postponed sales of oil leases in environmentally sensitive waters off Alaska, California and the southern Atlantic coast.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 17 Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, first abused and then startled an audience of major book publishers by telling them that he is adding the book field and communications in general to a bill he has introduced in the House to study monopolistic concentration in critical American industries.

TRENTON, May 17 The state's Director of Consumer Health Services, Dr. Oscar B. Sussman, has asked Governor Byrne to investigate the practice of assigning two sets of license plates to the state-owned cars of top state officials.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Navy is halting a spying operation that has kept track of port visits by Soviet naval ships and performed other intelligence tasks through business establishments and other covers in foreign nations, Pentagon sources said tonight.

IT HAS COME to my attention that there are those who consider certain foods too conspicuously easy to prepare to serve to guests. This category would presumably encompass many quickly grilled foods such as lean and tender chops lamb chops, for example.

WASHINGTON, May 17 To head off a sharp increase in American tariffs, Japan has agreed to severe limitations of its color television shipments in the United States over the next three years, American and Japanese sources reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 American companies began creating slush funds from which they made political contributions and other secret payments decades before the practice was exposed during the Watergate scandal, according to Securities and Exchange Commission files made public today.

TRENTON, May 17 The State Corrections Commissioner, Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, told prison officials today that they should stop being apologetic and defensive about shortcomings not of their making in correctional systems. He said that they should mount a campaign to "let everyone know what we can and cannot do and why."

PARIS, May 17 President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan, here on a three-day state visit, charged today that peace in the Horn of Africa was threatened by the Soviet Union, embarked with Cuba on "a new form of colonialism" in Africa.

Dorothy Hamill, the 20-year-old Olympic gold medalist in figure skating, was in town yesterday to pick up the keys to a 1977 Ford Thunderbird. It was all part of being voted the 1977 athlete-of-the-year by the readers of womenSports magazine. The magazine's publisher, Billie Jean King, also gave Miss Hamill a special crystal trophy, which Mrs. King called "the symbol of the many faceted accomplishments of women in sports today."

Picciotto, he has written, often poetically, about the Jews of his country.

HAVANA, May 17 The first cruise ship to bring American tourists from the United States in 16 years arrived here today to a reception that was at once spontaneous and staged, happy and sad, and always under the tight control of the Cuban Government.

Annie Laurie Williams, the authors' agent who sold Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" to David O. Selznick for the movies, died yesterday at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. She was in her 80's and lived in Mount Vernon. Miss Williams was the widow of Maurice Crane, also a literary agent.

Governor Carey and leaders of the State Legislature gave their support yesterday to a $4.3 million tourist program that will be conducted by Wells, Rich, Greene. This will require supplemental legislation.

Lucia Baldwin Collins, retired promotion director of Mademoiselle magazine, died at her home in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., on Monday, She was 73 years old and was the widow of Arthur Collins, president of Collins Tuttle, a New York real estate firm.

WHEN Lindy's restaurant in Manhattan closed its doors and ovens in September, 1969, it was the end of a legend in more ways than one. It was fabled for its sturgeon, corned beef and blintzes. But most of all it was renowned for its cheesecakes, which were as integral a part of Gotham culture as Yankee Stadium, Coney Island, Grant's Tomb and the Staten Island Ferry.

AMERICANS abroad often seek the solace of culinary familiarity when suffering from culture shock. If this urge besets them in Europe, one delicacy from home they rarely find, unlike other staples of the American larder, is watermelon. Turkey is now available throughout Europe although it is often smoked. Corn, which until recently was considered suitable only for pigs on the Continent, now is served to people. But watermelon is simply not eaten there.

OVERVIEW--For some years now, Rio de Janeiro has witnessed a relative decline in political and economic importance. The capital has been moved more than 600 miles inland to Brasilia, and with it has gone the power, influencemongering and juicy political gossip--Brazilians call it fofoca--that Rio once monopolized. Sao Paulo has emerged as a far more important industrial, commercial and financial center, and even a lesser city like Belo Horizonte appears to be expanding rapidly.

WASHINGTON, May 21--President Carter has concluded that the system of Western alliances established after World War II under American leadership no longer suffices to meet the challenge of international conditions. He intends to propose a broader international system in a speech tomorrow.

MANY homeowners do not realize that they can have running water around the outside of their houses without much difficulty. Using widely available and easy-to-handle flexible plastic pipe, any do-it-yourselfer can install extra outdoor faucets, a utility sink on his patio or terrace, a backyard shower or a drinking fountain. Or he can run water lines to supply permanently installed lawn sprinklers, eliminating the need to drag wet hoses around several times a week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 Seven years after the United Nations decided that the deep seabed resources are the "common heritage of mankind," negotiators from 150 countries are about to make a new try at breaking a deadlock over who is to mine ocean floor minerals potentially worth billions of dollars and how the profits are to be shared.

To describe Charles Aznavour as a singer or a songwriter, or both, is to overlook the basic theatricality of his performance. On Saturday evening, the first of his two appearances at Carnegie Hall (he also performed there last night), Mr. Aznavour began the process of capturing his audience by simply walking on stage businesslike, matter-of-fact, no flourishes and letting the audience briefly absorb his lean, intense face, punctuated by penetrating eyes under black, emphatic eyebrows.
ROME, May 22 (AP) Vitas Gerulaitis beat Antonino Zugarelli of Italy, 6-2, 7-6, 3-6, 7-6, today and became the first American to win the men's singles in the Italian open since 1960.

WASHINGTON, May 22--John H. Shenefield, the Justice Department's acting antitrust chief, says his staff is "taking a close look" at recent steel price increases and the public statements by steel executives that preceded them.

WASHINGTON, May 22 Proposals for weaker controls on automobile exhaust fumes that may be adopted in the House of Representatives this week would pose a continued threat to public health, according to an analysis just prepared by three Federal agencies.

Mr. Eda, a white-haired man of courtly manner, left the party in March, planning to form his own more moderate political organization, and he had intended to run in the July elections for a seat in the upper house of Parliament. He lost his seat in the lower house in the general election last December.
Teresa Cotterall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Cotterall of Tulsa, Okla., was married yesterday afternoon to Vincent Lagana, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lagana of New York.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 22 A bad performance by their goalkeeper and a worse one by the referee deprived the Cosmos of a victory at Giants Stadium today before 20,407 fans.

More than a third of the disadvantaged students at Hostos Community College in the South Bronx got financial aid under City University's College Discovery Program while improperly collecting publicassistance funds, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

Why has opposition to the offer of an endowed professorship to Henry A, Kissinger multiplied within the Columbia University community in the last two months? What can explain why this offer has provoked such immediate, strong and widespread criticism in this era of apparent political quiescence?

LONDON, May 22 Vice President Mondale suggested today that the United States had cleansed itself of a moral blemish by its strong condemnation this week of South African racial policies, and said that if the white minority regimes in the area responded to appeals for internal reform there was some hope that black Africa could be dissuaded from extreme and violent actions.

The site for a proposed school in Corona, Queens, a six-year battleground between homeowners and the Lindsay administration, is the center of another dispute this time with serious implications for the mayoral race.

Dr. Nancy E. Kemeny, an assistant professor in the department of medicine at Cornell University, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel M. Libby, a resident in internal medicine at the New York Hospital. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mrs. George Haynel in North Manursing Island, Rye, N.Y., by Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Great Neck, L.I.
Eight mentally ill prison inmates, four of them convicted killers, remained at large last night from the Dutchess County facility from which they escaped Friday night, the state police said.

ALBANY, May 22 The chief proponent of "sunset" laws regulations intended to force government agencies and programs to justify their existence or face cancellation has urged the Legislature to wait until next year before adopting a plan for the state.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. One gift shop on Main Street here already has received two orders for an "Official Olympic executive silver-plated paperweight" at $150 each. T-shirts, stickers and other souvenirs are selling well in other stores.

ATLANTIC CITY Even if the Atlantic City casino gambling bill pending in the New Jersey Legislature becomes law within the next month, only one casino is considered to have a chance of opening this year, and may be two to five years before the resort city has enough casinos to become a rival of Las Vegas.
Fortune magazine has announced officially that it will change to a publishing schedule of every other week beginning next January.

LONDON, May 22 Vice President Mondale suggested today that the United States had cleansed itself of a moral blemish by its strong condemnation this week of South African racial policies, and said that if the white minority regimes in the area responded to appeals for internal reform there was some hope that black Africa could be dissuaded from extreme and violent actions.
Justice Harold Baer is expected to attempt to end the long cityJets-Mets dispute in State Supreme Court today by suggesting the Mets allow the Jets into Shea Stadium before the baseball season ends.

It is odd, the avenues the mind can travel if you work in this particular field called food. Years ago my colleague Pierre Franey and I read a newspaper account dealing with a Frenchman who had pleaded guilty to smuggling some $12 million worth of heroin to New York. The account added that he whiled away his time in jail and became famous for his tuna souffles.

WASHINGTON, May 22 There are those who consider Mississippi socially backward, but something startling happened there the other day: The Mississippi Legislature voted to end criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana for personal use.

ATLANTIC CITY Even if the Atlantic City casino gambling bill pending in the New Jersey Legislature becomes law within the next month, only one casino is considered to have a chance of opening this year, and it may be two to five years before the resort city has enough casinos to become a rival of Las Vegas.
Thousands marched along Fifth Avenue yesterday in a jubilant tribute of pageantry and song in the 10th annual Martin Luther King Jr. memorial parade.

After searching the sewers of the South Bronx for several hours last night, sanitation workers found the source of the oil that had been spilling into the Harlem River near East 135th Street at a rate of up to 40 gallons a minute yesterday afternoon.

Elliot Bernstein, who wrote magazine articles and scripts for television, died of a heart attack yesterday at his summer home in Cutchogue, L.I. He was 41 years old and lived at 333 Pearl Street in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI) The Administration announced today that it would increase the United States contribution to the United Nation's Children's Fund from $20 million to $25 million in 1978.

CHICAGO, May 22 A special Cook County grand jury will soon start hearing evidence about widespread pornography and prostitution involving boys. The United States Attorney for the Chicago area began investigating allegations of such practices last week.

HOUSTON, May 22 Seafood salvage buyers, using a Mexican sanctuary, are recycling into the United States large volumes of foreign shrimp and other frozen ocean products that Federal food inspectors rejected as spoiled or contaminated.
The American consumer's inflationincome squeeze proved dramatically evident in the erratic first-quarter results reported last week by the nation's largest retailers.

BALTIMORE, May 22?Seattle Slew, undefeated and by now unquestioned, left the Pimlico Race Course by van today along with most of the horses he overpowered in the 102d Preakness and headed for the final test in racing's Triple Crown: the Belmont Stakes in New York.
Several mysteries that have perplexed grain futures traders for months were solved last week by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.

SAN SALVADOR, May 22 The Roman Catholic bishops of El Salvador accused the conservative military Government of this Central American republic today of "persecution of the church" in the name of anti-Communism.

NASHVILLE, May 22 (AP) Admitting he owned fewer than 100 shares of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, a Nashville businessman, Claude Cockrell Jr., said Friday he was giving up his attempt to take control of the film company.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. One gift shop on Main Street here already has received two orders for an "Official Olympic executive silver-plated paperweight" at $150 each. T-shirts, stickers and other souvenirs are selling well in other stores.

A Civil Air Patrol plane piloted by a 27-year-old woman crashed into a twofamily house in Queens yesterday, killing a 16-year-old air cadet and injuring two other teen-aged cadets as well as the pilot. No one on the ground was hurt.

Al Carmines's continuing love affair with the plays and poems of Gertrude Stein has produced five operas since 1963, and the latest of them, "A Manoir," has been on view at the Judson Memorial Church since April 22 (the final performance takes place tonight).

SCREEN SCENE Registration for the 19th annual American Film Festival starts at noon today at the New York Hilton Hotel. The public again is invited to look in on the daily competitive screenings tomorrow through Friday at the six-day audio-visual assembly of teachers, producers and writers. This is the largest conclave of nontheatrical movies film fare rarely seen in commercial showcases in the world.

WASHINGTON In the still incomplete process of evolving a foreign policy, the Carter Administration has modified the way in which policy is made, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser to the President, has influenced these changes.

QUEBEC, May 22 (AP) Real Cloutier, Christian Bordeleau and Paulin Bordeleau scored two goals apiece today leading the Quebec Nordiques to an 8-3 rout of the Winnipeg Jets. The triumph gave the Nordiques a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven-game World Hockey Association final playoffs.
HIGHLANDS, May 22 New Jersey's coastal waters, which have endured fish kills, black water, the rotten-egg smell of decay and fish that might contain toxic chemicals, appear to be healthy again.

WASHINGTON, May 22 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that the withdrawal of American ground troops from South Korea would not endanger the security of that nation, and made it plain that any military officer who publicly challenged the policy would be punished.
MEMPHIS, May 22 (AP) West Tennessee's madtom catfish, like its cousin to the east, the snail darter, is an endangered species that threatens to tangle a Federal water project.

Ann Esther Schechter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schechter of St. James, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon at her parents' home to Mark Wessel Crouse, son of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Crouse of Woodside, Calif. Village Justice Eugene L. Wishod of Headof-the-Harbor, L.I, performed the ceremony.
Who am I? Martha Graham never answered this question as succinctly as Descartes. It is not enough for her characters to think, they must feel and also battle their way to their destination.

KENT, Ohio, May 22 Students protesting Kent State University's plans to build a gymnasium near where four students were killed in an antiwar protest on May 4, 1970, have camped on the site for 10 days and are vowing to stay until the site is changed or they are evicted. University officials have said that the group will be allowed to remain until construction starts in late June or until a disturbance occurs.

TRENTON, May 22 The New Jersey State Senate has scheduled debate and a possible vote tomorrow on a bill to regulate casino gambling in Atlantic City. The Senate calendar also has 51 other bills listed for discussion during what may be the last full session before the chamber's summer adjournment.
The perjury indictment against Salvatore Nigrone, the law partner of Paul P. Rao Jr., has been dismissed in Brooklyn.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

JOHANNESBURG, May 22 Andrew Young suggested today that South African blacks mount an economic boycott against apartheid and said that it would be hypocritical of the United States, born in a revolution, to condemn violence by blacks seeking freedom from white minority regimes here and in Rhodesia and South-West Africa.

There was a time when the Chief Justice of the United States let the work of the Supreme Court speak for itself. But no more. Besides speaking out vigorously for administrative reform of the court system and for fair pay for judges, Chief Justice Burger has begun to speak in defense of the Court's decisions against its critics.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 22 (AP) Terry Holladay took advantage of a loss of temper by Billie Jean King to score a 6-4 upset that led the Golden Gaters to a 29-20 World Team Tennis victory last night over the New York Apples.

WASHINGTON, May 22 President Carter, in a message to be submitted to Congress tomorrow, will pledge the "unsparing support" of his Administration to the protection of the nation's environment and the preservation of its resources.

Governor Byrne can be seen on television these days conceding that he made a mistake four years ago in failing to see the need for a state income tax and asking the voters to forgive him and give him credit for making tough decisions when they cast their ballots in the primary election for Governor of New Jersey on June 7.

HOUSTON, May 22 Seafood salvage buyers, using a Mexican sanctuary, are recycling into the United States large volumes of foreign shrimp and other frozen ocean products that Federal food inspectors rejected as spoiled or contaminated.
TOKYO, May 22 (Reuters) A.W. Clausen, president of the world's largest commercial bank, said today the prevailing low level of confidence in the world economic community was wholly unjustified.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 "The sky is red." That is the code message that one of the nation's master arsonists telephoned to clients to let them know that their heavily insured property a hotel, warehouse or factory had just been set ablaze.

Jane Sherrill Samuels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jess Samuels of New York City, was married yesterday afternoon to Karl Peter Herbst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Herbst, also of New York City. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Posner in his study at Temple Emanu-El.

A Civil Air Patrol plane piloted by a 27-year-old woman crashed into a twofamily house in Queens yesterday, killing a 16-year-old air cadet and injuring two other teen-aged cadets as well as the pilot. No one on the ground was hurt.

On the level of candidates for the world championship, it can be a tricky business playing to an opponent's weakness. Either he will be very good at covering it up or he will discover that he is by no means as weak in the area of his weakness as he is supposed to be.

Andrea Leslie Port, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Port of Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Myron Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ade Kahn of Woodmere, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the Summit by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman of the Central Synagogue.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 22 President Carter's host here, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, has a record in human rights that makes Mr. Carter look something like a Jimmy-come-lately.
Demonstrators against landings of the British-French Concorde supersonic jet brought out more cars but caused less disruption at Kennedy International Airport yesterday than the week before.

PEEKSKILL, May 21 Nine years ago C. Kennard Robinson, who was involved in this area's volunteer fire departments for 47 years, confided to a friend that "when I go I want to leave this life in style."

A 78-year-old woman shot to death in the Inwood section of Manhattan on May 14, spent the last four years of her life in poverty while she tried to recover $74,000 she had given a friend to build a house, according to court records. The friend's son built the house, but took title to it in his own name, the records say.

Alice Holcomb, an artist who gave a show at the Barzansky Gallery here in 1962, died last Saturday in Sarasota, Fla., where she had been living. She was 70 years old and a resident also of Rockport, Mass., where she had served on the governing board of the Rockport Art Association.
Belmont's race track, which has been shut by a strike of ticket-sellers, will open today. Fans will be admitted free, but there will be no betting on races.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 22 President Carter said today that it was now a propitious time for a settlement in the Middle East and warned that failure to act could be disastrous "not only for the Middle East but perhaps for the international political and economic order as well."

Alice Tully Hall was nearly full at midnight Saturday for an all-Bach "Our Bach" concert featuring the third orchestral suite and the concertos for oboe d'amore in A, oboe and violin in C minor, and harpsichord in D.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 There were the makings of a mystery thriller Thursday and Friday when Gene Shue, the Philadelphia 76er coach, ordered the closing of practice sessions.

For more than 18,000 New York City police officers, the big election the one that is really important does not involve Abraham D. Beame, Mario M. Cuomo, Bella S. Abzug and the other mayoral hopefuls but candidates named Samuel DeMilia, Ken McFeeley and Philip Caruso.

ALBANY, May 22 The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has revised its earlier, more pessimistic projections, and now says it should be able to meet a Sept. 30 deadline for approving all the funds allotted to New York State for sewage-treatment projects, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner said today.

Children are irresistibly drawn to "The Nutcracker" at any time of the year, as one could clearly observe Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House on a hot day in May. Hordes of them came to see Mihail Baryshnikov's production of the story, which had its first clutch of performances in New York last week by American Ballet Theater and no doubt will be receiving many more.

As the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey prepares for the replacement of its retiring chairman, William J. Ronan, and for the arrival of a new executive director, it has been hit by three legal decisions. Two were mere jabs; the third, a haymaker. Unless it can shake off the effects of that last blow, the authority might as well prepare to take the count.

CINCINNATI, May 22 In one of the most far-reaching shake-ups in the 107year history of the National Rifle Association, voting members of the organization ousted today most of their top elected and paid officials.
Juliann Terese Cucolo was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Gerard Beeson, a trial lawyer with the criminal division of the Department of Justice in Washington.

Several passengers reportedly received skinned knees and other minor injuries last night during an emergency evacuation of an American Airlines DC-10 that returned to Kennedy International Airport a few minues after it took off because of a telephoned bomb threat.

John Grierson, a British aviation pioneer and author, died after a stroke Friday night at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He had been visiting the United States in connection with celebrations commemorating the traps-Atlantic flight of Charles A. Lindbergh.
PARIS, May 22 The blast furnaces are growing cold all over Europe and many may never warm up again.

Ron Guidry's lively left arm and some previously quiescent New York bats salvaged a split of a doubleheader for the Yankees against the Baltimore Orioles yesterday at the Stadium.
Louise Reynolds doesn't much like being a secretary, but at least her salary lets her do what she wants to do in the evenings and on weekends: publish her own little magazine.

WASHINGTON, May 22 For years, professional money managers have commented among themselves, not without envy, about the very high salaries paid to those who run the group of mutual funds that includes the Massachusetts Investors Trust.

His actions have shown him unfit to teach here, and Columbia should not hire him."
MONTE CARLO, May 22 Hats off to the Walter Wolf racing team.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 22 George Haines Jr., a 33-year-old teacher in Philadelphia who plays out of New Jersey's Somerset Hills, won the 67th Travis Memorial golf tournament today, beating Jerry Courville of Shorehaven in Connecticut, 2 and 1, in the 36-hole match-play final.

BOSTON, May 22 Suddenly we were back in the emotions of Vietnam. There on the screen was Richard Nixon, refusing to "bug out," rejecting the "easy political past," acclaiming the invasion of Cambodia as "one of the most effective operations of the war" and refusing to notice that the patient had died.

OAKLAND, May 22 A lone skydiver parachuted from a plane 2,500 feet above the recreation fields of this westernmost borough of Bergen County today, and descended into the middle of thousands of cheering people gathered for the 75th anniversary of the borough's incorporation.

WASHINGTON, May 22 Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that the withdrawal of American ground troops from South Korea would not endanger the security of that nation, and made it plain that any military officer who publicly challenged the policy would be punished.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The United States Government especially the Departments of Commerce, Transportation and Treasury "has not emphasized enforcement" of the United Nations sanctions against Rhodesia, the General Accounting office reported today.
In the closing days of his Presidency, Richard M. Nixon considered granting pardons to everyone involved in the Watergate scandal, Newsweek magazine reported yesterday.

Warren E. Cox, a longtime antiques dealer and an authority on porcelain and pottery, died yesterday in his apartment at 201 East 37th Street in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and had been ill for several years.

DUBLIN, Ohio, May 22 The rain falls on rich and poor alike, even on Jack Nicklaus and his golf tournament. In fact, completion of the closing round of the Memorial Tournament had to be postponed tonight because of rain, lightning and flood conditions.

BILBAO, Spain, May 22 Wiping away tears, Dolores Ibarruri, president of the Spanish Communist Party, today made an emotional public return to her native Basque province of Vizcaya, which she last saw in 1936 just before the Spanish Civil War exploded.

WASHINGTON, May 22 There are those who consider Mississippi socially backward, but something startling happened there the other day: The Mississippi Legislature voted to end criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana for personal use.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I, May 22 Sunshine, a 12 1-2-pound Shih Tsu owned by Victor Joris, the fashion designer, was judged best in show over 1,600 dogs tonight at the 75th Long Island Kennel Clubevent on the Hofstra University campus.

Rabbi Harold H. Gordon, executive vice president of the New York Board of Rabbis, died Saturday night in Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 22 Harvard's varsity crew beat Yale for the 15th straight year today in the nation's oldest intercollegiate sports event, this time raced over two miles on the Thames River, which has been the race site for many of the last 99 years.

Sergiu Comissiona chose to conduct four nicely contrasted works for his guest appearance with the American Symphony in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, the final concert of the orchestra's season. Although the music could not have been more varied, the pieces had one common denominator they were all very much concerned with sonority and provided a real test of an orchestra's virtuosity.
Using a map to plot the advance, Dr. Thomas C. Abruzzo watched this year as measles and rubella (German measles) broke out in every community in Nassau County.
MIDDLETON, Wis., May 16 The debate over decriminalization of marijua na in this town of 12,000 people officially ended some time ago, but feelings on the subject still run deep.
Measured by the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, which is down 7 percent this year the stock market's performance of late has been less than spectacular.

WASHINGTON, May 22 Chile's military Government has been accused in a report by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights of continuing to carry out arbitrary arrests, torture and murder of Chilean citizens suspected of being its enemies.

TEANECK, May 22 "If I were a girl, I would cry," Leroy J. Thomas said as he waved vigorously to get the attention of his son at Fairleigh Dickinson University's commencement exercises for 1,600 students here today.

ALBANY, May 21 The Legislature is considering a series of adjustments to the laws governing juvenile justice, intended to forestall moves for more sweeping changes in the Juvenile Justice Reform Act from some legislators who feel the act does not go far enough in handling juvenile crime.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22 Two fine defensive plays in the ninth inning allowed Catholic University to defeat St. John's, 4-3, in the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's District 2 baseball playoffs this afternoon. Catholic thus advanced to the National Collegiate regional playoffs in Middletown, Conn., beginning Thursday.

Menahem Begin, whose right-wing Likud bloc emerged from elections last week as the strongest political force in Israel, said on an American television program yesterday that it would "play into the hands of the Soviet Union" for his nation to accept a return to its pre-1967 borders.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 21 The reported decline of violence in the fall lineup of network TV programming has not affected its popularity as a topic for debate in advertising circles.

Beatrice Hacker, wife of Louis M. Hacker, the retired dean of Columbia University's School of General Studies, died Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness. She was 77 years old and lived at 430 West 116th Street.

Power, in the form of 19 home runs, ran wild in three major league baseball games at Pittsburgh and Boston yesterday. The Pirates routed the Dodgers, 11-4, and sent Don Sutton to his first loss in seven decisions. Ten of the Pirates' runs were produced on homers by Omar Moreno, Dave Parker (two, including a grand slam), and Al Oliver.

The marriage of Martha Ann Revit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Revit of Harrison, N.Y., to Steven Richard Resnick, son of Robert Resnick of Port Jefferson, L.I., and Mrs. Edward Lombardi of New York, took place yesterday at the Pierre. Rabbi Saul J. Teplitz performed the ceremony.

LOS ANGELES, May 22 In a decaying Jewish neighborhood below Beverly Hills, where bagel bakeries and knish shops send enticing smells out onto Pico Boulevard, a small Egyptian minority struggles to find a foothold in America.

Charles L. Schultze, President Carter's plain-spoken chief economic adviser, ran into considerable skepticism in Washington last week from a distinguished business audience when he sought to lay out the Administration's four-year goals and say how Mr. Carter meant to achieve them.

Norman D. Archer, a former chief of the indictment bureau in the Queens District Attorney's office, was convicted last night of sharing in a $15,000 bribe to fix a criminal case.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed yesterday a State Supreme Court justice and reinstated the murder conviction of a cab driver who, it was charged, had killed a man to whom he had lost $1,000 in a card game.
JIDDAH, Saudi Arabia "You can do almost anything you want with oil," it is often said here, "except drink it."

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) The Supreme Court ruled today that individuals are subject to the Federal ban on sending obscenity through the mail even though the state where they are acting has more permissive standards.

Two specialist firms on the New York Stock Exchange that operate as a single unit lost their registration as a specialist in the common stock of a listed company because of violations of regulations, the exchange announced yesterday.

A year ago Muhammad Ali fought someone named Richard Dunn in Munich, and, to the great delight of NBC, 65 million watched on television in the United States. In Montreal last year five Americans won Olympic gold medals in boxing, and ABC earned golden ratings.
The heart may go out to Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, who lost his job in South Korea for denouncing President Carter's new policy there. But the mind must applaud the President.

TRENTON. May 21 Angelo Bruno, reputed head of organized crime in the Philadelphia area, agreed today to testify before the State Commission of Investigation to avoid going back to prison for contempt of court.

Profits of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange dropped sharply in the first quarter, as tradingg volume, and therefore commission income, sagged. Net earnings amounted to $34.7 million, compared with $215.1 million in the first quarter of 1976 and $111.5 million in last year's fourth quarter.
JERUSALEM, May 23 Menahem Begin, the head of the right-wing Likud political bloc and the man slated to be Israel's next Prime Minister, was taken to a hospital early today suffering from chest pains.

A leader of demonstrations against landings of the Concorde supersonic plane at Kennedy International Airport said yesterday that he had made a "hardship" appeal against the dismissal of an airport worker who took part in Sunday's protest against the BritishFrench craft.
AUGUSTA, Ga., May 23 (UPI) The First Augusta Bank and Trust, which was declared bankrupt on Friday opened for business today after being acquired by the First National Bank of Atlanta.

The stubborn World Hockey Association, ever hopeful of consolidation with the National Hockey League, strengthened its image yesterday and scored a psychological victory over its rival with the announcement that Gordie Howe and his sons Mark and Marty had signed a multimillion dollar contract to play for the New England Whalers.

In Washington today, hearings resume before the Metcalf subcommittee inquiring into the accounting profession. Today's sar witness before the Senate group is to be Harvey Kapnick, chairman of Arthur Andersen Company and a mover and shaker within the accounting world.
TRENTON, May 23 The State Senate approved today a 98-page bill for the regulation of casino gambling in Atlantic City.

DUBLIN, Ohio, May 23 Jack Nicklaus went through the formality of playing three holes this morning to complete the victory in the Memorial Tournament he actually had locked up yesterday before rain and lightning deferred the finish.
President Carter has clearly indicated that he will seek ways to reduce the soaring costs of health care in this nation, and hospitals reportedly are already feeling the squeeze.
MOSCOW, May 23 The official press agency Tass said today that there was "still a long distance to be covered" before a new Soviet-American agreement limiting strategic weapons could be concluded.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that it was eliminating a Federal form widely used by college students applying for Government financial assistance.
Michael W. Moynihan, the younger brother of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, is directing the public relations for the visit of Saudi Arabia leaders to Washington this week.

John Milton Lacey, special agent in charge of the office of investigation, United States Customs for the Treasury Department in Newark, died Saturday in Jersey City Medical Center of injuries received in an automobile accident. He was 47 years old and lived at 1792 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 23 Scientists in California reported today that bacteria bred in laboratories have been engineered to make the gene for insulin, a development that could provide a virtually limitless supply of the vital hormone and have an important impact on the treatment and understanding of diabetes.

The prime rate of major domestic banks is expected to increase this week to 6 percent from 6 percent, according to William C. Bigelow, a vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank in charge of international money market operations.

Ulmer's "Americaner Shadchen" ("American Matchmaker"), the Yiddish film that opened yesterday for a run through Sunday at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

Alfred Schild, a Univerisity of Texas physicist who pioneered many advances in the interpretation, verification and application of Einsten's theories of relativity, died yesterday in Downers Grove, Ill. He was 55 years old.

TOKYO, May 24 (UPI)--Following the recent agreement to limit Japan's export of color television sets to the United States, the Japanese steel industry will shortly urge the Government to start negotiations with the United States for a similar accord, steelmakers said today.

Florio has decided it is even more dangerous politically to tax people's credibility than their pocketbooks and is basing his campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination on town meetings dsigned to give his views on state issues a complete airing.

"Now be sure to write down your cute name and your little telephone number so I can call ya' to come back, honey, dahlin'" urged Lucy Parlange, the effervescent mistress of Parlange, the plantation house on False River that has been in her husband's family since it was built in 1750.

WASHINGTON--When Jimmy Carter was elected President, the two new Democratic leaders in the Congress-- Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia and Speaker Tip O'Neill of Massachusetts--had one major question: Would Carter really negotiate with them in private on a legislative program, or try to work around them by appealing over their heads to the people.

HARTFORD, May 24--The much-debated and much-lobbied bill that would ban flip-tap cans and require that deposits be paid on beer and soft-drink bottles in Connecticut appeared today to have been blocked for another year.

Brad Park, the former Ranger defenseman who was among the Boston Bruins recently swept by the Montreal Canadiens in the four-game Stanley Cup finals, said yesterday that his team "merely had run out of games" in the National Hockey League series.

In a move designed to sharply expand the computing power of programmable pocket calculators, Texas Instruments Inc. yesterday demonstrated calculators with clip-in "libraries" of up to 5,000 program steps, or distinct instructions.

Every week 4-year-old Gena Candy plays with brightly colored toys, watches "Sesame Street" and sometimes has a spelling lesson--at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City. She is one of 50 children who do just that while their parents visit inmates in the short-term Federal correctional facility on Park Row. It is all part of a new prison day-care program sponsored by the Federal Bureau of Prisons and the Children's Television Workshop.

A stay barring the start of Concorde test flights to Kennedy International Airport was extended yesterday to June 1 by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, May 22--The Arabs have added yet another financial institution to their growing array--the latest venture designed to emulate the well-known International Monetary Fund.

MONTREAL, May 24--Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Liberal Party gained a seat in the House of Commons today after winning five out of six by-elections.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Like a trial lawyer in defense of his client, Senator Edward M. Kennedy tried today to prove in a public forum the case for the Carter Administration's proposal to limit the rise in hospital costs.

The nation's fourth largest automobile company, the American Motors Corporation, yesterday designated Gerald C. Meyers, 48, as president and chief operating officer. VIENNA--Behind the japanned screen of courtesy which masked the colloquy on southern Africa's future between Vice President Mondale and Prime Minister Vorster, there raged potentially explosive disagreement. Fie on calendars and bird watchers: Warm weather stimulates al fresco appetites and, with the arrival of Memorial Day next Mon day, epicurean minds are irresistibly drawn to thoughts of charcoal-grilled foods and other delights of feasting in sunlight and shade.

Back in the feudal age of 1975 when baseball players were owned outright by their employers, Peter Seitz decided that the contracts of two pitchers named Andy Messersmith and have McNally meant what they said. JOHANNESBURG, May 24--A leader of the reform wing in the South African Cabinet suggested today, for the first time in public, that the 10 million blacks living outside their tribal homelands could gain representation in a new national political system that would supersede the existing Parliament, in which all political power is held by whites.

The United Steelworkers of America took another long step yesterday toward establishing a pattern of lifetime income security for industrial workers. BOVENSMILDE, the Netherlands, May 24--The South Moluccans who kidnapped 105 Dutch school children and five of their teachers here yesterday morning shattered the middle-class calm of this suburban settlement of ordered brick houses along a canal. Old wounds of Dutch society--racial prejudice, fear and the strains of colonialism--were opened and some townspeople believe they will take years to heal again.

LONDON, May 24 (AP)--Gold prices fell below $146 an ounce on European bullion markets today for the first time in more than a month, and the dollar had a narrowly mixed day on currency exchanges.

IN "PATRIOTIC GORE" Edmund Wilson wrote of Harriet Beecher Stowe: "[She] had got rid of Calvinism; she had dramatized the teaching of Jesus. Yet her God was still a God of Justice rather than a God of Love. Her pity runs to sentimentality, which is to say that it sometimes seems false; but she is never an obnoxious moralist: Her judgment of men is quite sober and her judgment of ideas quite sound."

THE NATIONAL Book Awards program is changing hands again. After two unhappy years of marriage, the administration of the program is being divorced from the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters. Instead, the Association of American Publishers will go it alone, assuming responsibility for administration, financing and selection of the panelists who vote for the winners in poetry, fiction and major nonfiction categories.

IT IS TRADITIONAL by now with the Nev: York Philharmonic's "Promenades" that one group of concerts each season is devoted to dance music of various kinds. This year's installment was introduced at Avery Fisher ball on Wednesday night for the first of four performances.

EARTH WORMS" at Playwrights Horizon is the third play by the furiously talented Albert Innaurato to surface in New York this season. In common with its predecessors, "The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie" and "Gemini," currently at Broadway's Little Theater, the new play is a black comic version of a rapacious society consuming its young.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 26 Caesars World Inc. of Los Angeles was reported today to be completing negotiations to lease two Boardwalk properties for a new casino hotel. Such a purchase would be the first of Atlantic City property by owners of a Las Vegas casino hotel since Nevada adopted a law last week permiting companies holding Nevada casino licenses to conduct gambling businesses in other states.

With reports that soybean exports by Brazil were running at twice the rate of those from the 1976 harvest futures prices of that commodity closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Brazil is outranked as a soybean exporter only by the United States.

Textron Inc., a conglomerate based in Providence, R. I., said yesterday it had reached a tentative understanding with Solvay et Cie. of Brussels to acquire 2.7 million shares of the Allied Chemical Corporation, which is owned by Solvay.

A certified public accountant was acquitted of charges of mail fraud, stack fraud, and conspiracy by a Federal jury in New York yesterday in a case that raised the issue of the responsibility of an accountant in the preparation of unaudited financial statements.

BALTIMORE, May 26 Publishers of Baltimore's daily newspapers agreed today, in settlement of a state civil antitrust suit, to a 10-year injunction against any agreement to fix retail or wholesale prices of the papers and to rebate an estimated $187,000 to subscribers in restitution for simultaneous price increases instituted in August 1975.
LONDON, May 26 (AP) The price of gold fell sharply in Europe today while the dollar was narrowly mixed.

JERUSALEM, May 26 Menahem Begins choice of Moshe Dayan to be foreign minister in a government led by Mr. Begins Likud Party caused a disruption in coalition talks between Likud and another political party today and produced a furious reaction in Mr. Dayan's Labor Party.

To restore a full school day in September, Mayor Beame is prepared to grant the Board of Education least $10 million extra, an amount that is less than the board wants but more than it is likely to get from the City Council and the Board of Estimate, city officials said yesterday.

FRANKFURT, May 36 (Reuters) West Germany released today figures that showed a continued large trade surplus last month.

IF MEMORY and records serve, the work of Seiijiro Uchikawa, the director-writer, had not surfaced here before the arrival yes- terday of "Tange-Sazen," the latest offering in the Regency Theater's Japanese film series. More than anything else, it indicates that the prolific Nipponese movie industry is not suffering from any dearth of directors or Samurai sagas.
A 25-year-old Ulster County man was arrested last night and charged with the kidnapping of a wealthy 30-year-old woman whose body was found in a shallow grave, dead of several gunshot wounds.

WASHINGTON, May 26 President Carter threatened today to use his veto power it Congress voted what he called "excessive" increases in spending, but Congress did not appear to be in a mood to heed such warnings.
STOCKHOLM, May 26 (AP) An unarmed hijacker who pretended to be carrying explosives seized a Soviet domestic airliner today and forced it to fly to Sweden.

ON A FINE spring afternoon one of the best places to be is the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y. You may not picnic, and you may not play games, but you can walk as you wish on hundreds of acres of spectacular country. Green hills abound; centenarian forests grow ever more majestic; deer, fox and raccoon add a four-footed garnish.

ATLANTA, May 26 (API) With 57 players in the field of 156 unable to finish because of a late afternoon thunderstorm, the first day of the $200,000 Atlanta Classic golf tournament ended with the opening round incomplete.

Albert King made a decision yesterday, but it wasn't the one that had been expected. The basketball star from Fort Hamilton High in Brooklyn decided to withhold the announcement of where he would go to college. The reason

LONG DISTINGUISHED by the diversity, originality and modest prices of its restaurants, Greenwich Village has in recent years been the breeding ground for a new sort of eating place: the small, storefront cafe-restaurant with a limited menu of carefully turned out specialties. John G. Heimann, a Democrat and early Carter supporter was nominated yesterday as Comptroller of the Currency. The appointment by President Carter, which was expected, is subject to confirmation by the Senate.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The House approved an amendment to its new cleanair legislation today to relieve New York State from imposing tolls on the free bridges across the East and Harlem Rivers.

Convinced that the vote mix in New York City mould put him into the mayoral runoff-and that he would win it Representative Herman Badillo, who lost to Mayor Beame in the Democratic mayoral primary runoff in 1973, has all but decided to declare for the Democratic nomination.
A consolidation of United Way campaigns in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area which sponsors believe would more than double total contributions was announced yesterday.
ASSEN, The Netherlands, Friday, May 27 South Moluccan terrorists today released all the children they had held hostage in the Boldensmilde school near here.

The Board of Estimate yesterday postpolled action on Mayor Beame's request for $1 million in Federal job funds for the B'nai Torah Institute, a Brooklynbased social-service agency that is under investigation by three Federal agencies

For Adam Makowicz, the red-bearded, blue-eyed, 36-year-old Polish jazz pianist, who is making his first American appearance at the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street, every day is "totally music." In addition to playing five hours from 8:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. every night (except Sunday) at the Greenwich Village nightclub, he practices three to four hours every day and also composes.

JOHANNESBURG, May 26 Support appears to be building within South Africa's ruling National Party for constitutional changes that would offer political power to the 2.4 million people of mixed race and the 700,000 Indians, but there has so far been scant high-level backing for a proposal that the reforms be wid ened to include blacks living outside the rural "homelands" areas set aside for blacks.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (Reuters) The productivity gain in the private business sector was revised upward to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.7 percent in the first quarter from the 3.2 percent originally reported, the Labor Department said.

A combination of rising industrial production, strong consumer spending and an ample supply of mortgage money pushed construction contracts to a new high in April, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
BLEECKER STREET, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, is a seven-block stretch, 1,500 feet long, that offers more an tiques shops-20-and a greater variety of vintage wares than anywhere else in town.

Esmark Inc. holding company for Swift Company, the world's largest meat packer, reported yesterday earnings declines of 22.8 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 25.3 percent for the halfyear ended with April. The lower results were attributed mainly to continued weakness of the Swift subsidiary, most other operations were well ahead of last year, according to Robert W. Reneker, chairman.

WASHINGTON WHEN JEROME KILTY stitched together the correspondence between George Bernard Shaw and the ac tress Mrs. Patrick Campbell for the play "Dear Liar" he was building ingeniously, but upon sand.
A statewide harness racing strike was averted yesterday when the Legislature agreed on a relief bill that was promptly attacked by the tracks, labor and Governor Carey.
A study of 100 private colleges and universities has concluded that, contrary to widespread belief, independent institutions are holding their own in competition with their public counterparts.

Sylvia Syms could scarcely have asked for anything more at her Town Hall concert on Wednesday evening. She was in excellent voice-strong, full, completely responsive to even her most gentle nuances. She had, miracle of miracles, a sound system that projected her voice cleanly, clearly and naturally. She looked gorgeously sunny and cerrulean in a loose, flowing powder-blue gown. And she had a large adoring audience that applauded eagerly at even her slightest cue.
While the Pittsburgh Pirates breeze along in first place in the National League's Eastern Division, the battle continues between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Philadelphia Phillies.
ASSEN, the Netherlands, Friday, May 27 South Moluccan gunmen have released all 105 child hostages held in a schoolroom in a Dutch village, a Justice Ministry announcement said today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The United States had a record trade deficit of $2.6 billion in April and may register an unprecedented $20 billion deficit for the full year, the Commerce Department said today.

Cook Industries Inc., one of the Big Six commodity trading houses and a leading grain exporter, said yesterday that Willard R. Sparks, senior executive vice president and third-ranking officer of the company, had resigned. Mr. Sparks, 39 years old, also resigned as director of the company's agriproducts group.

While a handful of experts focused their attention on the final of the Reisinger knockout team championship, 1,200 players will be looking for successes in the Eastern regional championships beginning today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

The nine known dead in the Everard Baths fire were identified yesterday, mostly by friends rather than family members, as District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan announced an investigation as to whether criminal violations of the fire and building codes might have caused the blaze Wednesday.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 26 Briarcliff College may live after all. It received a reprieve today, a few hours before the graduating class was preparing for what was expected to be the final commencement of the 75-year-old women's college.

New York City and its major commercial banks were reported close to agreement yesterday on an intricate legal formula clearing the way for a bank "stretch" in the maturity dates of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds a step that would yield $250 million vital to Mayor Beame's proposed budget.

A CURIOUS but pleasant program was presented in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night by Accion Cultural Argentina, an organization formed by Argentines in the United States to promote the culture of their country. It was the first concert it had sponsored, and it fell on the 167th anniversary of the establishment of Argentina's first government.
SUMATRA, Fla., May 26 (AP) Lightning strikes ignited five new fires in Apalachicola National Forest today, diverting some of the crews that had contained a 7,000-acre blaze burning since Monday.

Bert Lance, director of the Office of Budget and Management, said here last night that the Carter Administration wanted the recent steel price increase "to come in at 5 percent instead of 6."

A new 24-hour, two-man police substation in the Times Square area was heraided amid a flurry of speechmaking yesterday by a host of city officials including Mayor Beame and Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd.

WOOD-RIDGE, May 26 The case of a Manhattan cabinetmaker arrested here on Mother's Day for illegally carrying eight prescribed tranquilizers in an unmarked vial was referred tonight to the county Brand jury.

One man was killed and four others, all believed to be members of the Jamaican religious sect known as the Rastafarians, were wounded last night in an exchange of gunfire in Brooklyn, the police reported.

ALBANY, May 26 The New York State Senate passed today, by a vote of 36 to 14, a bill that could increase an industrial competitive-bidding war that has developed in recent months between New York and Pennsylvania.

Belmont Park's labor dispute took a turn for the worse yesterday when electricians complaining of "death threats" blocked an attempt by management to use administrative personnel as parimutuel clerks.

WASHINGTON. May 26 President Carter, emphasizing the "staunch" commitment of the United States to South Korea, defended the Administration's plan to withdraw American ground troops there and expressed confidence today that it was strong enough to repel attack.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26 (AP) Gov. Marvin Mandel today vetoed a bill that would have restored the death penalty in Maryland, saying that the measure was so poorly drawn that it would lead to a series of court challenges.

The stock market, showing its best gains in the final half-hour of trading, staged a mild rally yesterday after a fiveday selling spree that carried the Dow Jones industrial average to a 16-month low.

The city won its fight last night to keep the Jets in New York, when the Mets bowed to court pressure and permitted the football team into Shea Stadium during the baseball season. WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission accused the Falstaff Brewing Corporation, its chairman and two former officers today of violating securities fraud and reporting laws.

MEXICO CITY Five months after President Jose Lopez Portillo took office, conservative forces in Mexico appear to have recovered much of the ground lost during the reformist administration of his predecessor, Luis Echeverria Alvarez.

LOS ANGELES, May 26 H.R. Haldeman, White House chief of staff under President Nixon, today expressed displeasure with Mr. Nixon's explanation of the Watergate affair and said that his own version of the cover-up would be presented in a book scheduled to be published this fall.

The Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research plans to begin a controversial type of genetic experimentation known popularly as gene-splicing, executives of the midtown Manhattan institute said yesterday.

IT DOESN'T HAVE quite the dimensions of the Mark Rothko case, but a court battle is in progress over the ownership of paintings by the late Arnold Friedman (1872-1946), an artist little known to the public but much praised by leading critics.

For his United States debut as the star of a television advertising campaign James Coburn; the actor, was given the simplest script in years. In each of the three spots he delivers only two words: "Schlitz Light."

ST. SIMONS ISLAND. Ga., May 26 (UPI) President Carter climbed into blue jeans today as soon as he got to the retreat where he will spend the weekend, adding that he was "looking forward" to a nine-hour trip on a nuclear attack submarine.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (Reuters) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today cleared President Carter's nominations of Malcolm Toon as Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Arthur A.Hartman as Ambassador to France.

MIAMI, May 26 Three top Florida Democrats with close ties to the White House suffered a considerable loss of prestige with the defeat of their handpicked candidate yesterday in Little Havana's community election here.

WASHINGTON, May 26 The House of Representatives passed today a bill to amend the Clean Air Act of 1970 after first adopting a provision that would further delay and permanently weaken controls on automobile exhaust fumes that constitute a potential health hazard.
AMBON, South Moluccas, May 26 Three times in the last 20 years the authorities here have sent policemen to arrest a man living in a small home on a side street.

Barbara Kirk Cavanagh and Davison Winchell Grant, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in Grace Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. Christopher F. Allison, performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON Their average age is 70, but they are running about Washington like a bunch of college kids. They are a group of 90 elderly people participating in a Congressional internship program that emphasizes governmental services for the aging.

AREA A Fishing has not been good in this area in recent days, but a few flounder ranging from 4 to 15 pounds have been caught with smelts, clams, minnows, spearing and bloodworms. A few large-sized striped bass have also been taken at the Ocean City bridge and in Barnegat Bay Inlet near jetties. Bluefish of more than 10 pounds have been caught in waters about eight miles off Seaside park and Avalon.
