Grace Company announced an agreement in principle to acquire Pic 'N Pay, a 348-unit chain of self-service shoe stores and leased departments, through an exchange of one share of Grace for every 2.3 shares of Pic 'N Pay common stock. Pic 'N Pay would continue to operate under its present management.

Washington and Moscow announced the other day that their scientists will soon begin joint studies for two types of possible cooperative space ventures. One will explore the potentiality of using our space shuttle and the Soviet Union's Salyut space station for joint projects in the early 1980's; the second concerns the possible later usefulness of a Soviet-American station in space.

Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein and a group of Yorkville tenant leaders charged that the city's Housing and Development Administration had allowed a landlord to let a four-block area deteriorate so that a nursing-home owner could expand his operations.

LIBERTY, Tex., May 26 (AP) A Liberty County grand jury ruled today that there was no criminal responsibility involved in an accident in which a jet-powered boat driven by Dan Pastorini. Houston Oiler quarterback, crashed into a crowd in Liberty County last Sunday. Two persons died as a result of the mishap.

THE HOLIDAY WEEKEND begins on a note of quiet charm with an interview with Anne Morrow Lindbergh, her first for television, tonight at 8 on CBS. It ends in unexpected disappointment Monday night at 9 with a new production of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town." The generally subdued schedule also includes a profile of South Africa's Afrikaaners in "The White Laager," a Swedish documentary carried on Channel 13 at 9 this evening.

HOUSTON, May 26 Every day at post offices, telegraph offices and border crossing points throughout the United States, millions of dollars disappear from the nation's economy. Gas leaks nave been so frequent at the huge Co-op City housing projects in the Bronx that Consolidated Edison now checks each of the development's 35 highrise buildings every day to prevent the situation from "getting out of hand" and creating a possible emergency, the utility said yesterday.

MIAMI, May 26 (AP) Arthur Chalk, the founder of the world's oldest airline, Chalk's International Airline Inc., died today. He was 88 years old.

MADISON, Wis., May 26 (UPI) When a 15-year-old boy raped a girl in a stairwell at West High School, Judge Archie Simonson ruled yesterday, he was reacting "normally" to prevalent sexual permissiveness and women's provocative clothing.

SALZBURG, Austria-West Germany is preparing to build the world's first fully integrated "fuel cycle park" atop a geologic formation in which it would deposit all the most radioactive wastes generated by German nuclear plants for the next several generations.

VALERIE CARTER, who opens the show for a three-night run by Country Joe McDonald at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, starting tonight, put out her first record a few months ago. It was called "Just a Stone's Throw Away," and it was warmly received by most of the press, even by those normally resistent to the Los Angeles woman singer-songwriter genre.

ALBANY,May 26 Three Democratic Assemblymen all elected with Conservative Party endorsements introduced a bill today that would retain criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana but would insure that no first offender went to jail.

OTTAWA, May 27 Forecasting an early end to the controversial wage and price controls instituted at the end of 1975, the Canadian Government proposed today that a new agency be established to monitor increases in pay and costs here after the present restrictions are lifted.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 27 (AP) St. John's posted a 3-2 victory today and eliminated Seton Hall from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Northeast regional college baseball tournament.

SYRACUSE Ten years ago, John Lockett, the president of Local 320 of the International Union of Electrical Workers, recalled, thousands of workers would arrive up to an hour early to get a parking space close to their plants in the gigantic parking lots surrounding General Electric's Electronics Park here.

New York State's special anticorruption prosecutor, John F. Keenan, announced yesterday that he would not appeal the dismissal of an indictment against Patrick J. Cunningham, but would continue to seek evidence against the Bronx leader and his law partner, Joseph S. Kaming.

Nan Elizabeth Rypins Malkin, a psychiatric social worker at the Center for Mental Health of the Manchester (Conn.) Memorial Hospital, and Dr. Donald L. Shapiro, the medical director of the center, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the home of Drs. Sylvia and Francis Helfrick in Manchester by Rabbi Neil Kominsky.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) The Senate Rules Committee voted today to remove primary election campaigns from a bill extending public financing to Senate elections and lowered the amount of campaign money each candidate could spend. It also voted to allow specified Senate aides to solicit campaign contributions.
CHICAGO, May 27 After nearly eight years of Federal pressure, the Board of Education has agreed to integrate Chicago's public school teachers in apparent compliance with Federal guidelines.

NEW DELHI, May 27 The United States, making a good will gesture to the new Government of India, announced today that it had decided to resume the interrupted supply of enriched uranium for a nuclear power plant near Bombay.

ESSEX, Conn., May 27 The Ivoryton Playhouse, a mainstay of the summer strawhat theater circuit in New England for 47 years, will not open this season, Kenneth Krezel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., its owner, said yesterday.
The Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger, warned yesterday that unless new ways were found to settle disputes, the country might be "overrun by hordes of lawyers hungry as locusts."

WASHINGTON, May 27 The House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee today recommended cuts of $2.7 billion in President Carter's proposed defense budget, making a long series of small reductions without eliminating any major weapons system Mr. Carter had sought.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus is naming two National Park Service career employees with experience in urban parks to direct the service, a spokesman said today.

The Boston Musica Viva's concert Thursday night at the 92nd Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A, had its charms, but it didn't quite live up to its advance billing in two ways. The showpiece of the concert was supposed to have been the world premiere of "Clear Leaps" by Lucia Dlugoszewski. The premiere had already been postponed twice and this time she said that the manuscript had been stolen at an airport.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 27 The second major event of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. 1977 was a performance of Gian Carlo Menotti's "The Consul" last night at the Gaillard Municipal Theater. But the events closest to the hearts of the audience so far have been the noonday chamber-music recitals. There have been two so far at the 480-seat Dock Theater. Both have been sold out, and have been greeted with enthusiasm little short of frantic.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Defense Department said today that it planned to start withholding state taxes July 1 from the pay of service personnel with legal residences in 13 states.

Leaders of the Co-op City housing project in the Bronx say that their compromise agreement with New York State which last summer ended a long bitter residents' "strike" over maintenance charges is "on the verge of breaking up."

Future prices of live beef cattle closed mixed while those of feeder cattle finished up and those of live hogs closed mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday.
JERUSALEM, May 27 Moshe Dayan quit the Labor Party today as the furor over his acceptance of the post of Foreign Minister in a prospective Likud government increased.
The reason for the high rate of unemployment is Henry Kissinger. Every time a new job opens up, Kissinger grabs it before anybody else can apply.

Mayor Beame yesterday accepted $1.10 to settle the city's $250,000 suit against George H. Willig, the Queens mountain climber who, on Thursday, became New York's newest folk hero by scaling the 1,350-foot South Tower of the World Trade Center.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 (Reuters) Lebanese right-wing leaders announced tonight they considered the 1969 Cairo agreement that regulates the activities of Palestinians in Lebanon as null and void and the Palestinian presence as illegal.

DETROIT, May 27 Mark Fidrych, The Bird of baseball and the biggest draw in the big leagues, returned to the public stage tonight as he had left it before his operation talking to the ball and himself, pacing around the pitcher's mound, smoothing the dirt on hands and knees, and prompting 44,207 cheering fans to raise the roof of Tiger Stadium.
With a security force of 200 Pinkertons and policemen standing guard, ontrack wagering began yesterday at strike-bound Belmont Park after four days of betless racing.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The budget director, Bert Lance, and the Civil Service Commission chairman, Alan K. Campbell, announced today the start of a "top-to-bottom study leading to reorganization of Federal personnel management."

The opening moments of Joan Baez's Thursday evening concert at the Palladium could not have been improved upon. A soprano saxophonist wearing a red jumpsuit rode onto the stage on a unicycle playing the saxophone and honking bicycle horns. "You know the words," he shouted out gruffly at one point. "I know the melody."

ALBANY, May 27 The State Board of Regents, which voted six months ago to dismiss Ewald B. Nyquist as State Education Commissioner, today chose his executive deputy, Gordon Mac Kay Ambach, to succeed him.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 Gerard Kauper, executive director of the Atlantic City Convention Bureau, said today that hotels in Cherry Hill 50 miles away might be requested to help house some of the, conventions seeking to come to the resort in 1978 and 1979.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 If the Mets ever run out of money to pay Tom Seaver's $225,000 annual salary, Tommy Hutton of the Phillies might be willing to contribute a little from his $50,000 or so to keep the righthander around.

ROSELLE, N.J., May 27 Ch. Grey Roc Winged Victory, a brindle greyhound bitch, scored over 952 other contenders today for her third best-inshow award at the Union County Kennel Club's 39th all-breed dog show at the Warinanco Park ice skating rink.

CENTEREACH, N.Y. In his few months in office, President Carter has made human rights a household phrase. It is an "I'm for " concept that grabs even stronger than the support of motherhood and flag. Human rights has been a household term in my world since I learned to think.

Max Roach, the drummer, whose engagement this week and next at Storyville, 58th Street at Madison Avenue, marks his first performance in a New York club in seven years, is leading a quartet that is a surprising and fascinating reflection of his own approach to drumming.

GENEVA, May 27 The United States today urged all sugar exporting and importing countries to "rethink" their positions in preparation for a new effort to reach an agreement on a price-stabilizing pact that eluded them during a six-week conference here.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 27 A team of psychiatrists continued negotiating today with South Moluccan terrorists who have freed 105 children and a teacher from a village school but are still holding 60 hostages there and in a commuter train they seized Monday.
ALBANY, May 27 Joseph F. Crangle of Buffalo, Erie County Democratic chairman, is scheduled to appear next Tuesday in Albany Police Court on a charge of driving while intoxicated.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The United States and Panama may be near a breakthrough in their negotiations for a new treaty for the Canal Zone, an American source said today.

They want to believe that once these flaws are corrected, the city will resume its normal growth: The Big Apple will become the Ever Bigger Apple.

LONDON, May 27 After nine hectic days, the auction of the contents of one of England's great houses, Mentmore Towers, ended today, raising a total of 6,032,543 ($10.3 million), far more than anyone had expected.

WASHINGTON, May 27 A Senate committee, the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department are investigating alleged monopolistic practices in the sale of eyeglasses that may cost American consumers as much as $400 million a year in excessive prices.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 27 (AP) Five men were charged tonight with the murder of Capt. Robert Nalrac, a British intelligence officer who disappeared May 14, the police said.

WASHINGTON, May 27 Delegates to the first White House Conference on Handicapped Individuals, who came to Washington this week hoping to adopt a national agenda of issues that concern the disabled, left for home today, many of them angry, disillusioned and wondering what had been accomplished.

ST. PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla., May 27 Worth C. Coutney, a former publisherr of The Chicago Herald American, vice president of the Hearst Publishing Company and Hearst Publications Inc. and an advertising and business agent executive of The Toledo News-Bee, Toledo Blade and Cleveland Press, died here Wednesday. He was 79 years old.
JOHANNESBURG, May 27 (AP) President Agostinho Neto of Angola announced today that his forces had crushed a revolt by army extremists after street fighting that killed many men and women.
OTTAWA, May 27 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his wife, Margaret, announced jointly today that they had separated and that Mr. Trudeau would retain custody of their three sons.

Mayor Beame yesterday accepted $1.10 to settle the city's $250,000 suit against George H. Willig, the Queens mountain climber who, on Thursday, became New York's newest folk hero by scaling the 1,350-foot South Tower of the World Trade Center.

Barbara H. Jacobs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven M. Jacobs of Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary L. Sussman, son of Mrs. Ruth Sussman of Teaneck, N.J., and Jerome Sussman of Edgewater, N.J.

MOSCOW, May 27 The unexpected ouster of President Nikolai V. Podgorny from the Communist Party's governing Politburo several days ago has been accompanied by several other enigmatic personnel shifts that suggest only that the political authority of the party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, is stronger than ever.

BUENOS AIRES, May 27 (AP) A rightist army general who had issued a veiled criticism of the plans of the Argentine military junta to eventually restore civilian government has been arrested, the newspaper Cronica said today.

Sig Mickelson, who was president of CBS News in the 1950's, said yesterday that his organization had cooperated with the Central Intelligence Agency to the extent of "sharing information" under implied instructions from William S. Paley, chairman of CBS Inc.

DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, May 22 In the stultifying afternoon heat, the grime-encrusted ceiling fans at the Cafe de Paris spin wildly to no avail. At the bar off-duty soldiers of the French Foreign Legion, in rolled up T-shirts and cut-off.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 27 A desegregation suit filed yesterday by the Kansas City Board of Education took the legal battle over school integration to another level by seeking desegregation not just across district lines but also across state boundaries.

Spurred by memories of a bitter winter and lured by the promise of near-perfect weather, millions of New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors took to the road yesterday for the Memorial Day weekend, the first long holiday of the summer season.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 27 Pride of Carlisle, a dazzling 5-year-old bay gelding who once was a run-ofthe-mill trotter because of an abundance of calcium in his hocks, gained his fourth straight victory at the Meadowlands tonight.
The Dow Jones industrial average sank yesterday below 900 considered a psychological barrier by many investors but Wall Street reacted with apparent calm.

ATLANTA, May 27 (AP) Dave Stockton, who won two P.G.A. national championships with some effective scrambling, resorted to that tactic today in shooting a three-under-par 69 that staked him to a share of the second-round lead in the $200,000 Atlanta Classic golf tournament.

MIDTOWN MEMORY LANE Weekend visitors to the Times Square area interested in seeing the new Songwriters' Hall of Fame Museum can do so now, because today it begins opening its doors on Saturdays from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. This is in addition to the regular weekday hours, at the same times Monday through Friday.

ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 27 A team of psychiatrists continued negotiating today with South Moluccan terrorists who have freed 106 children and a teacher from a village school but are still holding 60 hostages there and in a commuter train they seized Monday.

Citibank yesterday raised the basic rate it charges on loans to corporations by a quarter-point to 6 percent, the second such increase this month. By early evening most of the country's other giant banks followed the move.

Christopher R. Parrott, 34, the No. 2 man in the troubled Agri-Products division of Cook Industries Inc., Memphis, resigned yesterday. He was the second high-ranking vice president to leave the company in as many days. Willard R. Sparks, 39, senior executive vice president and head of the AgriProducts division, resigned Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 27 Northeastern urban communities, already hard hit by air pollution, "got left out in the smog," disappointed spokesmen for New York State and New Jersey said today in commenting on key parts of the new clean-air bill passed by the House yesterday.

Nearly 7,000 electronic wristwatches valued at more than $1 million were stolen from a Queens warehouse before dawn yesterday, but the police said they arrested three men, recovered the watches and solved the crime two hours before the burglary was discovered.

Few things in ballet could be more historically appropriate than American Ballet Theater's staging a small Fokine Festival in the midst of its longest-ever season at the Metropolitan Opera House. George E. Bryant, former executive dean of the Graduate School of Education of the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University in Brookville, L.I., died Wednesday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Clinton Corners, N.Y.

DEVON, Pa., May 27 Annihilator, an experienced Long Island mount, won the junior jumper class tonight and pulled into a tie for the lead for the championship at the Devon Horse Show.

Bob Lemon, the congenial manager of the Chicago White Sox, spent only one season as a coach with the Yankees. But that was long enough for him to get to know most of the characters in the Yankee cast that has become so entertaining to the rest of the baseball world.

The ongoing upheaval in the Roman Catholic church has predictably evoked extremes of response, Since Vatican II began in 1962 to update traditionbound attitudes and practices, both clergy and laity have manifest lovehate reactions to the passing of the old and the emergence of the new. Some Catholics like what they see, others remain loyal but anguished, still others leave.
AUGUSTA, Me., May 27 (AP) A bill aimed at removing the word "nigger" from the names of brooks, hills and islands in Maine was passed in the State Senate today and was sent to Gov. James B. Longley.

Under the memorandum of agreement signed between the City of New York and the United States Tennis Association, the 1978 United States Open championships will shift from the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens to a public tennis center to be built-in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens.

Representative Herman Badillo said yesterday that New york City could stop the flight of middle-class people to the suburbs by rebuilding the slums so that the poor would want and be able to stay where they live now.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 27 President Carter descended into the murky depths of the Atlantic today on a nuclear submarine cruise that mixed the politics of national defense with the nostalgia of his naval career.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) A Federal district judge refused today to order the Navy to reinstate a former officer who acknowleged committing homosexual acts while in the service.

Like many newcomers to New York City and more than a few natives George Weller of Kentucky was quickly stupefied by the intricacies of the subway system and the rainbow-hued spaghetti strands that purport to trace its tangled underground course.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The United Automobile Workers, long considered by many to be one of the nation's more progressive labor organizations, joined with the auto industry this week to help defeat stringent controls on car exhaust fumes.
A spokesman for the Loews Corporation said yesterday that the company was conducting a feasibility study to determine whether it would enter the casino hotel business in Atlantic City.

An explosion ripped through a paint factory in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, killing two employees and injuring nine others, including two firemen who fought the blaze which raged for nearly two hours.
Gwendolyn Grace Wall, daughter of Grace Audrey Wall of Huntington, L.I., and C. Robert Wall of New York, was married yesterday to Allen Kent Merrill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen H. Merrill of New York.

LARCHMONT, N,Y., May 27 A foul, a near-collision, and a daring starboard tack maneuver that did not quite come off, were the exciting elements of the start at dusk today of the Storm Trysail Club's annual race to Block Island and back.

With a cast on his right arm and purplish bruises on his boyish face, Steve Cauthen was leaving Long Island Jewish Hospital in a wheelchair Wednesday when newsmen surrounded him.

TRENTON, May 27 Representing what it described as "the 1,180,799 citizens who voted against casino gambling," a coalition of church organizations and other citizen's groups appealed to Governor Byrne today not to sign the Casino Control Act until it is substantially strengthened against infiltration by organized crime.

PARIS, May 27 (UPI) Stan Smith overcame his dislike of clay courts today for a 6-4, 6-3, 7-5 victory over Juergen Fassbender of West Germany to join three other Americans in the round of 32 of the $330,000 French open tennis championships.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., May 27 (AP) A total of 401 sit-in demonstrators at the University of California, Santa Cruz, were arrested before dawn today, capping protests at several of the university's campuses where dmands included ending university ties with companies with financial interests in South Africa.

A legislative committee looking into the New York City school system's testing procedures heard a former school district testing and research official testify yesterday that a few months after he left his post he sold testing and evaluation materials to his former school district.

WASHINGTON, May 27 The House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee today recommended cuts of $2.7 billion in President Carter's proposed defense budget, making a long series of small reductions without eliminating any major weapons system Mr. Carter had sought.
A Federal Court judge in Manhattan called yesterday for a national investigation into the disclosure in The New York Times of non-public information relating to terrorist bombings.

On the basis of an autopsy, Ulster County authorities said yesterday that Gertrude Resnick Farber died of suffocation after she was kidnapped and buried alive in a wooden box near the remote Catskill Mountain town of Grahamsville, N.Y. last Tuesday.

The state's fiscal watchdog for New York City said yesterday that if everything that could go wrong did go wrong, Mayor Beame's proposed budget for next year would be out of balance by as much as $970 million. This view was publicly attacked by the Mayor's aides and pri- vately scorned by the State Emergency Financial Control Board staff.

Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, fined Darryl Dawkins of the Philadelphia 76ers and Maurice Lucas of the Portland Trail Blazers $2,500 each yesterday for their parts in the fourthquarter brawl in Thursday night's game. O'Brien also ordered Gene Shue and Jack Ramsay, the coaches, to hold a meeting with their teams before tomorrow afternoon's third game of the championship series in Portland, Ore., to "review the seriousness of the situation."

PARIS One of the major if hitherto unasked questions of worried France is what will the army do if, as is likely, next year's legislative elections produce a left-wing parliamentary majority and a Cabinet including Communist ministers. In other words, would there be any possibility of army intervention to frustrate the nation's expressed will?

A State Supreme Court jury in Riverhead, L.I., last night found Walter B. Carey guilty of the fatal beating of a Long Island teen-ager, turning aside the defense contention that she died when doctors removed her from a respirator, four days after the beating.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., May 27?As the Bergen County Prosecutor's office began considering today the possible indictment of a Manhattan man charged with a druglaw violation for carrying prescription tranquilizers in an unmarked container, support seemed to be growing in the State Legislature for a new amendment to exclude thousands of legitimate medical patients in New Jersey from the law's provisions and penalties.

OTTAWA, May 27 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his wife, Margaret, announced jointly today that they had separated and that Mr. Trudeau would retain custody of their three sons.

HAVANA, May 27 (Reuters) A Soviet airliner crashed as it was coming into land at Havana Airport today, killing 56 passengers and 10 crew members, according to an official communique from the Cuban Government.

CINCINNATI, May 27 Both the men and women of the Procter Gamble Company are getting the option of taking a six-month "child-care leave" when they adopt or have a baby.

WASHINGTON, May 27 President Carter has worked out an arrangement with Senator Henry M. Jackson to provide key Senate leaders with up-to-date information on strategic arms negotia tions through Mr. Jackson's subcommittee in an effort to prevent a major fight on the Senate floor if a treaty is ever signed with the Soviet Union.

The marriage of Winifred Feldman, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Robert J. Feldman of Washington, to Thomas G. Lavely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hal Lavely of Story City, Iowa, took place yesterday. Superior Court Judge Florence Murray performed the ceremony in her chambers in Providence, R.I.

DETROIT, May 27 After years of allowing its five car divisions to place their brand names on engines inside their cars, the General Motors Corporation has decided in principle to drop the practice starting with its 1978 model cars, several knowledgeable persons within the company said today.

TBILISI, U.S.S.R. The Soviet Army is gradually destroying an ancient cave monastery in southern Georgia by refusing to shift the site of an artillery range, according to a former government official who lost his job after waging a lonely campaign to save the complex.

WASHINGTON, May 27 After a sharp upward revision in the first quarter's growth rate, the Government signaled today through an index designed to predict future trends that the economy may continue to grow strongly, but at a somewhat slower pace.

KUWAIT The Kuwait Stock Exchange will probably never challenge the supremacy of the Big Board, but on the basis of trading activity the lifeblood of any market its backers believe the future is assured. In an effort to cut costs, the New York City Transit Authority announced that it would begin testing a time-hon ored power-saving technique known to every teen-ager with Dad's borrowed car and little money for gasoline that is coasting.

LONDON, May 27 (AP) The dollar rose or held steady against several major European currencies in modest trading today. This performance was in contrast to the dollar's overall decline in the four previous sessions this week.

YAPHANK, L.I, May 27 Parr Meadows, which last night concluded its first full week as a quarter-horse racing plant, has not been "knocking them dead" at the turnstiles. Track officials, however, insist livelier times lie ahead. Despite ideal weather only 2,065 turned out for last night's regular nine-race program.

Surrogate Samuel A. Spiegel of Manhattan, who in 21 years as an Assemblyman and judge devoted himself to fighting the battles of such "little guys" as public housing tenants, widows, and orphans, died Thursday night of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

TROMBETAS, Brazil Jose Carvalho Santos left his small town in Brazil's dusty, impoverished northeast six years ago. He could have followed many of his unemployed neighbors to the booming industrial centers of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. But instead he headed west to the Amazon frontier where early in the 1970's the military Government began the first serious effort to conquer the jungles that extend over more than half of the country.

BIG striped bass moving north from the Chesapeake Bay hit off Montauk a few days ago and should offer fine action now. Hudson River bass, fanning eastward along the North Shore, also should provide good catches for experienced fishermen.

Tompkins of Thornwood, N.Y. The Rev. John Daley performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church.

AMERICANS are now engaged in a loud protest over the impending ban on saccharin, the sole remaining artificial sweetener on the market. It is puzzling to note that, upon the publication of experiments indicating that large amounts of saccharin cause bladder cancer among rats, our major reaction is to hoard and consume as much of the sweetener as possible. Has anyone actually stopped using this food ingredient since its harmful effects were revealed?

Two high emissaries of the Carter Administration, Vice President Mondale and Andrew Young, chief delegate to the United Nations, have returned from extended journeys to explain Washington's Africa policy to the parties directly involved. A CONVIVIAL spirit radiates through L'Auberge Bretonne. The owners greet old friends and introduce themselves to new ones. It is clear that in its 16 years of existence the Auberge has become for many that lovely little French country inn so often sought yet so rarely found.

Even in January, you might feel that a gin and tonic would be the appropriate drink to sip before dinner as you sit in green and white captain's chairs at the clean white Parsons tables.

The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish by the vicar, the Rev. Bertram H. Herlong. He was assisted by the Rev. Howard Calkins of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church.

THE Hartford Stage Company's production of George Bernard Shaw's "Candida," which runs through June 12, is an historic one. It marks the end of the H.S.C.'s 14season, 88-play run in a drugstore warehouse. A few blocks away on Church Street the new theater long wanted, long awaited is already rising.

Patrice Armstrong and Lloyd Samuel Clareman of New York were married yesterday in Bath, Ohio. Edwin Male Jr., a bishop in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (Mormon), performed the ceremony in the chapel of the church's Akron Ward.

Francis Shattuck Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Landgrove, was married to Richard Hendrik Stenhuis of Zwolle, the Netherlands. He is the son of Mrs. H. Stenhuis-Bleeker and the late Jan Stenhuis of Groningen, the Netherlands. The Rev. Edward O. Miller, former rector of St. George's Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

The morning is rising into 80-degree temperatures as Mr. Merolli dashes off through the underbrush to a sign reading, "SIDE VAULT OVER BAR, THEN RETURN UNDERNEATH."

WASHINGTON, May 29 (Reuters) President Carter said in an interview published today that the deployment of American tactical nuclear weapons in the Pacific implied their possible use, if necessary, to defend South Korea in case of an invasion from the North.

Goddard Lieberson, president of Columbia Records for 19 years, who introduced long-playing records to the American public, died of cancer early yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

Sara Winston, an artist and a teacher, died Friday of a heart attack at Columbus Hospital. A former resident of South Orange, N.J., she had lived in Greenwich Village for the last 16 years. She was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 29 Taking up where the Ford Administration left off, the Carter Administration plans to end price and supply controls for gasoline next fall.
TAMPA, Fla., May 29 The Tampa Bay Rowdies spoiled Franz Beckenbauer's United States debut today, and from now on this city is likely to be known more for its soccer than for its cigars.

CLINTON, N.Y., May 29 Alex Haley returned to his own roots today, delivering the commencement address at Hamilton College, where he was on the faculty for two years and where he wrote the first rough draft of his best-selling novel "Roots."
Manuel Davett Nadal, athletic director emeritus and assistant to the dean of the Kent School for Boys in Kent, Conn., died Friday in a fire that engulfed his home on the campus. He was 80 years old.

The curiosity and imagination of cooks and others who read this column are seemingly without limit. We recently wrote a column stating that Parisienne spice, which is used in making pates and terrines in the French kitchen, is no longer imported into this country. We added that the formula for making the spice mixture varied but often included thyme, bay leaf, coriander seeds, mace and so on.

In her tiny office on the fifth floor of the round building that houses the state-owned radio and television stations of France, she shouted. She thrashed the air with her arms. She pounded her fists on her desk. She stamped her feet. She jumped up and down in her seat. And she kicked a desk drawer.

PARIS, May 29 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived here today in a bid to improve relations between the rich and poor nations of the world by successfully winding up the 18-month Conference on International Economic Cooperation, informally referred to as the northsouth talks.

After a week of play that began with 67 teams, the Reisinger knockout team championship ended in the early hours of Saturday morning in a victory for a team led by Alan Greenberg of New York. SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 29 A fastspreading fire, pouring heavy, blinding smoke throughout one of the largest nightclubs in the Middle West, killed at least 160 persons last night and injured 130. HARRISBURG, Pa., May 29 (UPI) Sandra Spuzich shot a final round of 67 for a 201 today to come within one shot of the 54-hole record on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour and win the $50,000 Ladies Keystone open. Her earlier rounds were 68 and 66.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, proposed today that personal allow ances for high-ranking generals and admirals be eliminated.

Traders in commodity futures are often described as people who either buy goods they don't want or sell goods they don't have. Actually, what they buy and sell are contracts involving the future delivery and acceptance of commodities.

The variety and breadth within the classical ballet idiom were demonstrated with no trouble at all Saturday. In the end, the only measure of a foreign policy lies in the claims it is allowed to make on domestic interest. Worthy goals do not begin at the water's edge; they usually cost something that society is or is not persuaded to pay. War is the extreme example; free trade the almost daily test. Without a domestic price, a policy of wishing other nations well and bidding them cooperate is so much piety.
